THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN 
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Shannon Knox McKinney, Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Larry A. McKinney, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-600
  Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 3, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        T. Preston Reid, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent.
        Jack D. Griffeth, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Shannon Knox and Larry McKinney both appeal from a family 
  court order finding that Knox and McKinney were not married under common law 
  from 1993 to 1998 and that a bifurcated evidentiary trial needed to be held 
  to determine if a common law marriage existed between the parties from 1998 
  to 2002.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
  [1] 
FACTS
 Knox and McKinney were romantically involved and lived together 
  from August 1993 to January 2002.Â  During that time, neither party maintained 
  a separate residence.Â  The couple lived in four different homes during the eight 
  years they lived together, including a home they built together in 1996.Â  McKinney 
  is an electrical engineer and a successful businessman who owns and is a partner 
  in many businesses.Â  Knox, who has a high school education, was responsible 
  for household duties such as cleaning and buying groceries.Â  
Knox claims the couple held themselves â€œout as husband and wife to 
  the general public, friends and neighbors, in business relations, and in many 
  organizations with which [the couple was] associated.â€Â  She also claims the 
  couple had family memberships at gyms and private clubs, including the Greenville 
  Country Club.Â  Additionally, Knox asserts the couple held a joint checking account 
  at a local bank.Â  Further, Knox submitted copies of their water and power contract, 
  listing her as McKinneyâ€™s spouse.Â  However, McKinney claims that both parties 
  did not intend to be married and used different names throughout their relationship, 
  including tax returns, bank accounts, and driverâ€™s licenses.Â  McKinney also 
  alleges they used separate names when introducing themselves to others and in 
  written contracts.Â  McKinney submitted affidavits from 16 individuals who knew 
  the couple and stated that they did not hold themselves out to the public as 
  a married couple.Â Â Â  
In 1998, the couple decided to purchase a condominium in Greenville.Â  Knox 
  claims that McKinney told her she had to sign a â€œWaiver Agreementâ€ before they 
  could close on the condominium.Â  The Waiver Agreement stated that â€œalthough 
  [Knox and McKinney] may live together, date and see [each] other on a frequent 
  basis, they are not husband and wife, either legally or by common law.â€Â  The 
  agreement further provided that it could be â€œpresented [in court] as conclusive 
  and binding evidence that the parties have never been married to each other.â€Â  
  Knox claims that McKinney and his attorney pressured her into signing the agreement.Â  
  She further claims that she did not sign it freely or voluntarily and that she 
  was fraudulently induced to sign it.Â  McKinney argues that Knox consulted with 
  an attorney before signing the agreement.Â  The couple separated in January 2002.Â 
On July 2, 2002, Knox filed a motion for temporary relief and a complaint seeking 
  alimony and equitable distribution of the coupleâ€™s property based on the coupleâ€™s 
  common law marriage.Â  On August 19, 2002, McKinney filed an answer and a motion 
  to dismiss on the grounds that the parties are not husband and wife, and therefore, 
  the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The motion was heard on August 
  29, 2002.Â  On September 9, 2002, the family court filed its order finding that 
  Knox and McKinney were not married under common law because of the Waiver Agreement.Â  
  Thus, the court found it was without subject matter jurisdiction to adjudicate 
  Knoxâ€™s claims and dismissed the action under Rule 12(b), SCRCP.Â  The court further 
  determined that any irregularity in the consummation of the Waiver Agreement 
  should be tested in the Court of Common Pleas.Â  
On September 16, 2002, Knox filed a motion for a new trial and/or motion to 
  alter or amend judgment, arguing the court erred in finding it did not have 
  subject matter jurisdiction and by denying Knox a full evidentiary hearing as 
  to the existence of a common law marriage.Â  The motion was heard on October 
  30, 2002.Â  On December 2, 2002, the family court filed an amended order, finding 
  that it did have subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to section 20-7-420(5) 
  of the South Carolina Code (1985).Â  The court then found that â€œwhether the intent 
  of the parties to remain unmarried changed after January 30, 1998 is 
  a question of fact to be found from evidence showing their mutual intent after 
  that dateâ€ (emphasis added).Â  The court granted a bifurcated evidentiary trial 
  â€œlimited to determine the existence/non-existence of a common law marriage between 
  the parties after January 30, 1998â€ (emphasis added).Â  Knox and McKinney 
  both now appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
    
The issue of common law marriage is a case at law.Â  
  Richland Memorial Hosp. v. English, 295 S.C. 511, 513, 369 S.E.2d 395, 
  396 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without 
  a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal 
  unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  
  Townes Assoc., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 
  773, 775 (1976).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
    

  
On appeal, Knox argues the family court erred in finding she and McKinney were 
  not married under common law before the parties signed the January 30, 1998 
  Waiver Agreement. 
Section 20-7-420(5) of the South Carolina Code (1985) grants the family court 
  exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine the validity of marriages.Â  â€œIn 
  South Carolina, a common-law marriage exists if the parties intend to enter 
  into a marriage contract.â€Â  Barker v. Baker, 330 S.C. 361, 367, 499 S.E.2d 
  503, 506 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œIt is essential to a common law marriage that there 
  shall be a mutual agreement between the parties to assume toward each other 
  the relation of husband and wife.Â  Cohabitation without such an agreement does 
  not constitute marriage.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 235 S.C. 542, 550, 112 
  S.E.2d 647, 651 (1960).Â  â€œA valid common law marriage requires that the facts 
  and circumstances show an intention on the part of both parties to enter into 
  a marriage contract.â€Â  Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 545, 466 S.E.2d 
  373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The party claiming a common law marriage must prove 
  it by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Yarbrough v. Yarbrough, 280 S.C. 
  546, 551, 314 S.E.2d 16, 18-19 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, direct evidence of 
  the partiesâ€™ intent is not often available, thus the existence of a common-law 
  marriage is frequently proved by circumstantial evidence.Â  Barker, 330 
  S.C. at 367-368, 499 S.E.2d at 507.Â  Typically, the circumstantial evidence 
  relied upon to prove a common-law marriage is the amount of time a couple has 
  lived together and whether the couple publicly held themselves out as husband 
  and wife.Â  Id.Â  â€œWhile the presumption of marriage from cohabitation 
  and reputation is ordinarily a rebuttable presumption, the degree of proof to 
  overcome it is generally very high, especially where the parties have cohabitated 
  as husband and wife for a long time.â€Â  Owens, 320 S.C. at 546, 466 S.E.2d 
  at 375.Â  â€œThe presumption of marriage can be dispelled only by evidence which 
  is â€˜clear, distinct and satisfactory.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Jeanes v. Jeanes, 
  255 S.C. 161, 177 S.E.2d 537 (1970)).Â  Thus, the family court was required to 
  determine if Knox presented enough evidence of a common law marriage to trigger 
  the presumption.
        
In its order, the family court concluded that Knox had failed to prove that 
  she and McKinney were married under common law from 1993 to 1998.Â  On appeal, 
  because this is an action at law, we are bound by the family courtâ€™s findings 
  of fact unless they are without evidence to support them.Â  The presumption of 
  a common law marriage is triggered by proof of cohabitation and reputation as 
  husband and wife.Â  Knox stated at both hearings that she needed more time for 
  discovery and requested an evidentiary trial.Â  By failing to hold a trial, Knox 
  was deprived of her right to put up her own witnesses and cross-examine the 
  witnesses against her. [2] Â  Thus, the court erred by not 
  holding an evidentiary trial to determine the coupleâ€™s marital status from 1993 
  to 1998.Â  
On cross appeal, McKinney argues the family court erred in determining that 
  an evidentiary trial should be held to determine if the parties remained unmarried 
  after the January 30, 1998 Waiver Agreement. 
        
  
          Because we hold an evidentiary trial 
            should be held to determine whether Knox and McKinney were married 
            from 1993 to 1998, we affirm the family courtâ€™s determination that 
            an evidentiary trial should be held to establish the coupleâ€™s status 
            from 1998 to 2002.
          AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
            AND REMANDED.
          
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

        
       [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
        to Rule 215, SCACR.
       
        [2]  Our supreme court has acknowledged that, â€œ[t]he right to confrontation, 
        although historically limited to criminal prosecutions, has been applied 
        in the civil context.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Servs. ex rel. 
        Texas v. Holden, 319 S.C. 72, 78, 459 S.E.2d 846, 849 (1995).Â  In 
        determining when the right to confrontation applies, our supreme court 
        stated, â€œWhere important decisions turn on questions of fact, due process 
        requires an opportunity to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses.â€Â  
        Brown v. South Carolina State Board of Education, 301 S.C. 326, 
        329, 391 S.E.2d 866, 867 (1990).

PER CURIAM:Â  In April 2003, Darius Holcomb 
  was tried and found guilty of three counts of kidnapping and one

After a thorough review of the record pursuant

title: Moring v. Moring
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Amber E. Moring, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        James R. Moring, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â Frances P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-605
  Heard November 10, 2004 â€“ Filed December 3, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART 
  AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Stephan Victor Futeral, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
        Susan Trout Kinard, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce action, Husband appeals from an order of 
  the family court asserting the family court erred in (1) apportioning marital 
  debt, (2) finding certain property to be transmuted into marital property, (3) 
  determining child care costs for child support purposes, (4) requiring Husband 
  to pay a percentage of private school tuition, (5) requiring Husband to attend 
  anger management, (6) determining Wifeâ€™s income in previous and more recent 
  years, (7) determining Husbandâ€™s income, (8) ordering Husband to return an engagement 
  ring to Wife, (9) awarding Wife $28,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees, and (10) dismissing 
  Husbandâ€™s Rule to Show Cause . We affirm in part, and reverse in part and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife were married on May 11, 1996 and have two daughters, Alex 
  who was four and Mimi who was fifteen months at the time of the final hearing.Â  
  They separated in March, 2000, while Wife was pregnant with Mimi.Â Â  On March 
  15, 2000, Wife filed this action seeking, among other things, a divorce on the 
  ground of physical cruelty, custody, child and spousal support, possession of 
  the marital home, equitable division of marital assets and debts, and attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  Husband answered, denying the material allegations, and counterclaimed 
  seeking custody and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Following an October 25, 2001 hearing in a bifurcated trial, the family court 
  granted Wife a divorce on the ground of one year continuous separation, and 
  incorporated the partiesâ€™ agreement giving Wife custody and providing a partial 
  agreement regarding Husbandâ€™s visitation, with the final agreement to be determined 
  when the hearing reconvened.Â  The Court reconvened on January 10 and 14, 2002, 
  and thereafter issued its order (1) requiring Husband to pay the partiesâ€™ marital 
  debt of $9,500 on the Providian credit card debt, (2) finding the Husbandâ€™s 
  condominium had been transmuted into marital property and awarding Husband possession 
  of the home but finding Wife was entitled to fifty percent equity in the home, 
  (3) finding the engagement ring non-marital and awarding Wife ownership and 
  possession of it, (4) further setting forth Husbandâ€™s visitation, (5) determining 
  retroactive child support and ongoing child support based on previous and current 
  incomes of the parties, (6) finding the expenses of a nanny to be reasonable 
  child care expenses for child support determinations, (7) ordering Husband to 
  pay fifty percent of the cost of private school tuition for the children, and 
  (8) ordering Husband to pay $28,000 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has the authority to find the 
  facts in accordance with its own view of preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford 
  v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad 
  scope of review does not, however, require this court to disregard the findings 
  of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 
  S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  Neither are we required to ignore the fact that the 
  trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry 
  v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Providian Debt
Husband first contends the family court erred in failing to determine the final 
  amount he must pay on the Providian bank card debt.Â  He contends, at the temporary 
  hearing, Wife represented there was a $9,500 balance owed to Providian, he was 
  ordered to pay $300 per month toward marital debt, and the court failed, in 
  the final order, to give him credit for $7,200 he had paid toward the debt.Â  
  He asks this court to find the balance owed by him on the debt to be $2,300.Â  

The record shows, following a temporary hearing on April 12, 2000, Husband 
  was ordered to pay $300 toward debts listed on Wifeâ€™s financial declaration.Â  
  This amount apparently was not limited to just the Providian debt, and the order 
  did not specifically mention a Providian debt.Â  Other than Wifeâ€™s January 2002 
  financial declaration submitted at the final hearing, the only other evidence 
  showing the Providian debt is an unsigned, undated financial declaration of 
  the Wife during the time of her previous employment, which indicates a Providian 
  debt balance of $9,500.Â  Because this document is not signed or dated, it is 
  impossible to determine whether the Providian debt was $9,500 at the time of 
  the temporary hearing.Â  At any rate, this document shows debt from at least 
  four other major credit cards with a total balance of $35,900, not including 
  the Providian balance.Â  By the time of the final hearing, Wifeâ€™s financial declaration 
  showed a Providian debt balance of $9,500, but listed only two other major credit 
  card debts totaling a little over $17,000.Â  Wife testified at the final hearing 
  that the only marital credit card debt left was the Providian debt.Â  Thus, even 
  if we were to consider this unsigned, undated document as evidence, it shows 
  Wife paid down a substantial portion of the credit card debt.Â  Because none 
  of the proceedings from the temporary hearing are included within the record, 
  it is impossible to determine which of these various debts were purported to 
  be marital at the time of the temporary hearing.Â  See Wint v. Wint, 
  310 S.C. 48, 50, 425 S.E.2d 48, 50 (Ct. App. 1992) (the burden is on the appellant 
  to furnish a sufficient record on appeal from which this court can make an intelligent 
  review).Â  In the final order, the family court held it was uncontroverted that 
  the Providian debt of $9,500 was marital and Wife had been maintaining that 
  debt, â€œtogether with the $300 contribution from [Husband]â€ ordered after the 
  temporary hearing.Â  Given the record before us, based on our review of the totality 
  of the facts, we find a preponderance of the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s 
  determination that Husband should be responsible for the remaining debt owed 
  on the Providian card.
II. Transmutation of the Condominium
Husband next contends the family court erred in finding his condominium had 
  been transmuted into marital property because Wife only sought a â€œspecial equityâ€ 
  in the property, and therefore the family court should not have granted Wife 
  relief pursuant to the doctrine of transmutation.Â  We disagree.Â  
During Wifeâ€™s examination of Husband at trial, Husband testified he bought 
  the condominium in 1984 and he had made every mortgage payment on it except 
  for one that Wife made from money he had given her.Â  Counsel for Husband sought 
  clarification during this line of questioning stating: 

  It has always been their position that the condo is non-marital and they 
    were not wanting to try to show transmutation.Â  They may be just showing this 
    for a different purpose, but I want to be clear because it will affect my 
    questions.Â  And I donâ€™t know if they have reversed that position now or not.Â  
  

Wifeâ€™s counsel responded as follows: 

  Weâ€™re not interested in possession.Â  We have always put forth a claim as 
    a special equity in the condo for the wifeâ€™s contribution.Â  There has been 
    a lot of discovery going back and forth about proof of contribution during 
    the marriage.Â  And there would be no other reason for those questions and 
    the resulting responses unless thatâ€™s what we were doing.Â  And the pleadings 
    - -

At this point, the court cut counsel off and this line of questioning continued.Â  
  Later on during the hearing, when objecting to the relevance of certain questions 
  by Husbandâ€™s attorney, Wifeâ€™s attorney stated, â€œWe are seeking a share of the 
  marital home.â€Â  
Thereafter, Wife testified that for two years of the marriage, Husband made 
  little to no income while he was starting up a new business.Â  During this time, 
  Husband had no other source of income.Â  Wife testified she made at least three 
  payments herself to the mortgage company during this time.Â  She also stated 
  that Husband managed to pay the mortgage and other bills from money Wife gave 
  to him.Â  Wife claimed she used her pre-marital â€œnest eggâ€ money of $45,000 and 
  incurred $40,000 in debt to pay the bills during this time.Â  She further testified 
  she believed she had â€œearned an interest in that condominiumâ€ and she was â€œentitled 
  to share in this home [because she] supported [Husband] during the marriage.â€Â  
  The partiesâ€™ tax returns showed Husband earned business income of $4,934 in 
  1997 and sustained a net loss of $8,883 in 1998.Â  
Husband cites Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 529 S.E.2d 14 (2000) 
  in support of his argument that the family court should not have awarded Wife 
  relief pursuant to the doctrine of transmutation.Â  Husband quotes as follows 
  from Calhoun:Â  â€œSince the relief sought by petitioner was that of a special 
  equity, neither the family court nor the Court of Appeals erred in refusing 
  to grant her relief pursuant to the doctrine of transmutation.â€Â  Id. 
  at 107, 529 S.E.2d at 20.Â  However, in Calhoun, the court found that 
  petitioner limited the issue on appeal by the relief she sought when she only 
  asked that the market appreciation of the home be included in the marital estate.Â  
  The court held â€œ[a] family court cannot award relief beyond the scope of the 
  pleadings.â€Â  Id. at 107, 529 S.E.2d at 20.Â  Because the petitioner in 
  Calhoun had only sought a special equity, the family court properly declined 
  to afford her relief pursuant to the doctrine of transmutation.
Although Wifeâ€™s counsel did state Wife was seeking a â€œspecial equityâ€ in the 
  condominium, she also indicated her client was seeking â€œa share of the marital 
  home.â€Â  Further, Wife originally sought possession of the â€œmarital homeâ€ in 
  her complaint, as well as equitable distribution of marital assets.Â  At the 
  time Wifeâ€™s counsel used the term â€œspecial equity,â€ counsel specifically clarified 
  that they were no longer seeking possession of the home, and began to 
  argue Wifeâ€™s allegations in her pleadings, but was cut off by the court.Â  We 
  decline to find an inadvertent misstatement by Wifeâ€™s attorney should preclude 
  Wife from pursuing the relief properly requested in her pleadings.
III.Â  Child Care Costs
Husband next argues the family court erred in allowing $330 per week for child 
  care costs because the actual cost was only $300, a portion of the cost was 
  attributable to house cleaning, and the evidence showed reasonable day care 
  costs were between $173 and $228 per week.Â  We disagree.
The record shows that both of the partiesâ€™ children suffer from rather severe 
  asthma and allergy problems.Â  Husband admitted that when Alex was young, it 
  was not recommended that she attend day care because â€œher allergies were so 
  bad.â€Â  Wife testified she had a nanny to watch the children and that she did 
  not enroll the girls in day care because of their health conditions.Â  Wife stated 
  she paid the nanny $300 a week plus $30 for gasoline expenses for a total of 
  $330 a week.Â  Husband agreed to employment of the nanny, but merely objected 
  to Wife getting full credit for the amount paid to the nanny because he believed 
  the nanny also cleaned the house.Â  Wife admitted the nanny did clean on occasion, 
  but testified Wife did most of the cleaning, the vacuuming performed by the 
  nanny was necessary for two asthmatic children, and because the nanny had one 
  or both children with her the entire day, there was little time for her to clean.Â  
  Child support awards are addressed to the sound discretion of the family court 
  and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Patel 
  v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 531, 599 S.E.2d 114, 122 (2004).Â  The child care 
  arrangement is the same as it was before the parties separated, and it contemplates 
  the special health needs of the children.Â  Based on the record before us, we 
  find a preponderance of the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s determination 
  on this issue.
IV.Â  Private School TuitionÂ Â Â  
Husband next asserts the family court erred in requiring him to pay fifty percent 
  of the cost of private school tuition for the children.Â  He argues Wife failed 
  to specifically request this relief.Â  He further asserts there was no agreement 
  by the parties to send the children to private school and there were no special 
  circumstances warranting the cost of private school.Â  We agree.Â Â  
The only evidence of record concerning private school for the children is that, 
  at the time of trial, Alex was enrolled in First Scotts Kindergarten K-4 program.Â  
  Wife testified she believed the tuition for the school is $2,400 a year.Â  She 
  further stated Alex was attending First Scotts at the time the parties separated 
  and she intended to send Mimi there as well.Â  Despite the fact that no mention 
  was made of Husband sharing in these costs, the family court ordered Husband 
  to be responsible for fifty percent of the cost of private school tuition for 
  the children, finding â€œ[t]he parties had established a course of conduct during 
  their marriage of having [Alex] enrolled in private kindergarten. . . . â€Â  
It is clear Wife never requested Husband be required to contribute to private 
  school tuition in her complaint.Â  Neither is there any indication that the issue 
  of her entitlement to a contribution for private school tuition was raised at 
  the hearing such that the issue was tried by consent.Â  See Shirley 
  v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 340-341, 536 S.E.2d 427, 435 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting 
  when issues not raised in the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent, 
  they will be treated as if they had been raised in the pleadings).Â  Husband 
  was not, as Wife asserts, placed on notice Wife was seeking private school costs 
  for the children merely because Husband knew Alex was attending a private pre-school 
  program.Â  â€œDue process requires that a litigant be placed on notice of the issues 
  which the court is to consider and the rule that family court pleadings are 
  to be liberally construed may not be stretched so as to permit the judge to 
  award relief not contemplated by the pleadings.â€Â  Abbott v. Gore, 304 
  S.C. 116, 119, 403 S.E.2d 154, 156 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Accordingly, we find the 
  family court erred in ordering Husband to contribute to the childrenâ€™s private 
  school tuition.
V.Â  Anger Management
Husband argues the family court erred in ruling he was required to attend anger 
  management because there is insufficient evidence to show he has a problem with 
  anger.Â  We disagree.
Wife initiated this action seeking a divorce on the grounds of physical cruelty.Â  
  At the commencement of the hearing, Wife moved to amend her complaint to seek 
  a divorce on the ground of one-year continuous separation and the motion was 
  granted without objection.Â  However, Wife still testified to incidences where 
  Husband became verbally and physically abusive with her, at times in front of 
  their daughter.Â  Wife also admitted she had thrown drinks and soup at Husband 
  and had thrown some of Husbandâ€™s artwork off the balcony.Â  The guardian ad litem 
  testified to an incident she witnessed when she escorted Wife to retrieve some 
  personal property from the marital home and Husbandâ€™s anger escalated during 
  the visit.Â  After the incident, the guardian indicated to Wifeâ€™s attorney she 
  believed Husband needed anger management counseling.Â  The guardian testified, 
  while she thought Husband was a nice person, he directed anger at Wife, and 
  she believed Husband needed anger management to deal with it.Â  The family court 
  ordered both Husband and Wife to enroll in anger management courses.Â  Based 
  on the facts before us, we defer to the family court judge who saw and heard 
  the witnesses, and we find a preponderance of the evidence supports the courtâ€™s 
  determination that Husband should attend an anger management course.
VI. Â Wifeâ€™s Income
Husband next asserts error in the family courtâ€™s determination of Wifeâ€™s income 
  for purposes of determining retroactive and ongoing child support.Â  Specifically, 
  he contends the court found Wifeâ€™s gross monthly income in 2000 to be $2,947 
  when it was really $4,895 and further found her current gross monthly income 
  to be $3,410 when she actually earns gross monthly income of $6,712.Â  We disagree.
Wife testified she earned gross income of $35,366 in 2000.Â  While she had reported 
  a higher gross monthly figure on her financial declaration for the April 2000 
  temporary hearing, Wife testified she had not earned as much during the rest 
  of the year because she had gone on bed rest with her pregnancy, making much 
  less money during that year.Â  She further took a distribution from her IRA that 
  year in order to purchase her home, making her income appear higher.Â  Her 2000 
  tax return shows Wife earned wages of $35,366 and took an $18,500 distribution 
  from her IRA in the year 2000.Â  We find no error in the courtâ€™s finding on Wifeâ€™s 
  gross monthly income for the year 2000.Â  
As to the current income figure, Wifeâ€™s financial declaration at the final 
  hearing showed she was earning $1,594 in salary, received income of $1,116 in 
  the form of a forgivable loan, and earned $700 from other sources per month.Â  
  Wife testified she was receiving average commissions of $1,594 a month, received 
  a forgivable loan from her new employment accounting for $1,116 per month, and 
  received $700 a month in property management fees. Â Thus, the evidence supports 
  the courtâ€™s finding that Wife had a gross monthly income of $3,410 at the time 
  of the final hearing.Â  Further, Husband fails to show any basis for his assertion 
  Wife earned $4,895 a month in addition to the property management income and 
  forgivable loan.Â  
VII.Â  Husbandâ€™s Income
Husband next asserts 
  the family court erred in determining his income from self-employment, arguing 
  the court overstated gross receipts and failed to deduct a sufficient amount 
  for ordinary and necessary business expenses.Â  We find the evidence insufficient 
  to support the courtâ€™s determination on the gross receipts of the business, 
  but find sufficient evidence on the issue of expenses.
South Carolina Regulation 114-4720, governing the determination 
  of child support, provides in pertinent part as follows:
 
  (1) Definition.Â  The guidelines define income as the actual gross income 
    of the parent, if employed to full capacity, or potential income if unemployed 
    or underemployed. . . .
  (2) Gross Income.Â  Gross income includes income from any source including 
    salaries, wages, commissions, royalties, bonuses, rents (less allowable business 
    expenses), dividends, severance pay, pensions, interest, trust income, annuities, 
    capital gains, social security benefits (but not Supplemental Security Income), 
    workersâ€™ compensation benefits, unemployment insurance benefits, disability 
    insurance benefits, Veterans benefits and alimony, including alimony received 
    as a result of another marriage and alimony which a party receives as a result 
    of the current litigation.Â  Unreported case income should also be included 
    if it can be identified.
  *Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *
  (4) Income From Self-Employment or Operation of a Business.Â  For income from 
    self-employment, proprietorship of a business, or ownership of a partnership 
    or closely held corporation, gross income is defined as gross receipts minus 
    ordinary and necessary expenses required for self-employment or business operation, 
    including employerâ€™s share of FICA.Â  However, the court should exclude from 
    those expenses amounts allowed by the Internal Revenue Service for accelerated 
    depreciation or investment tax credits for purposes of the guidelines and 
    add those amounts back in to determine gross income.Â  In general, the court 
    should carefully review income and expenses from self-employment or operation 
    of a business to determine actual levels of gross income available to the 
    parent to satisfy a child support obligation.Â  As may be apparent, this 
    amount may differ from a determination of business income for tax purposes.

S.C. Reg. 114-4720(A) (emphasis added).
The family court order found Husband earned total commissions of $161,142 in 
  2000 and $153,506 in 2001.Â  Husbandâ€™s accounting expert testified Husband earned 
  gross income of $64,933 in the year 2000 and $68,243 for the year 
  2001.Â  She determined these figures based on the companyâ€™s general ledgers, 
  bank statements, and credit card statements.Â  Husband testified, and the business 
  tax return shows, Husbandâ€™s company had gross receipts of $133,969 in 2000.Â  
  Wife, on the other hand, testified she suspected Husband was underestimating 
  his income and that he had, in the past, failed to report all of his income 
  on his tax return.Â  Further, Husband admitted that at one time, when he was 
  employed to handle the personal affairs of an elderly woman, he failed to report 
  all of that income on his income tax return.Â  While Wife contends she put into 
  evidence Plaintiffâ€™s Exhibit # 22, Husbandâ€™s business bank statements through 
  the end of 2001 which purportedly show gross receipts â€œfor each of those years,â€ 
  the record does not show this specific exhibit is included.Â  Further, the record 
  does contain statements from the various business bank accounts, however, these 
  statements are so disorganized and voluminous that it is impossible to determine 
  whether there is any support for the family courtâ€™s finding on gross receipts 
  of the company.Â  While Wife may very well have provided evidence in support 
  of the figures used by the family court, this court is unable to verify the 
  figures through the record before us.Â  The family court was required to determine 
  gross receipts pursuant to S.C. Reg. 114-4720(A)(4).Â  Given the record before 
  us, we find it necessary to remand this issue to the family court for redetermination 
  of the value of Husbandâ€™s gross receipts during the pertinent years.Â  If needed, 
  the family court may take additional testimony on the matter.Â  See Widman 
  v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 116, 557 S.E.2d 693, 703 (Ct. App. 2001) (wherein 
  this court remanded to the family court for a determination of the value of 
  a share of stock where evidence in the record was insufficient to enable appellate 
  court to make a determination, and allowed taking of additional testimony by 
  the family court to resolve the issue).
As to the deductible business expenses, the record supports the family courtâ€™s 
  finding that Husband pays many of his personal living expenses out of his business 
  account and that he is not entitled to some of the expenses he claims.Â  The 
  record shows Wife successfully challenged many of these expenses.Â  Further, 
  we agree with the family court that Husband failed to produce credible evidence 
  on the commingled expenses, and we find he specifically failed to demonstrate 
  the evidence of record to support the expenses he now contends were wrongly 
  excluded.Â  Accordingly, we find the court properly excluded certain expenses 
  pursuant to S.C. Reg. 114-4720(A)(4).
VIII.Â  Engagement Ring
Husband next contends the family court erred in ordering him to transfer the 
  engagement ring in his possession to Wife because it was non-marital property.Â  
  We disagree.
At trial, Husband testified he gave the ring to Wife as an engagement ring.Â  
  He claimed he came into possession of the ring when Wife â€œtook the ring off 
  and said â€˜you can have the ring.â€™â€Â  Wife adamantly denied giving the ring to 
  Husband.Â  She stated that, after their separation, she and Husband were arguing 
  over money and how much he had paid for the ring.Â  She took the ring off her 
  finger and asked Husband if that was all he cared about, at which point he took 
  the ring, smiled, and walked out the door.Â  
The family court found the ring was given to Wife prior to the marriage, it 
  was non-marital property, and Wife was to have permanent possession and ownership 
  of the ring.Â  Husband asserts this was error, contending the family court did 
  not have jurisdiction to apportion the non-marital property.Â  â€œAn antenuptial 
  gift of an engagement ring is the recipientâ€™s separate property.â€Â  Frank 
  v. Frank, 311 S.C. 454, 457, 429 S.E.2d 823, 825 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Husband 
  is correct in his assertion that the family court does not have jurisdiction 
  to apportion non-marital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  However, family courts have exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine actions 
  for â€œdivorce . . . and for settlement of all legal and equitable rights of the 
  parties in the actions in and to the real and personal property of the marriage 
  . . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(2) (Supp. 2003).Â  Thus, the family court 
  clearly has jurisdiction to determine what is and is not marital.Â  Here, the 
  court did not â€œapportionâ€ the non-marital property, but merely determined it 
  was in fact non-marital and belonged to Wife. 
  [1] Â  Accordingly, we hold the family court properly determined Wife was 
  entitled to possession and ownership of the ring.Â  
IX.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband contends the family court erred in awarding Wife $28,000 in attorneyâ€™s 
  fees because (1) the court improperly found much of Wifeâ€™s fees were caused 
  by Husbandâ€™s frivolous claim for custody, (2) the fees included $3,600 from 
  services of an unnecessary second attorney and, (3) the court improperly awarded 
  fees in part based on Husbandâ€™s purported obstructive behavior in refusing to 
  allow Wife to retrieve some of her personal effects.Â  We disagree.
The family court found Wife had incurred attorneyâ€™s fees and cost of $41,513 
  and Husband should contribute $28,000 toward the fees and costs.Â  The record 
  before us is replete with evidence supporting the family courtâ€™s determination 
  that Husbandâ€™s claim to custody was frivolous in that he maintained the claim 
  for other purposes than obtaining custody of his children.Â  The preponderance 
  of evidence also supports the courtâ€™s finding that Husband was obstructive in 
  that he refused to allow Wife to retrieve items that were clearly non-marital.Â  

As to Husbandâ€™s assertion regarding a second attorney, the record shows Wifeâ€™s 
  attorneyâ€™s fees affidavit was admitted into evidence without objection.Â  The 
  record fails to demonstrate Husband ever challenged the use of two attorneys 
  or raised any objection to the fees during the hearing on his motion to reconsider.Â  
  Further, Husband failed to raise any issue concerning attorneyâ€™s fees in his 
  motion for reconsideration.Â  As a general rule, an issue may not be raised for 
  the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the 
  court below to be preserved for appellate review.Â  See Noisette v. 
  Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (holding an issue not 
  preserved where the trial court did not explicitly rule on an argument and the 
  appellant failed to make a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to alter or amend the judgment 
  on that ground).Â  Because the family court did not have an opportunity to rule 
  on this issue, it is not preserved for our review.Â  
We find no error in the award of attorneyâ€™s fees based on Husbandâ€™s arguments 
  and therefore affirm the award of these fees to Wife. [2] Â  
X.Â  Dismissal of Husbandâ€™s Rule to Show CauseÂ Â  
Husband finally asserts the family court erred in denying his rule to show 
  cause.Â  He contends the evidence introduced at the hearing on the matter showed 
  Wife willfully failed to comply with the courtâ€™s order on visitation.Â  We disagree.
Following issuance of the final order, Husband sought to have Wife held in 
  contempt based on her failure to comply with the courtâ€™s order on visitation.Â  
  The family court dismissed the rule to show cause, finding, due to confusion 
  over the court ordered visitation, Wife initially failed to allow some of Husbandâ€™s 
  weekday visitations on Tuesday and Thursday during the summer months.Â  However, 
  Wife thereafter offered substitute visitation to make up for the missed days, 
  and specifically offered Tuesday and Thursday visitation, but Husband refused, 
  indicating he would rather take the matter to the court to have Wife held in 
  contempt.Â  
â€œContempt results from the willful disobedience of a court order, and before 
  a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically 
  reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 
  557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily 
  and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, 
  or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; 
  that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€Â  
  Id. (citation omitted).Â  A determination of contempt is within the sound 
  discretion of the trial judge whose decision will not be disturbed unless the 
  judgeâ€™s finding is without evidentiary support or there is an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Id. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
The record shows there was much confusion over the visitation issue.Â  There 
  was only a partial agreement in the first part of the bifurcated trial.Â  Wife 
  testified she did not realize she was in violation of the order, and she thought 
  the order provided no extended visitation over the summer months.Â  She further 
  stated she tried to comply, offering Husband additional time with the children, 
  but Husband refused stating he wished to settle the matter in court.Â  Even Husband 
  admitted the final order did not encompass what he thought it was supposed to 
  reflect on visitation.Â Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion.
Based on the foregoing, the order below is
ARRIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.Â Â  
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


 [1] Apportion means â€œ[t]o divide and distribute proportionally.â€ 
  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 99 (6th ed.1990).Â Â Â  
 [2] Husband does not challenge the attorneyâ€™s fee award on any other 
  basis.Â  Specifically, he does not argue against the award based on the appropriate 
  factors.Â  See Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 
  313, 315 (1991) (wherein court held, in determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to award, the court should consider the nature, extent, and difficulty 
  of the case, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional 
  standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, 
  and the customary legal fees for similar services).Â  Nor did he request this 
  court reverse and remand the issue based on our reversal of any other issues.Â  
  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 427 S.E.2d 665 (1993) (reversing 
  and remanding issue of attorneyâ€™s fees for reconsideration where husband argued 
  the substantive results achieved by trial counsel were reversed on appeal).Â  
  Accordingly, the award is affirmed based solely on the arguments submitted by 
  Husband.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

title: Walker Investment Management Trust v. Carolina First Bank
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Walker Investment Management Trust, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        GrandSouth Bank, B&B Development, LLC, Blasco Builders, Inc., and 
          Carolina First Bank, Defendants,
        of whom Carolina First Bank is, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
  Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-606
  Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Louis H. Lang, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Michael F. Mullinax, of Anderson, and Roxy Rae Beagley, of Clemson, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Carolina First Bank appeals the trial judgeâ€™s decision that 
  the Walker Investment Management Trustâ€™s interest in the subject property was 
  superior to the interest of Carolina First Bank.Â  We affirm.  
  [1] Â  
FACTS
David and Donna Walker owned 30.79 acres located at the intersection of Lebanon 
  Road and Liberty Highway in Anderson County, South Carolina.Â  In September 1999, 
  the Walkers created the Walker Investment Management Trust (Trust), naming their 
  daughters as the trustees.Â  In October of that same year, the Trust entered 
  into a contract of sale with B&B Development (B&B), headed by Joe Blasco 
  and Dan Balcer, who intended to build an apartment complex on the property.Â  
  The contract provided that the Trust would convey the property to B&B in 
  exchange for five 3-bedroom units and four 2-bedroom units, which would be deeded 
  to the Trust upon fifty percent completion of construction.Â  The contract also 
  stipulated that B&B would obtain a surety bond in the amount of $765,000 
  (the value of the transaction) as consideration for the contract sometime â€œon 
  or before . . . the infrastructure [was] started.â€Â  B&B never obtained the 
  surety bond or started building infrastructure.Â  Furthermore, though the deed 
  stated that the Trust conveyed the property for $107,765, the Trust never received 
  these funds.Â  
The documents were properly recorded in the Anderson County RMC Office on October 
  15, 1999 in the following order: the Trust, the contract, the deed to the trust, 
  and the deed to B&B.Â  
In January 2000, B&B obtained a mortgage on the property for $205,000 through 
  Carolina First to buy out Balcerâ€™s interest in the company.Â  The closing attorney 
  in this real estate transaction, Michael Spivy, was the same attorney who had 
  handled the closing between the Trust and B&B only months before.Â  B&B 
  also obtained two wrap-around mortgages on the property, as well as other property 
  owned by B&B, from GrandSouth Bank in the amounts of $791,087.84 and $101,251.33.Â  

GrandSouth began foreclosure proceedings against the property in controversy, 
  citing B&B, Blasco Builders, and Carolina First as defendants.Â  Shortly 
  thereafter, the Trust intervened by consent order, requesting a declaratory 
  judgment as to its rights to the subject property.Â  Following consolidation 
  of the suits, B&B and Blasco Builders defaulted, and GrandSouth moved for 
  a voluntary dismissal, which was granted by the trial judge.Â  The trial judge 
  declared the deed from the Trust to B&B as null and void and set it aside 
  in its entirety.Â  The court also restored fee simple title to the property in 
  the Trust and declared the Carolina First mortgage as null and void, extinguishing 
  the lien relating thereto in full.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor 
  equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying action.Â  An issue, 
  essentially one at law, will not be transformed into one in equity simply because 
  declaratory relief is sought.Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 
  356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  Here, the action was one to construe the real 
  estate contract and, therefore, at law.Â  In law actions, the trial court must 
  be affirmed when there is any evidence to support its findings.Â  Townes Assoc., 
  Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976). 

However, the relief sought by the Trust for the breach of contract cause of 
  action is equitable, as are the other three causes of action.Â  See Brown 
  v. Greenwood School Dist. 50 Bd. of Trustees, 344 S.C. 522, 525, 544 S.E.2d 
  642, 643 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding that an action to rescind a contract is in 
  equity); Bullard v. Crawley, 294 S.C. 276, 278, 363 S.E.2d 897, 898 (1987) 
  (â€œAn action to set aside deeds is a matter in equity.â€); Bank of Williston 
  v. Alderman, et al., 106 S.C. 386, 391, 91 S.E. 296, 297 (1917) (stating 
  that constructive trusts are created when one party obtains money that does 
  not equitably belong to him).Â  On appeal of an equitable action, the appellate 
  court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of 
  the evidence.Â  Townes Assoc., Ltd., 266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775.Â  
  This broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to disregard 
  the findings of the trial judge nor does it relieve appellant of the burden 
  of convincing the court that the trial judge erred.Â  The trial judge, who saw 
  and heard the witnesses, is better able to evaluate their credibility.Â  Calcutt 
  v. Calcutt, 282 S.C. 565, 569, 320 S.E.2d 55, 57 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, 
  the appellate court is not bound by the trial judgeâ€™s legal determinations.Â  
  Swindler v. Swindler, 355 S.C. 245, 249, 584 S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 
  2003).Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Notice
Carolina First claims that it did not have notice of the Trustâ€™s claim to the 
  property because the wording of the contract only provided the Trust a personal 
  remedy against B&B or on the surety bond in case of a default.Â  We disagree.
The contract provides
 
  The Seller agrees to convey to the Purchaser 30.79 acres . . . .Â  In consideration 
    of the conveyance of said 30.79 acres, the Purchaser agrees to secure a $765,000 
    Surety Bond to secure Sellerâ€™s interest in the property which will be conveyed 
    to B&B Development, LLC.Â  Upon 50% completion of said project, B&B 
    Development, LLC, agrees to deed to Seller for $1.00 and other consideration, 
    5 (five) 3 bedroom units and 4 (four) 2 bedroom units.Â  Once said units are 
    deeded then the surety bond is terminated . . . .Â  The Surety Bond is to be 
    in place on or before the time that the infrastructure is started. 
  . . . .
  If Purchaser fails to complete its obligation under this said contract then 
    the Surety Bond would cover any loss to Seller.Â  The Purchaser would keep 
    ownership of said land . . .Â  

The contract required B&B to purchase a surety bond to protect 
  the interests of the Trust.Â  The contract was then properly recorded, putting 
  all subsequent creditors on notice of the Trustâ€™s equitable interest.Â  â€œOrdinarily, 
  one who takes a security interest in real property with notice of an existing 
  third party equity in the property takes subject to the third partyâ€™s interest. 
  . . . It is sufficient that one either knows or ought to know some third 
  party interest exists.â€Â  South Carolina Fed. Savings Bank v. San-A-Bel Corp., 
  307 S.C. 76, 79, 413 S.E.2d 852, 854 (Ct. App. 1992) (emphasis added).Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-7-10 (Supp. 2003).Â  The inclusion of the surety bond requirement 
  in the contract alone should have put anyone on notice. Carolina First used 
  the same attorney to close their mortgage as B&B and the Trust used to close 
  their real estate agreement.Â  Notice to an attorney is notice to the client.Â  
  See Faulkner v. Millar, 319 S.C. 216, 221, 460 S.E.2d 378, 381 
  (1995) (discussing principles of agency).Â  Spivey drafted the contract of sale 
  between the Trust and B&B and conducted the closing.Â  He was as familiar 
  with the provisions of that contract as the parties were.Â  Balcerâ€™s testimony 
  unequivocally states that his understanding of the contract is that â€œthe property 
  would be returned back to Mr. Walker . . . if [B&B] did not complete these 
  unitsâ€ and purchase the surety bond to protect him.Â  Shortly thereafter, Spivey 
  represented to Carolina First that the property was unencumbered.Â  
Carolina First had notice or should have had notice of the Trustâ€™s 
  interest in the property.Â  Therefore, its mortgage is subordinate to the rights 
  and title in the Trust.
II. Rescission and Setting Aside the Deed
Carolina First claims the trial judge erred in rescinding and setting aside 
  the contract because this relief prejudiced the rights of an innocent third 
  party, Carolina First.Â  We disagree.
A valid contract consists of contractual intent, followed by an actual meeting 
  of the minds of the parties, accompanied by valid consideration.Â  Cobb v. 
  Gross, 291 S.C. 550, 553, 354 S.E.2d 573, 575 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Furthermore, 
  consideration must be legally sufficient.Â Â Â  The general rule is that for a 
  breach of contract to warrant rescission, the breach must be so fundamental 
  and substantial as to defeat the purpose of the contract.Â  Gibbs v. G.K.H., 
  Inc., 311 S.C. 103, 105, 427 S.E.2d 701, 702 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  In addition, 
  to cancel a deed the moving party must show total failure of consideration or 
  grossly inadequate consideration.Â  Patterson v. Goldsmith, 292 S.C. 619, 
  628, 358 S.E.2d 163, 168 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  In this case, there was a substantial 
  breach of the contract because no consideration was ever paid.Â  B&B never 
  obtained the surety bond, nor built or conveyed the development units as required 
  by the contract.Â  
Most importantly, the acts of an attorney are directly attributable to and 
  binding on the client.Â  Greenville Income Partners v. Holman, 308 S.C. 
  105, 107, 417 S.E.2d 107, 108 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  No mistake attributable to an 
  attorney can be successfully used as a ground for relief, unless it would have 
  been excusable if attributable to the client.Â  Simon v. Flowers, 231 
  S.C. 545, 551, 99 S.E.2d 391, 394 (1957).Â  As discussed above, Spivey represented 
  Carolina First, just as he had represented B&B in the deed from the Trust.Â  
  He examined B&Bâ€™s title and he closed the loan.Â  Spivey knew of B&Bâ€™s 
  agreement with the Trust, that counsel did not represent Walker at the initial 
  closing, and that Walker was concerned about protecting his interest.Â  In addition, 
  he knew B&B was responsible for purchasing the surety bond and that it failed 
  to do so.Â  Yet, he recommended Blasco proceed with the loan and represented 
  to Carolina First that its mortgage would have priority.Â  Unfortunately, Carolina 
  First is bound by his mistake.Â  Greenville Income Partners, 308 S.C. 
  at 107-08, 417 S.E.2d at 108.Â  Therefore, the trial judge had sufficient evidence 
  before him to rescind the contract and set aside the deed. 
III. Constructive Trust
Carolina First claims the trial judge erred in finding a constructive trust 
  had been created because there was no evidence of fraud, bad faith, abuse of 
  confidence, or a violation of a fiduciary duty, which would give rise to an 
  obligation in equity to make restitution.Â  We disagree.
A constructive trust arises whenever one party has obtained money, which does 
  not equitably belong to him, and which he cannot in good conscience retain or 
  withhold from another, who is beneficially entitled to it.Â  Lollis v. Lollis, 
  291 S.C. 525, 529, 354 S.E.2d 559, 561 (1987) (citing Bank of Williston v. 
  Alderman, 106 S.C. 386, 391, 91 S.E.2d 296, 297 (1917)).Â  Constructive trusts 
  do not arise by agreement or from intention, but by operation of law with actual 
  or constructive fraud as their essential element.Â  Id.Â  â€œActual fraud 
  is not necessary, but such trust will arise whenever the circumstances under 
  which property was acquired make it inequitable that it should be retained by 
  him who holds legal title.â€Â  Bank of Williston, 106 S.C. at 391, 91 S.E.2d 
  at 298.Â  The trial judge in Doe v. Roe, 323 S.C. 445, 452, 475 S.E.2d 
  783, 786-87 (Ct. App. 1996), found that duress, abuse of confidence, commission 
  of a wrong, and â€œany form of unconscionable conduct, artifice, concealment, 
  or questionable meansâ€ can create a constructive trust as well (emphasis added).Â  

Furthermore, â€œthe trust arises and follows the property of its proceeds.â€Â  
  Bank of Williston, 106 S.C. at 391, 91 S.E.2d at 298.Â  B&B acted 
  unconscionably by not purchasing the surety bond, failing to convey the buildings 
  or pay their worth as consideration for the contract.Â  This conduct created 
  a trust, which follows the property in the lien to Carolina First.Â  Lastly, 
  the trial judge had sufficient evidence of unconscionable conduct on the part 
  of the attorney who represented both B&B and Carolina First.Â  In fact, before 
  the lien agreement with Carolina First, Blasco reminded Spivey that there was 
  no bond to protect Walker.Â  Blasco felt that Walker would be taken advantage 
  of by the contractâ€™s wording as interpreted by Carolina First because Blasco 
  â€œdidnâ€™t have . . . [in] mind at allâ€ that the Trustâ€™s interests would not be 
  protected if B&B never purchased the surety bond.Â  Spivey even admitted 
  that â€œthe purpose of the surety bond was to be in place at the time anyone else, 
  other than B&B and Walker Development Trust, had an interest in that property.â€Â  

IV. Equitable Lien
Carolina First claims 
  that the trial judge erred when he concluded that an equitable lien was created 
  because the parties did not intend the property to serve as security for the 
  payment of the debt.Â  
Because we decided a constructive trust was created by the unconscionable conduct 
  of B&B and Carolina First through its attorney, we need not address this 
  issue.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and SHORT JJ., and CURETON A.J., concur.

 [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Linart Randolph, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-607
  Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 6, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Harry T. Heizer, Jr. and Joshua Kendrick, bothÂ  of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and 
          Solicitor William Townes Jones, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant, Linart 
  Randolph was convicted of murder and sentenced to life without parole.Â  On appeal, 
  Randolph asserts reversible error in the admission of (1) evidence of his drug 
  use on the night of the murder and, (2) the written statement of his co-defendant.Â  
  We affirm1 pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), 
  SCACR and the following authorities:Â  ISSUE I:Â  State v. Myers, 
  344 S.C. 532, 535, 544 S.E.2d 851, 852-53 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding where defendant 
  objected at trial on the ground that testimony was irrelevant, he could not 
  argue on appeal that testimony improperly placed his character at issue); State 
  v. Dickman, 341 S.C. 293, 295, 534 S.E.2d 268, 269 (2000) (holding a party 
  cannot argue one ground below and then argue another ground on appeal); State 
  v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003) (stating to 
  be preserved for appellate review, an issue must be raised to and ruled on by 
  the trial judge; though a party need not use the exact name of a legal doctrine 
  in order to preserve an issue, it must be clear that the argument has been presented 
  on that ground); State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 196, 577 S.E.2d 445, 
  448 (2003) (finding the erroneous admission of character evidence is harmless 
  beyond a reasonable doubt if its impact is minimal in the context of the entire 
  record); State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 550, 552 S.E.2d 300, 313 
  (2001) (holding where there is other properly admitted evidence of conduct demonstrating 
  the particular character trait in question, there is no reversible error); State 
  v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (finding any 
  error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is 
  harmless); ISSUE II: State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 453, 529 S.E.2d 
  721, 728-29 (2000) (holding the trial judge has considerable discretion in ruling 
  on the admissibility of testimonial and non-testimonial evidence and his determination 
  of admissibility will not be disturbed absent abuse of discretion resulting 
  in prejudice to the complaining party); State v. Schumpert, 312 
  S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (finding any error in admission of 
  evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless); State v. 
  Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 172, 508 S.E.2d 870, 876 (1998) (holding in order 
  to reverse a case based on the erroneous admission or exclusion of evidence, 
  prejudice must be shown).
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, 
  JJ., concur.


1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-609

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Randall L. Chambers, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        J. R. Murphy, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher Davis appeals the 
  trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company 
  on the issue of whether Davis may recover uninsured motorist (UIM) benefits 
  under an insurance policy.Â  We reverse.

LAW/ANALYSIS
We reverse pursuant to the following authority: 
  Burgess v. Nationwide Mutual Insurance, Op. No. 3863 (S.C. Ct. App. filed

REVERSED.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Gloria R. Owenby and John W. Owenby, Appellants,
v.
Kyle F. Kiesau, M.D.; Auburn Woods, III, M.D.; Julian Williams, M.D.; 
        Claude D. Woollen, M.D.; Robert A. Cochran, Jr., M.D.; David C. Hull, 
        M.D.; Cole Blease Graham, III, M.D.; Neil H. Parnes, M.D.; Brian
Baghdady, 
        M.D.; Lawrence Warren, Jr., M.D.; Mark Monson, M.D.; Drs. Kiesau, Barrow 
        & Davis, P.A.; Hull, Green, Woods, Cochran & Woollen, LLC; Spartanburg 
        Radiological Associates, P.A.; and the Spartanburg Regional Medical Center, 
        Defendants,/Of whom Spartanburg Regional Medical Center is, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-610
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  7, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Kirkman Moorhead, of Anderson, for Appellant.
William B. Darwin, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this medical negligence 
  claim, appellants Gloria Owenby and her husband John Owenby, appeal the trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment and argue that the two-year statute of limitations 
  for the claim had not run.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
After experiencing 
  serious discomfort in her abdominal region for several weeks, Gloria Owenby 
  visited a doctor and less than a week later she had surgery to remove a 24-pound 
  ovarian tumor, her ovaries, and her gall bladder. Dr. Kyle Kiesau and Dr. Auburn 
  Woods performed the surgery on July 21, 1999 at Spartanburg Regional Medical 
  Center. 
The chronology of events 
  in this case is critical.Â  After her discharge from the hospital on July 27, 
  Mrs. Owenby continually experienced a series of health problems for which various 
  physicians treated her.Â  On August 10, Dr. Julian Williams examined Mrs. Owenbyâ€™s 
  abdominal swelling and referred her again to Dr. Kiesau, an obstetrician/gynecologist.Â  
  Drs. Williams and Kiesau examined Mrs. Owenby August 24 and Dr. Kiesau informed 
  Mrs. Owenby that he believed a hematoma resulting from the surgery was causing 
  the continued swelling and subsequently approved her to take a planned vacation 
  with her husband. Mrs. Owenby described herself as â€œdeathly sickâ€ throughout 
  the vacation and visited Dr. Kiesau upon her return on September 17 and September 
  24, where he became concerned with her increased swelling.Â  Dr. Kiesau referred 
  Mrs. Owenby to Dr. Woods, a general surgeon, and Dr. Woods performed an ultrasound 
  on September 27.Â  Dr. Woods determined Mrs. Owenbyâ€™s abdomen was full of fluid, 
  opining that she was suffering from a seroma as a result of the surgery. 
  [2] Â  
Mrs. Owenby visited Dr. Woodsâ€™ 
  office with continued abdominal drainage on October 4 and October 6.Â  Dr. Lawrence 
  Warren, when performing an ultrasound procedure on October 18, asked the Owenbys 
  if the fluid had been tested to see if it was urine, indicating that sometimes 
  during surgery, the ureter is damaged by getting small slits or holes in it, 
  which creates leakage. [3] Â  Later that same day, Dr. Woods told Mrs. Owenby 
  that he had spoken with Dr. Warren and that a test would be scheduled to determine 
  if the fluid was urine as Dr. Warren suspected.Â  After abdominal and pelvic 
  CT scans were performed on October 19, Dr. Woodsâ€™ office called Mrs. Owenby 
  on October 21 and instructed her the tests indicated she should see a urologist 
  immediately. 
On October 26, 1999, Mrs. Owenby 
  saw an urologist, Dr. Clifton Williams, who told her she had an injured left 
  ureter that was leaking and causing urine to drain into her abdomen and that 
  it needed to be repaired. On November 2, Dr. Williams attempted to repair Mrs. 
  Owenbyâ€™s ureter but was unsuccessful, because, as he discovered during surgery, 
  Mrs. Owenbyâ€™s ureter was completely severed, about which he informed Mrs. Owenby 
  after the procedure. [4] Â  
Mrs. Owenby was asked under oath 
  if October 26, 1999 was the first time she recalled being told she â€œhad a ureter 
  that apparently had some sort of leak and was causing this excess drainage?â€ 
  She responded: â€œOther than what I believe the radiologist, Dr. Warren, told 
  me that day, that was the only time I heard that mentioned that I recall.â€Â  

The Owenbys filed this action 
  for medical negligence on October 31, 2001 based on a ureter injury and served 
  Dr. Kiesau on November 1, 2001.Â  Spartanburg Regional, a governmental entity, 
  was substituted as a defendant for Dr. Kiesau and moved for summary judgment. 
  [5]  Â At the summary judgment hearing, the trial court ruled that the statute 
  of limitations had run. This appeal follows.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
  In arguing that the trial 
    court erred in granting summary judgment based on the running of the statute 
    of limitations, Mrs. Owenby submits that she did not discover her injury until 
    November 2, 1999 and she filed her claim in a timely fashion.Â  We disagree.
  In an action against a governmental 
    entity, the two-year statute of limitations of the South Carolina Tort Claims 
    Act applies.Â  S.C. Code Ann.Â  Â§Â§15-78-100(a)â€”110 (Supp. 2003).Â  In examining 
    when the statute of limitations began to run, the discovery rule applies.Â  
    Young v. South Carolina Dept. of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 718, 511 
    S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding that the discovery rule applies to 
    actions brought under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act).Â  

  According to the discovery 
    rule, the statute of limitations begins to run when a cause of action reasonably 
    ought to have been discovered.Â  The statute runs from the date the injured 
    party knows or should have known by the exercise of reasonable diligence that 
    a cause of action arises from the wrongful conduct.
  . . . .
  [T]he injured party must act with some promptness where the 
    facts and circumstances of an injury place a reasonable person of common knowledge 
    and experience on notice that a claim against another party might exist. 
    Â Moreover, the fact that the injured party may not comprehend the full extent 
    of the damage is immaterial.

  Id. at 719, 511 S.E.2d at 416 (quoting Dean v. Ruscon Corp., 
    321 S.C. 360, 364, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996) (citations omitted) (emphasis 
    in original)).Â  See also, Joubert v. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 341 
    S.C. 176, 190, 534 S.E.2d 1, 8 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding that the statute of 
    limitations under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act begins to run â€œwhen the 
    plaintiff should know that he might have a potential claim against another, 
    not when he develops a full-blown theory of recoveryâ€).Â  The date when the 
    discovery should have been made is an objective question.Â  Young, 333 
    S.C. at 719, 511 S.E.2d at 416.

  â€œ[W]hether the particular 
    plaintiff actually knew he had a claim is not the test.Â  Rather, courts must 
    decide whether the circumstances of the case would put a person of common 
    knowledge and experience on notice that some right of his had been invaded 
    or that some claim against another party might exist.â€

  Id.
  The crux of Mrs. Owenbyâ€™s argument 
    is that her injury was not discoverable to a person of common knowledge.Â  
    She cites Pederson v. Gould, 288 S.C. 141, 341 S.E.2d 633, 634 (1986) 
    for her argument that expert testimony is often needed in medical malpractice 
    actions, because the subject matter is outside the scope of common knowledge.Â  
    The Pederson court does find that damage to the ureter that occurs 
    during a hysterectomy does not fall under common knowledge exception.Â  Id. 
    at 143, 341 S.E.2d at 634.Â  However, the common knowledge exception rule applies 
    to the use of expert testimony in medical malpractice cases to determine the 
    appropriate standard of care.Â  Id. at 142-43, 341 S.E.2d at 634-35 
    (finding that the trial court did not err in failing to charge the jury as 
    to the common knowledge exception).Â  The support is misplaced.Â  The present 
    case is about the discovery of an injury.
  As to the discovery of her injury, 
    Mrs. Owenby attempts to distinguish her situation from that in Bayle v. 
    South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 
    2001). [6] Â  Further she argues 
    that the injury to the party in Bayle was easier to link to the car 
    accident that caused it.Â  The Bayle court held that the plaintiffâ€™s 
    loss, which triggered the statute of limitations, was the death of his wife, 
    not the date he learned of a possible latent defect in the road.Â  Id. 
    at 122, 739 S.E.2d at 739.Â  The trial court simply cited the discovery rule 
    in Bayle, which cites Dean, Young, and Joubert 
    all mentioned above.Â  She further argues that this â€œâ€˜simplifiedâ€™ understanding 
    of the discovery ruleâ€ is countered by Strong v. Univ. of South Carolina 
    School of Medicine, 316 S.C. 189, 447 S.E.2d 850 (1994).Â  She interprets 
    Strong as holding injury only is not enough to start the statute of 
    limitations, that circumstances sufficient to put the injured party on notice 
    are needed. [7] Â  Mrs. 
    Owenby argues the trial court relied on her knowledge of the injury only, 
    rather than her knowledge that a claim might exist, citing the facts of Strong 
    where the plaintiff knew of his blindness in May 1989 but did not know the 
    cause until June 1989, when a doctor noted it in the plaintiffâ€™s medical file.Â  
    Id. at 191, 447 S.E.2d at 852.Â  In the instant case, the trial court 
    did not determine that the statute of limitations started with Mrs. Owenbyâ€™s 
    first knowledge of any injury.Â  Rather, the court determined that she was 
    told on October 18, 1999 of the possibility of an injury to her ureter and 
    that such an injury could have been caused during surgery.Â  Thereafter, 
    she was told that she did indeed have such an injury.Â  At the latest, Mrs. 
    Owenby discovered her injury on October 26, 1999.
  Mrs. Owenby says that the circumstances did not 
    put her on notice until November 2, 1999. 
    [8] Â  To find that she needed to know that her ureter was completely severed, 
    as she was told on November 2, does not have foundation in the law, which 
    is that understanding the full extent of the injury is immaterial.Â  See 
    Young, Â 333 S.C. at 719, 511 S.E.2d at 416. Â By October 
    26, 1999, she knew that she had an injury to her ureter and that it was an 
    injury that could have been caused during surgery.Â  This was sufficient information 
    to put a person of common knowledge on notice that a claim existed.Â  
  Viewed in a light 
    most favorable to Mrs. Owenby, the facts of this case make clear that she 
    discovered her injury no later than October 26, 1999.Â  Because Mrs. Owenby 
    did not file her claim within the applicable statute of limitations, the trial 
    court was correct to have granted Spartanburg Regionalâ€™s motion for summary 
    judgment.Â  Therefore, the decision of the trial court is
  AFFIRMED.
  ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  From September 30 to October 1, Mrs. Owenby was admitted to Spartanburg 
    Regional to drain some 5,500 milliliters of fluid after the initial procedure. 
    Additional fluid was drained while she was hospitalized and after her 
    discharge from the hospital.

 
   
    [3]  The Owenbys both indicated the fluid looked to be urine and drained 
    from at a rate of 1,200 to 1,500 milliliters per day October 6 through October 
    13.

 
   
    [4]  Dr. Williams reattached Mrs. Owenbyâ€™s ureter in a procedure on March 
    20, 2000.

 
   
    [5]  By the date of the hearing, all other defendants had been dismissed.

 
   
    [6]  She also attempts to distinguish Wiggins v. Edwards, 314 S.C. 
    126, 442 S.E.2d 169 (1994) for the same reason.Â  

 
   
    [7]  Strong reiterates the discovery rule: that the statute of 
    limitations begins to run when a person of common knowledge is put on notice 
    that some right has been invaded or a claim may exist, not when legal advice 
    has been obtained or a full blown theory of recovery has been established.Â  
    316 S.C. at 191, 447 S.E.2d at 852 (citation omitted).Â  

 
   
    [8]  The length of time it took doctors with expert knowledge to determine 
    her injury, as Mrs. Owenby argues, does not bolster the notion that a person 
    of common knowledge would have known a claim existed once that person was 
    told of the injury.
