title: Mid-South Management  v. Sherwood Development
text:
THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN 
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Mid-South Management Company Incorporated and William C. Buchheit Trust 
        A, as partners of Spartanburg Beach Cove Associates, a general partnership 
        and a joint venturer of Beach Cove Associates Joint Venture, and Beach 
        Cove Associates Joint Venture, Respondents,
v.
Sherwood Development Corporation, a joint venturer of Beach Cove Associates 
        Joint Venture; Coastal Financial Corporation, Coastal Federal Savings 
        Bank; Coastal Mortgage Bankers and Realty Co., Inc.; John Doe, which represent 
        unidentified shareholders of Sherwood Development Corporation; Michael 
        C. Gerald and James T. Clemmons, Defendants,
of whom, Sherwood Development Corporation, a joint venturer of Beach 
        Cove Associates Joint Venture; Coastal Financial Corporation, Coastal 
        Federal Savings Bank; Coastal Mortgage Bankers and Realty Co., Inc., Michael 
        C. Gerald and James T. Clemmons, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-611
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert E. Stepp and Amy L.B. Hill, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
Michael B.T. Wilkes, of Spartanburg, and Michael W. Battle, 
  of Conway, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Spartanburg Beach Cove Associates (Spartanburg) and Sherwood 
  Development Corporation (Sherwood) dispute their monetary contributions to a 
  settlement of lawsuits brought against their joint venture, Beach Cove Associates 
  (the â€œjoint ventureâ€).Â  Sherwood and its affiliates (Appellants), appeal an 
  order finding Spartanburg and its affiliates (Respondents), are entitled to 
  a judgment in the amount of $278,333.33, plus interest.Â  We affirm.  [1] 
FACTS
Beach Cove Development Corporation (BCD), Spartanburg, and 
  Sherwood created the joint venture in 1983 to develop land and sell condominiums 
  in Horry County.Â  Originally, Spartanburg had a 50% interest in the joint venture, 
  and Sherwood and BCD each had a 25% interest.Â  BCD defaulted as a joint venturer 
  sometime in the mid 1980â€™s, before the litigation began, leaving Spartanburg 
  with a two-thirds interest, and Sherwood with a one-third interest.
Spartanburg, Sherwood, and BCD entered into a joint venture 
  agreement (â€œAgreementâ€) on August 23, 1983.Â  The Agreement described the project 
  to be undertaken and defined the role of the venturers.Â  BCD was granted limited 
  powers of management.Â  However, after BCD defaulted, Spartanburg became the 
  majority venturer, and thus gained control as the managing venturer. 
The management authority was subject to certain 
  limitations.Â  The Agreement provided that none of the venturers would have authority 
  to act for or assume any obligations or responsibility on behalf of any other 
  venturer or the joint venture.Â  Additionally, the Agreement restricted management 
  of the joint venture from making certain expenditures without prior authorization 
  and provided that venturers could not take actions binding the joint venture 
  without the consent of the other venturers.Â  
The Agreement specified initial contributions, and provisions 
  were made for additional capital contributions.Â  Sherwood agreed to use its 
  best efforts to obtain loans to provide financing as necessary, and BCD was 
  given authorization to require additional contributions from the venturers by 
  giving written notice.Â  The Agreement further provided that no venturer would 
  be required to make any capital contribution or loan to the joint venture other 
  than as provided in this Agreement or as mutually agreed upon by the parties.Â  
  The Agreement also provided for allocation of profits and losses:Â  â€œThe respective 
  share of each Venturer in all joint venture income and expenses and each item 
  thereof, including depreciation and any investment tax credits, shall be allocated 
  to the Venturers in accordance with their Percentage Interest.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Finally, the Agreement contained indemnification 
  provisions.Â  The venturers agreed to hold each other harmless from losses resulting 
  from, among other things, lawsuits against the joint venture arising out of 
  breach of the Agreement.Â  Additionally, upon dissolution the parties agreed 
  to fund any negative balances. 
Pursuant to the Agreement, the condominiums were built, but 
  the project was largely unsuccessful.Â  The project encountered serious difficulties 
  because of federal tax changes, increased construction costs, and problems with 
  management.Â  Numerous capital calls were made and Sherwood paid all of them.Â  
  Additionally, in August 1993, Beach Cove Ocean Resort Homeowners Association, 
  Inc., sued the joint venture, alleging construction defects in the condominiums 
  and the parking garage.Â  The lawsuit also named numerous other defendants, including 
  the builders and suppliers of Beach Cove Ocean Resort.Â  Individual homeowners 
  in the condominium project also brought a class action lawsuit against the joint 
  venture.Â  
The joint venture retained the Bellamy Law Firm (Bellamy), 
  which advised the joint venture that a trial on the merits could result in a 
  significant judgment against it.Â  When mediation failed, Bellamy began working 
  on a settlement.Â  A conflict of interest existed in that Sherwood was set up 
  as a corporation with no assets, and was thus effectively judgment-proof, whereas 
  Spartanburg, a general partnership capable of responding to an adverse judgment, 
  was not.Â  Bellamy was aware of the possible conflict and discussed it with the 
  venturers.Â  Howell Bellamy, Jr., testified the venturers agreed that Bellamy 
  would continue to represent the joint venture and the venturers would deal with 
  their differences later.Â  Sherwood initially refused to contribute anything 
  toward a potential settlement, but did pay some of the legal fees.
In January 1997, Mike Gerald, president of Sherwood, and 
  Ray Harris, Spartanburgâ€™s corporate attorney, discussed the possibility that 
  the lawsuits could be settled if the joint venture authorized Bellamy to offer 
  up to $1 million in settlement.Â  As a result, Harris called Bellamy and confirmed 
  the joint venture would contribute up to $1 million to settle the lawsuits.Â  
  The minutes from the Sherwood Board of Directors meeting on January 16, 
  1997 show that Sherwood approved the authorization to fund the settlement, but 
  there was an erroneous assumption that the other defendants would contribute 
  approximately $650,000 towards the $1 million settlement, so the joint venture 
  would be responsible for only $300,000.Â  The Sherwood board then approved a 
  measure to commit $100,000, or one-third of the anticipated amount, toward the 
  settlement.Â  This offer was subject to approval by Spartanburg and receipt of 
  a full release of Sherwood.Â  However, Harris thought Sherwoodâ€™s offer was unsatisfactory.Â  
  Thus, Spartanburg did not respond and subsequently rejected the offer. 
Spartanburg decided to authorize Bellamy to continue with 
  the settlement negotiations and â€œdeal with Sherwood at a later time.â€Â  Bellamy 
  continued to work on a settlement and in February 1997 all parties to the underlying 
  litigation entered into a global settlement in the amount of $5,450,000.Â  The 
  joint venture was responsible for $835,000 of the total settlement.Â  Spartanburg 
  then issued a capital call requiring Sherwood to contribute $278,333.33, or 
  one-third of the joint ventureâ€™s portion.Â  However, Sherwood refused to pay.Â  
  Spartanburg paid the entire amount and sued Sherwood to collect its share of 
  the settlement.Â  The joint venture was dissolved as of December 31, 1998.Â  

The case was referred to a master-in-equity by a consent 
  order of the parties.Â  The claims against Appellants were bifurcated because 
  all the other Appellants stood in the shoes of Sherwood in regard to the claims 
  asserted in this case.Â  The claims against Sherwood were tried before the master, 
  and he issued a preliminary order finding Sherwood was liable for its share 
  of the settlement as alleged, plus pre-judgment interest in the amount of $158,302.11, 
  for a total of $436,635.44.Â  Sherwood made a motion for reconsideration.Â  In 
  August 2003, the master issued an order denying Sherwoodâ€™s motion to the extent 
  it sought to reverse his findings of fact and conclusions of law, resolving 
  his findings on certain testimony in Spartanburgâ€™s favor, and adopting the preliminary 
  order as the final order and judgment against Sherwood.Â  Sherwood now appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an action at law, referred to a master for final judgment, this 
  court will correct errors of law, but we must affirm the masterâ€™s factual findings 
  unless there is no evidence that reasonably supports those findings. Jefferies 
  v. Phillips, 316 S.C. 523, 527, 451 S.E.2d 21, 22-23 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The 
  complaint alleges four causes of action against Sherwood, three of which are 
  legal claims.Â  Of these, two involve breach of the joint venture Agreement, 
  and one is a claim for contribution pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-510 (Supp. 
  2003).Â  See Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 
  S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992) (action for breach of contract seeking money damages 
  is an action at law); Wallace v. Milliken & Co., 300 S.C. 553, 555, 
  389 S.E.2d 448, 449 (Ct. App. 1990), affâ€™d as modified, 305 S.C. 118, 
  406 S.E.2d 358 (1991) (actions created by statute are generally legal in nature).
The fourth issue, quantum meruit, is equitable in nature.Â  
  When both legal and equitable claims are in the same suit, each retains its 
  own identity and applicable standard of review.Â  Corley v. Ott, 326 S.C. 
  89, 92, 485 S.E.2d 97, 99 (1997).Â  In equity cases, the appellate court may 
  find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 544, 590 S.E.2d 338, 345 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Sherwood argues 
  it is not required to pay its share of the settlement because it did not agree 
  to contribute to the settlement.Â  We disagree.Â  
Partnership law 
  governs relations among joint venturers.Â  Matter of Fox, 327 S.C. 293, 
  301, 490 S.E.2d 265, 270 (1997).Â  â€œPractically the only difference between a 
  â€˜joint adventureâ€™ and a â€˜partnershipâ€™ is that a partnership is ordinarily for 
  the transaction of a general business of a particular kind, while a joint adventure 
  relates to a single transaction.â€Â  Wellington v. Crosland, 129 S.C. 127, 
  141, 123 S.E. 776, 781 (1924).Â  Accordingly, joint venturers owe each other 
  the highest level of fiduciary duty, as in partnerships.Â  Kuznik v. Bees 
  Ferry Assoc., 342 S.C. 579, 597-98, 538 S.E.2d 15, 24-25 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  Also, section 33-41-510(1) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) provides 
  that each joint venturer must contribute toward the joint ventureâ€™s losses according 
  to its share of the profits unless there is a contrary agreement between the 
  venturers.Â  
It is unclear from 
  the record whether an agreement was ever reached between the parties in regard 
  to authorization of the settlement.Â  However, under partnership law, Spartanburg 
  does not have to show that Sherwood agreed to contribute to the settlement.Â  
  Each venturer in a joint venture is an agent of the joint venture, and his or 
  her acts done in the ordinary course of business bind the joint venture.Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-310 (1990).Â  Thus, if the settlement was a valid act of the 
  joint venture, done in the ordinary course of business, Sherwood must contribute 
  its share unless it can show an agreement to the contrary.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  33-41-510(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  
There is evidence 
  in the record to support the masterâ€™s finding that authorization of the settlement 
  was in the ordinary course of business.Â Â  Although the venturers never voted 
  on the settlement, Sherwood offered $100,000 toward the settlement, which represented 
  what it believed at the time to be one-third of the joint ventureâ€™s obligation.Â  
  Neither Gerald nor anyone else at Sherwood objected to the settlement, and Gerald 
  testified he was present in the courtroom when the settlement was announced 
  on the record in open court. 
Spartanburg made 
  the decision to go forward, believing it had the authority as majority venturer 
  to act for the joint venture.Â  Harris, acting as counsel for Spartanburg, made 
  the call to Bellamy to authorize the settlement on behalf of the joint venture.Â  
  Once the authorization was made, the obligation became a valid debt of the joint 
  venture.Â  Sherwood agreed to pay one-third of any valid joint venture debts 
  under the Agreement.Â  Although there is some disagreement as to whether Sherwood 
  agreed to fund the settlement, there is no dispute that Spartanburg did not 
  agree that Sherwood would be relieved of its responsibility to pay its part 
  of the settlement amount.Â  Thus, Sherwood is required under partnership law 
  to pay its share of the settlement.Â  
Sherwood argues 
  section 1.3 of the Agreement, which provides that a venturer is only liable 
  for debts or obligations incurred pursuant to the Agreement, absolves it of 
  liability for the settlement because it was not an obligation incurred pursuant 
  to the Agreement.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
The settlement 
  did not create a new obligation for the joint venture. Â It merely settled a 
  contingent liability.Â  The lawsuits were a liability of the joint venture, not 
  just Spartanburg, and there was evidence that an adverse judgment could have 
  cost more than $13 million.Â  Regardless of the amount eventually agreed upon, 
  Sherwood demonstrated it was willing to participate in a settlement by approving 
  a contribution of $100,000.Â  Therefore, section 1.3 does not remove Sherwoodâ€™s 
  obligation to pay its share.
Sherwood also argues 
  the settlement payment was not a valid joint venture debt because Spartanburg 
  paid the settlement amount out of its own account for tax purposes.Â  We disagree.Â  

Whether or not 
  parties attempt to characterize payments as something they are not for tax purposes 
  does not affect the agreement between the partners.Â  Bray v. Head, 311 
  S.C. 490, 496-97, 429 S.E.2d 842, 845-46 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Spartanburg intended 
  the payment to be on behalf of the joint venture.Â  In Kuznik v. Bees Ferry 
  Assoc., 342 S.C. 579, 538 S.E.2d 15 (Ct. App. 2000), this court considered 
  several factors in determining whether a promissory note was a valid partnership 
  obligation.Â  While one of the factors the court considered was how the partnership 
  characterized the debt, the court also considered other factors, including capital 
  calls from the partnership and testimony from a partner and an attorney for 
  the partnership.Â  Id. at 591-92, 538 S.E.2d at 21-22.Â  Applying these 
  factors to this case, we find no error in the masterâ€™s conclusion that the settlement 
  was a valid partnership obligation.
The master further 
  found that Section 33-41-510(1) of the South Carolina Code created a right of 
  contribution in Spartanburg from Sherwood.Â  This is consistent with our holding 
  in Kuznik, where we upheld a finding of entitlement to indemnity once 
  a valid partnership obligation was found.Â  Thus, without determining whether 
  the statute itself created a right of contribution, Spartanburg clearly had 
  a common law right of contribution for indemnity.Â  Additionally, the joint venture 
  Agreement itself creates a right of indemnity in Spartanburg from Sherwood.Â  
  Pursuant to section 9.4.5 of the Agreement, Sherwood is required to pay its 
  share of the settlement in order to remove the negative capital balance that 
  was created when the joint venture dissolved. Â 
Because the settlement 
  created a valid joint venture obligation, and Sherwood is required to pay its 
  share under both partnership law and the Agreement, we need not address the 
  quantum meruit claim or the remaining issues in this case.Â  Accordingly, 
  Sherwood is liable for one-third of the settlement.
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December

Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate Defense, of

PER CURIAM:Â  In May 2003, Kelvin Creech was tried and found guilty of 
  failure to stop for a blue light.Â  He was sentenced to two years imprisonment.Â  
  Creech appeals, arguing the trial court erred by allowing the State to present 
  inadmissible prejudicial character evidence against him.Â  On appeal, counsel 
  for Creech has filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S.

  permission to withdraw from further representation.Â  Creech has not filed a 
  pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record pursuant to Anders and State 
  v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal 
  and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.
 APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
  
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Flanary v. Flanary
text:
PER CURIAM: In this domestic action, Edward Flanary appeals the family 
courtâ€™s equitable division of marital property


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Edward R. Flanary, Jr., Appellant,
v.
Carolyn Virginia Flanary, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-613
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
O. W. Bannister, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
Vanessa Lynn Hartman, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  In this domestic action, Edward Flanary appeals the family 
  courtâ€™s equitable division of marital property, claiming the family court erred 
  in its calculation of the division of the estate.Â  We affirm. [1] 
 FACTS
  Edward Flanary (Husband) married Carolyn Flanary (Wife) in 1980. Both Husband 
    and Wife had children from a previous marriage. Initially, Husband worked 
    in sales and Wife stayed at home as a homemaker.Â  In 1981, the parties opened 
    a retail fabric business, eventually selling their interest in the company 
    in 1987.Â  In 1990, Husband and Wife started American Foam and Fabric (American 
    Foam) to sell replacement headliners for automobiles.Â  At the time of trial, 
    the business had grown from a few part-time employees to ten full-time employees.Â  
    Husband carried most of the responsibility for running and managing the business. 
    Wife assisted with the business, receiving a small salary for secretarial 
    duties she performed during the day while the children attended school.Â  Wife 
    worked regularly at American Foam until 1997 when she quit to take care of 
    her father who had been diagnosed with cancer. 
  Husband and Wife separated in 1998 and after several failed 
    attempts to reconcile. Wife filed for divorce in June 2000 based on a one-year 
    separation; however, the case was administratively dismissed for lack of trial 
    or other disposition within two hundred and seventy days.Â  In January 2002, 
    Husband filed for divorce, which the court granted in September 2002. A hearing 
    was held to determine issues related to alimony, equitable division, and attorneysâ€™ 
    fees. The family court awarded Wife permanent periodic alimony, divided the 
    marital assets, and denied attorneysâ€™ fees to either party. Husband filed 
    a motion for reconsideration arguing the court erred in its equitable division, 
    which was denied.Â  This appeal follows.
  LAW/ANALYSIS
  Husband 
    argues the family court abused its discretion by miscalculating the marital 
    estate and failing to grant Husband a greater portion of the estate.Â  We disagree. 
  
  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code lists fifteen factors for the 
    court to consider in making an equitable apportionment of marital estates 
    and vests the discretion to decide what weight should be assigned to the various 
    factors in the family court. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003).Â  â€œOn 
    review, we look to the fairness of the overall apportionment; if the end result 
    is equitable, it is irrelevant that we might have weighed specific factors 
    differently than the family court.â€Â  Â Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 
    88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œThis court will affirm the 
    family court judge if it can be determined that the judge addressed the factors 
    under section 20-7-472 sufficiently for us to conclude he was cognizant of 
    the statutory factors.â€Â  Id. Â Â 
  Husband contends the family court intended to give each party an equal portion 
    of the estate and the court omitted certain debt in its calculations; however, 
    the courtâ€™s order refutes this claim.Â  The order approximates an equal apportionment 
    of assets, yet Husband received a greater debt ratio. While Husband does carry 
    a greater load of the marital debt, he also receives income-producing assets 
    to assist in extinguishing the debt. All the debt calculations might not have 
    been clearly delineated in the courtâ€™s order; however, the entirety of Husbandâ€™s 
    debt appears plainly in the order. Furthermore, the family court addressed 
    Husbandâ€™s argument in its order denying the motion for reconsideration and 
    reiterated the reasons for dividing the estate in such a manner.Â  The court 
    listed several factors to compensate for Husbandâ€™s higher debt ratio, including 
    awarding American Foam to Husband, imputing income to Wife, assigning a lower 
    than actual income to Husband, and allowing Husband an annual credit. 
  The law of equitable distribution is premised on providing the family court 
    the flexibility to view each case based on individual circumstances peculiar 
    to the parties involved and to fashion division of partiesâ€™ assets in a manner 
    that is uniquely fair to the parties concerned.Â  Thomas v. Thomas, 
    353 S.C. 523, 529, 579 S.E.2d 310, 313 (2003).Â  Equitable division is not 
    necessarily equal division. Â Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its 
    discretion when determining equitable division of the marital estate.
  AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
   ANDERSON, J., concurs.Â  STILWELL, J., dissents in a separate 
    opinion.
  STILWELL, J. (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, 
    the net result of the division of marital assets and the assignment of marital 
    debt is inequitable distribution, not equitable distribution.
  The total amount of gross assets, according to the calculations relied upon 
    by the family court, is $1,224,521.Â  The total amount of marital debts is 
    $937,777.75, resulting in net equity to be equitably apportioned of $286,743.25.Â  
    Even though Husband received gross assets valued at $961,725, he was assigned 
    total marital debts of $880,026, leaving him with a net equity pursuant to 
    equitable distribution of $81,699 as compared to Wifeâ€™s net equitable distribution 
    valued at $205,044.Â  I am convinced this is not the result intended by the 
    court.Â  The wording of the order itself clearly indicates the court wanted 
    to make â€œan approximate equal division of the properties,â€ and the requirement 
    in the order that the Husband pay down the first mortgage on the marital home 
    was designed to â€œequalize the division.â€Â  
  This conclusion is buttressed by the family courtâ€™s final analysis of the 
    equitable distribution award when it summarized the results by stating that 
    Husbandâ€™s â€œnet marital estate,â€ after calculating the debt assigned to Husband, 
    â€œwill be $222,632.39â€ and compared that with â€œWifeâ€™s net estate . . . [of] 
    $215,501.28.â€Â  This leads to the inescapable conclusion that there has been 
    a mathematical miscalculation, since the sum of these two figures greatly 
    exceeds the total value of the net estate.Â  For this reason, I believe the 
    result of the family courtâ€™s equitable distribution award was not as intended.
  Even if the family court intended this result, I would favor reversing because, 
    in my opinion, this division, which apportions approximately 71% of the net 
    marital estate to Wife where there is no marital fault involved, no children 
    were born of the union, and Wife is awarded $2,000 per month in alimony, is 
    patently unfair and inequitable.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Ashley Villas Homeownersâ€™ Association v. Johnson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN 
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ashley Villas Homeownersâ€™ Association, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Geona Shaw Johnson; et al., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-614
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  December 7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Helen Ann Harper and Robert A. Kerr, Jr., both of Mt. Pleasant, 
  for Appellant.
Benjamin Goldberg, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Ashley Villas Homeownersâ€™ Association appeals from an order 
  granting summary judgment to Respondents.Â  We reverse.  
  [1] 
  FACTS
  Ashley Villas is a residential neighborhood constituting 234 townhouse properties.Â  
    Thomas M. Evans (the â€œdeveloperâ€) developed the neighborhood in 1974.Â  At 
    that time, the developer recorded the original restrictive covenants in the 
    Register of Mesne Conveyance (RMC) office for Charleston County.
  The developer built and maintained common recreation 
    areas in the neighborhood; however, he deeded the recreation areas to the 
    Ashley Villa homeowners in 1976.Â  The homeowners accepted the transfer and 
    created the Recreation Association to maintain the areas.Â  The Recreation 
    Association was incorporated as a nonprofit organization in March 1976. 
  By 1990, the neighborhood had fallen into a state 
    of disrepair.Â  As a result, a group of homeowners organized an effort to improve 
    the neighborhood.Â  The group sought the votes necessary to amend the original 
    covenants and to establish a homeownersâ€™ association to enforce the covenants.Â  
    In December 1994, the group recorded the amended covenants and the creation 
    of the Homeownersâ€™ Association in the RMC. 
  Initially, the Recreation Association continued 
    to own the recreation areas.Â  However, the Recreation Associationâ€™s members 
    voted to transfer the recreation areas to the newly created Homeownersâ€™ Association 
    because the association lacked the funds necessary to maintain the areas.Â  
    The Homeownersâ€™ Association accepted the transfer in December 1998.
  On August 9, 2000, the Homeownersâ€™ Association brought 
    an action to collect past due annual assessments from delinquent homeowners.Â  
    The trial court ordered arbitration and an arbitration hearing was held on 
    June 13, 2001.Â  The arbitrator found in favor of the Homeownersâ€™ Association 
    and awarded it past due annual assessments and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Respondents 
    appealed and the judge granted them a right to a jury trial.Â  The Homeownersâ€™ 
    Association then filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied on 
    December 20, 2001.Â  Respondents also filed a motion for summary judgment and 
    a hearing was held on September 18, 2003.Â  The trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ 
    motion for summary judgment on November 18, 2002.Â  The Homeownersâ€™ Association 
    now appeals.
  STANDARD OF REVIEW  
    On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, we review all ambiguities, 
      conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence in a light most favorable 
      to the non-moving party.Â  Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 
      349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002).Â  â€œSummary judgment is appropriate 
      when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and the 
      conclusions and inferences to be drawn from the facts are undisputed.â€Â  
      Etheredge v. Richland Sch. Dist. One, 341 S.C. 307, 311, 534 S.E.2d 
      275, 277 (2000).Â  Moreover, summary judgment is proper only when the moving 
      party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Jackson v. Doe, 
      342 S.C. 552, 555, 537 S.E.2d 567, 568 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
    â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts 
      of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Tupper 
      v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997). 
      â€œSummary judgment should not be granted even when there is no dispute as 
      to evidentiary facts if there is dispute as to the conclusion to be drawn 
      from those facts.â€Â  Id.Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy, which 
      should be cautiously invoked so that no party will be improperly deprived 
      of a trial of the disputed factual issue.Â  Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 
      S.C. 310, 318-319, 592 S.E.2d 326, 331 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS


I. Extrinsic Evidence


The
Homeownersâ€™ Association argues the trial court erred in admitting extrinsic
evidence to explain the terms of the original covenants because the evidence
violates the parol evidence rule.  We
agree.
      The parol evidence 
      rule prevents the introduction of extrinsic evidence of agreements or understandings 
      contemporaneous with or prior to execution of a written instrument when 
      the extrinsic evidence is to be used to contradict, vary, or explain the 
      written instrument.â€Â Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards,
      354 S.C. 459, 471, 581 S.E.2d 496, 502 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe cardinal rule 
      of contract interpretation is to ascertain and give effect to the intention 
      of the parties and, in determining that intention, the court looks to the 
      language of the contract.â€Â  Friarsgate, Inc. v. First Federal Sav. and 
      Loan Assâ€™n of South Carolina, 317 S.C. 452, 457, 454 S.E.2d 901, 905 
      (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous, clear, and explicit, 
      it must be construed according to the terms the parties have used, to be 
      taken and understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  Id.
Ashley Villasâ€™
original covenants state that the â€œ[c]ovenants shall automatically renew . . .
unless a change in part or in whole shall be agreed upon by a majority vote of
the homeowners of Ashley Villas.â€
Respondents argue the developer never intended for Ashley Villas to have
a homeownersâ€™ association.To
prove the developer did not intend for the language â€œchange in part or in
wholeâ€ to include altering the original covenants to allow for the creation of
a homeownersâ€™ association, the trial court allowed an affidavit from Alvie
Evans, an individual involved in the original development of Ashley Villas, to
be admitted as extrinsic evidence.However,
taken in the light most favorable to the Homeownersâ€™ Association, the language
of the original covenants was â€œunambiguous, clear, and explicitâ€ in its
â€œplain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Therefore,
the trial court erred in admitting Evansâ€™ affidavit to prove the developerâ€™s
intent.
 
  Moreover, summary judgment was improper even if the language of the 
  original covenants was ambiguous because the determination of a partyâ€™s intent 
  is a question of fact.Â  Southern Financial Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 
  349 S.C. 77, 81, 562 S.E.2d 482, 484 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œOnce the court decides 
  the language is ambiguous, evidence may be admitted to show the intent of the 
  parties.â€Â  Id.Â  Examined in the light most favorable to the Homeownersâ€™ 
  Association, there is conflicting evidence as to the developerâ€™s intent.Â  
  Evansâ€™ affidavit stated the developer did not include a homeownersâ€™ association 
    in the original covenants because he did not intend for one to be created.Â  
    Phoebe Miller, a past president and current treasurer of the Homeownersâ€™ Association, 
    testified the developer did not provide for a homeownersâ€™ association because 
    he wanted federal assistance financing.Â  Miller also testified the homeowners 
    created a Homeownersâ€™ Association because of new federal guidelines requiring 
    a homeownersâ€™ association for federal financing.Â  The conflicting evidence 
    of Evansâ€™ affidavit and Millerâ€™s testimony create a genuine issue of material 
    fact as to whether the developer intended to qualify for federal financing 
    or to exclude a homeownersâ€™ association.Â  Therefore, even if the trial court 
    properly admitted the extrinsic evidence, summary judgment was improper because 
    a genuine issue of material fact exists regarding the developerâ€™s intent.Â  
  
  II. South Carolina Nonprofit Corporation 
    Act
  The Homeownersâ€™ Association also contends the trial court erred in holding 
    the Recreation Association failed to comply with the South Carolina Nonprofit 
    Corporation Act.Â  Specifically, the Homeownersâ€™ Association argues a genuine 
    issue of material fact exists as to whether the notice requirements of section 
    33-31-1202(c) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003) were satisfied.Â  We 
    agree.
  The sale of assets 
    by a nonprofit corporation other than in the ordinary course of activities 
    is governed by section 33-31-1202 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003).Â  
    A nonprofit corporation may:

  [S]ell, lease, exchange, or otherwise dispose of all, or substantially all, 
    of its property, with or without the goodwill, other than in the usual and 
    regular course of its activities on the terms and conditions and for the consideration 
    determined by the corporationâ€™s board if the proposed transaction is authorized 
    by subsection (b).

  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-1202(a) 
    (Supp. 2003).Â  
  However, section (c) further states:

  If the corporation does not have members, or does not have members entitled 
    to vote on the transaction, the transaction must be approved by a vote of 
    a majority of the directors in office at the time the transaction is approved.Â  
    In addition, the corporation shall provide notice of any directorsâ€™ meeting 
    at which such approval is to be obtained in accordance with Section 33-31-822(c).Â  
    The notice also must state that the purpose, or one of the purposes, of the 
    meeting is to consider the sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of 
    all, or substantially all, of the property or assets of the corporation and 
    contain or be accompanied by a copy or summary of a description of the transaction.

  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-1202(c) 
    (Supp. 2003).Â  
  If a nonprofit corporation has members entitled to vote, the proposed transaction 
    must be approved by the board and by two-thirds of membersâ€™ votes cast or 
    a majority of the voting power, whichever is less.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-1202(b) 
    (Supp. 2003).Â  A directorâ€™s attendance at or participation in a meeting waives 
    the notice requirement for the meeting.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-31-823(b) (Supp. 
    2003).
  At trial, 
    Respondents argued the transfer of the recreation area from the Recreation 
    Association to the Homeownersâ€™ Association was invalid because the Recreation 
    Association failed to comply with the notice requirements of section 33-31-1202(c) 
    of the South Carolina Code.Â  Specifically, Respondents alleged some Recreation 
    Association members and directors did not receive notice of the transfer or 
    vote on the transfer, rendering the transfer invalid.Â  The trial court agreed 
    and held the Homeownersâ€™ Association could not charge any assessments because 
    it did not own, lease, or have a duty to maintain the recreation areas as 
    the transfer was invalid for failure to comply with South Carolina Code section 
    33-31-1202.
  Taken in the light most favorable to the Homeownersâ€™ Association, a genuine 
    issue of material fact exists as to whether the requisite number of directors 
    and members of the Recreation Association received notice and voted on the 
    transfer.Â  The parties presented conflicting evidence of the number of Recreation 
    Association directors at the time of the transfer.Â  Michael Oshinsky, president 
    of the Homeownersâ€™ Association, testified the three directors who voted unanimously 
    to transfer the recreation areas to the Homeownersâ€™ Association were also 
    the only remaining members of the Recreation Association.Â  Oshinsky testified 
    the notice provision of section 33-31-1202 of the South Carolina Code was 
    satisfied because the three directors were the only members and their vote 
    for the transfer waived the notice requirements.Â  Moreover, evidence suggested 
    the Recreational Association had no members after May 3, 1996, which was more 
    than four months prior to the September 22, 1996 vote to transfer the property 
    to the Homeownersâ€™ Association. 
    [2] Â  Therefore, summary judgment was improper.
  REVERSED. 
  ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  The Record on Appeal includes a list of members, an itemized category 
    report, and check register for the Recreation Association.Â  The last deposit 
    for a membership fee was made on May 3, 1995, and because memberships were 
    annual the last membership would have expired on May 3, 1996, more than four 
    months before the meeting to transfer the recreation areas to the Homeownersâ€™ 
    Association.

title: State v. Cunningham
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Michael B. Cunningham, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-615
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott
Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., allÂ  
  of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Appellant.
C. Carlyle Steele, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case comes before us on appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s 
  decision reversing and remanding respondentâ€™s conviction in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  
  We reverse the circuit court.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Respondent, Michael B. Cunningham, was charged with 
  littering and appeared before the magistrate.Â  Waiving his right to counsel 
  and to a jury trial, he was found guilty following a bench trial.Â  Cunningham 
  appealed to the court of common pleas asserting, among other things, that he 
  should receive a new trial because the main witness at the trial â€œdid not testify 
  directly, but rather had [the] officer read his statement which was improper 
  hearsay.â€Â  
The magistrate filed a return which included as follows:

The State represented 
  by Master Deputy, Ben Forrester, presented a sworn statement signed by the victim, 
  Mr. V.L. Sloan, about the incident which occurred in his presence on the date 
  of May 6, 2002.Â  The victim was present in the courtroom and stated for the 
  record that he was the author of that statement.Â  He was also prepared to answer 
  any questions that the defendant, Michael Cunningham, might have.Â  He did not 
  ask Mr. Sloan anything.Â  This was not improper hearsay.

*Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  *

The defendant did testify 
  in this bench trial merely stating that Mr. Sloan must have been mistaken when 
  he stated that he saw the defendant throw a bag of trash out of his truck in 
  the early hours of May 6, 2002 while the moon was still in the sky and dawn 
  was beginning.Â  The victim was standing by his house not more than 10 feet from 
  the road when he saw him throw the trash out.

On appeal to the circuit court, Cunninghamâ€™s counsel asserted 
  Cunningham was denied the right to confront witnesses against him by admission 
  of the hearsay statement, and admission of the hearsay evidence was not cured 
  by the right to cross-examination.Â  The State, while not conceding the statement 
  was improper hearsay, argued the issue was not properly preserved for appeal, 
  as there was no objection below to the reading of the victimâ€™s statement.Â  The 
  circuit court agreed that a contemporaneous objection was required, but found 
  â€œit would be speculationâ€ to assume there was no objection since there was no 
  transcript from the trial.Â  Thereafter, by order dated September 26, 2003, the 
  circuit court reversed Cunninghamâ€™s conviction and remanded for a new trial.Â  
  The circuit court judge found the reading of the statement of the witness was 
  inadmissible hearsay and, because the return did not address whether an objection 
  was made to the reading of the statement, a conclusion by the court that no 
  objection was made would involve speculation by the court.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State appeals, asserting the circuit court erred in reversing 
  Cunninghamâ€™s conviction because the record failed to show Cunningham made a 
  contemporaneous objection to the admission of the evidence at the trial level.Â  
  We agree.
A circuit court has only appellate jurisdiction over a judgment from magistrate 
  court. Â State v. Adler, 278 S.C. 66, 67, 292 S.E.2d 185, 186 (1982).Â  
  In criminal appeals from magistrate court, the circuit court may not conduct 
  a trial de novo, but instead reviews for preserved error 
  raised by appropriate exception.Â  State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 
  556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  It is axiomatic that in order to preserve 
  an issue for appellate review, a party must make a contemporaneous objection, 
  and an issue which is not properly preserved cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal.Â  State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 869, 
  873 (1994).Â  An issue must be both raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge 
  to be preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 
  142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693 (2003).
A magistrateâ€™s return is the official record of the trial proceedings, 
  and an appellate court may not consider facts not included within the return.Â  
  State v. Brown, 358 S.C. 382, 387-88, 596 S.E.2d 39, 41 (2004).Â  The 
  burden is on the appellant to provide a sufficient record from which an appellate 
  court can make an intelligent review.Â  State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 
  199, 498 S.E.2d 642, 647 (1998); State v. Freeman, 319 S.C. 110, 122, 
  459 S.E.2d 867, 874 (Ct. App. 1995).
The circuit court judge determined, because the return did not 
  address whether an objection was made to the reading of the statement, a conclusion 
  by the court that no objection had been made would involve speculation by the 
  court.Â  However, a conclusion that such an objection was made is equally speculative.Â  
  Here, the only record from the trial level in this case is the magistrateâ€™s 
  return.Â  There is simply no evidence of record that Cunningham objected to the 
  admission of the evidence at the trial level or that it was in any manner raised 
  to or ruled upon by the magistrate.Â  See Roche v. S.C. Alcoholic Beverage 
  Control Commâ€™n, 263 S.C. 451, 455, 211 S.E.2d 243, 244 (1975) (the purpose 
  of an appeal is to determine whether the trial judge erroneously acted or failed 
  to act, and where the appellantâ€™s contentions are not presented or passed on 
  by the trial judge, such contentions should not be considered on appeal).Â  As 
  previously noted, in criminal appeals from magistrate court, the circuit court 
  may review only for preserved error.Â  Further, the magistrateâ€™s return is the 
  official record of the trial proceedings, and the circuit court, sitting in 
  an appellate capacity, is not allowed to consider any facts not included within 
  the return.Â  The return does not reflect any objection was made to the admission 
  of the evidence Cunningham challenges on appeal.Â  Because the record failed 
  to reflect the issue raised on appeal was raised to the trial court, we hold 
  the circuit court erred in reversing Cunninghamâ€™s conviction on that basis.Â  

For the foregoing reasons, the circuit court order is reversed 
  and Cunninghamâ€™s conviction is reinstated.
REVERSED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
  1  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Cliffs at Keowee v. Oâ€™Donald
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The Cliffs at Keowee Community Association, Inc.,
Respondent,
v.
Roger L. Oâ€™Donald, Lynne Oâ€™Donald, and Cornerstone National Bank,
Defendants,
of whom Roger L. Oâ€™Donald and Lynne Oâ€™Donald are
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-616
Heard November 17, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James C. Alexander, of Pickens, for Appellants.
R. Murray Hughes, of Pickens, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Roger and Lynne Oâ€™Donald appeal the trial courtâ€™s order 
  granting a permanent injunction to The Cliffs at Keowee Community Association, 
  Inc.Â  The injunction prohibited the Oâ€™Donalds from constructing a home that 
  did not include a two-car garage as required by the subdivisionâ€™s restrictive 
  covenants.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1995, the Oâ€™Donalds purchased lot 27 at The Cliffs at Keowee, 
  a new residential subdivision located on Lake Keowee in Pickens County.Â  The 
  conveyance was subject to any and all restrictions attached to the property, 
  including the â€œDeclaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictionsâ€ established 
  by the Association.Â  The Association is the homeowners group for The Cliffs 
  at Keowee, and every lot owner is a member.Â  
The Covenants required the approval of all proposed structures by 
  the appropriate committee before beginning construction.Â  Further, the Covenants 
  expressly provided that the approval of any proposed plan would not constitute 
  a waiver of the right to withhold approval of any similar proposals or plans 
  subsequently or additionally submitted for review.Â  
Article XI of the Covenants, entitled â€œArchitectural Standards,â€ provides in 
  paragraph 11.8(c) that all homes are required to have two-car garages:Â  â€œAn 
  attached, semi-detached, free-standing or basement level two-car garage[] shall 
  be required for each dwelling or residence.â€Â 


Although the developer originally retained responsibility for enforcement 
  of the Covenants, it transferred this duty to the Associationâ€™s Architectural 
  Review Board (ARB) in May of 2000.Â  The Covenants required that the ARB consist 
  of three members to be duly constituted.Â Â Â  
In 2001, the Oâ€™Donalds sought approval from the ARB for plans to 
  build a home on their lot, but the request was rejected because the plans did 
  not include a two-car garage.Â  The Oâ€™Donalds subsequently proceeded with construction 
  without the ARBâ€™s approval.Â Â Â  
The Association filed suit against the Oâ€™Donalds requesting temporary and permanent 
  injunctions to stop construction of the home.Â  The Oâ€™Donalds answered and filed 
  counterclaims seeking, among other things, a declaration that the Covenants 
  were not enforceable.Â  They also filed a third-party complaint against individual 
  ARB members.Â  
In December of 2001, Judge Henry Floyd granted a temporary injunction prohibiting 
  further construction pending a hearing on the merits.Â  By consent of the parties, 
  the matter was referred to a special referee, who, after the final hearing, 
  granted a permanent injunction to the Association in May of 2003 and denied 
  the relief requested by the Oâ€™Donalds.Â  The Oâ€™Donalds filed a motion to alter 
  or amend the judgment, which was denied.Â  The Oâ€™Donalds appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to enforce restrictive covenants by means of an injunction 
  is in equity.Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 498 S.E.2d 862 (1998).Â  
  On appeal of an equitable action tried by a judge alone, this Court may find 
  facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976).Â  
  This broad scope of review does not, however, require an appellate court to 
  disregard the findings of the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses and 
  was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Widman 
  v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 557 S.E.2d 693 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Changed Conditions
The Oâ€™Donalds first contend the trial court erred in finding the 
  subdivision had not been radically and substantially changed so as to make the 
  Covenants unenforceable.Â  We disagree.
Under South Carolina law, restrictive covenants can be deemed unenforceable 
  where there has been a change of conditions.Â  Inabinet v. Booe, 262 S.C. 
  81, 202 S.E.2d 643 (1974).Â  Although there is no hard and fast rule as to what 
  constitutes a change of conditions, generally the character of a neighborhood 
  must have been radically and substantially altered so as to practically destroy 
  the essential objects and purposes of the restrictive covenants.Â  Id. 
  at 84, 202 S.E.2d at 645 (citing Pitts v. Brown, 215 S.C. 122, 54 S.E.2d 
  538 (1949)).Â  The party seeking to avoid enforcement of the restrictions has 
  the burden of proving a change of conditions.Â  Id.Â  
To support their argument, the Oâ€™Donalds point to several violations 
  of the Covenants, such as the fact that three homes were built without two-car 
  garages.Â  As noted by the trial court, two of the homes were built without garages 
  when the developer retained enforcement power and there are no records as to 
  whether or not these homeowners received approval before building their homes.Â  
  Once the ARB was aware of violations following its takeover of enforcement, 
  it wrote letters to the homeowners requesting compliance with the Covenants 
  or proof that the developer had approved the plans.Â  The Association is currently 
  working with these homeowners to resolve the violations.Â Â Â  
The Oâ€™Donalds also suggest that a two-car, in-line garage in the neighborhood 
  was a radical and substantial change from the Covenants that altered the character 
  of the subdivision.Â  The homeowners with that garage, however, followed the 
  Associationâ€™s process for seeking approval and worked closely with the ARB.Â  
  The ARB eventually approved the two-car, in-line garage because the unique nature 
  of the homeownersâ€™ property justified a variance.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Other violations alleged by the Oâ€™Donalds, such as the lack of requisite 
  square footage, the lack of paved walkways, the docking of a houseboat on one 
  of the lots, and the use of plywood siding, also first occurred when the developer 
  had the responsibility of enforcing the Covenants.Â  As William Mahoney, chairman 
  of the ARB, testified, â€œall of the plans that [the ARB has] approved since . 
  . . July 15, 2000 meet the requirements.â€Â  In addition, the ARB sent compliance 
  request letters to the homeowners, and timetables have been set to bring violators 
  into compliance.Â  Although some violations do exist in the subdivision, we agree 
  with the trial courtâ€™s ruling that they have not fundamentally changed the residential 
  character of the neighborhood so as to make the Covenants unenforceable.Â Â Â  

II.Â  Waiver and Estoppel
The Oâ€™Donalds assert the trial court erred in holding the Association 
  neither waived nor is estopped from asserting its right to enforce the Covenants 
  because it failed to object to past violations.
â€œA waiver is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or relinquishment 
  of a known right.â€Â  Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horizontal Prop. Regime, 
  307 S.C. 339, 344, 415 S.E.2d 384, 387 (1992).Â  â€œGenerally, the party claiming 
  waiver must show that the party against whom waiver is asserted possessed, at 
  the time, actual or constructive knowledge of his rights or of all the material 
  facts upon which they depended.â€Â  Id. at 344, 415 S.E.2d at 387-88.Â  
  Further, a partyâ€™s waiver of the right to object to a minor violation of a restrictive 
  covenant does not result in waiver of his right to object to a subsequent and 
  more substantial violation.Â  Gibbs v. Kimbrell, 311 S.C. 261, 268, 428 
  S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 1993).
As noted above, when the ARB took over enforcement of the Covenants, 
  the violations complained of by the Oâ€™Donalds were already in existence.Â  Once 
  the ARB learned of the violations, it began the process of bringing those homeowners 
  into compliance.Â  The only variance granted by the ARB was for the two-car, 
  in-line garage, which was properly approved as required by the Covenants.Â  Moreover, 
  the Covenants themselves provide that the granting of a variance does not prevent 
  the future enforcement of those restrictions on a homeowner.Â  Thus, we agree 
  with the trial court that the Association did not make a voluntary and intentional 
  waiver of its right to enforce the Covenants.
The Oâ€™Donalds also argue that the Association is estopped from enforcing 
  the Covenants because it has permitted multiple violations by other homeowners 
  without protest.Â  
â€œEstoppel arises when a party, relying upon what another has said 
  or done, changes his position to his detriment.â€Â  Gibbs, 311 S.C. at 
  268, 428 S.E.2d at 729.Â  â€œAdditionally, estoppel arises when a party observes 
  another dealing with his property in a manner inconsistent with his rights and 
  makes no objection while the other changes his position in reliance on the partyâ€™s 
  silence; the partyâ€™s silence is acquiescence that estops him from later seeking 
  relief.â€Â  Id.
Our review of the record reveals no evidence to suggest that the 
  Oâ€™Donalds changed their position in reliance upon the words, actions, or acquiescence 
  of the Association.Â  Despite the ARBâ€™s insistence that it intended to enforce 
  the Covenants, the Oâ€™Donalds began construction of their home and continued 
  until the circuit court issued a temporary injunction against them.Â  The Oâ€™Donalds 
  knew they did not have ARB approval, but violated the Covenants and began construction 
  anyway.Â  Accordingly, we hold the Association is not estopped from enforcing 
  the Covenants.Â  
III.Â  Composition of the ARB
The Oâ€™Donalds claim the trial court erred in finding the ARB had 
  sufficient authority to enforce the Covenants.Â  We disagree.
The Oâ€™Donalds assert the Covenants require the ARB to consist of at least three 
  members.Â  Although their meeting minutes refer only to two members, we conclude 
  there is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s finding that the ARB as then 
  constituted had sufficient authority to enforce the restrictions when the Oâ€™Donalds 
  sought approval of their construction plans.Â  
William Mahoney, Richard Kraince, and William Carruthers, Jr. all testified 
  that they were members of the ARB, with Mr. Mahoney being the chairman.Â  The 
  minutes expressly reflect that at least two of the above, Mr. Mahoney and Mr. 
  Carruthers, served on the ARB.Â  The minutes also show that any member wishing 
  to serve on the ARB could simply contact Mr. Mahoney.Â  Mr. Kraince testified 
  he was also on the committee as a volunteer member.Â  Mr. Mahoney confirmed that 
  Mr. Kraince was a member of the committee, although his name was not specifically 
  listed in the minutes in that capacity.Â  Mr. Mahoney stated that the same minutes, 
  which failed to list Mr. Kraince, also failed to reflect that the Oâ€™Donalds 
  had attended the board meeting, so the minutes were incomplete.Â  
In any case, we note the Oâ€™Donalds could have immediately challenged the composition 
  of the ARB and thus its power to enforce the Covenants.Â  Instead, they elected 
  to build without first obtaining approval from the ARB; consequently, we find 
  no error in this regard.Â  
IV.Â  Damages
The Oâ€™Donalds lastly claim the trial court erred in failing to award 
  actual and punitive damages.Â  
An argument is deemed abandoned on appeal if it is argued in a short, 
  conclusory statement without supporting authority.Â  Fields v. Melrose Ltd. 
  Partnership, 312 S.C. 102, 439 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  We decline to 
  address this issue because the Oâ€™Donalds failed to analyze the facts or state 
  appropriate authority to support their argument on appeal.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher M. Pringle 
  was convicted of driving under suspension (DUS), second offense, failure to 
  stop for a blue light, and possession of a firearm by a person convicted of 
  a crime of violence.Â  He received consecutive sentences of three years for failure 
  to stop for a blue light and two years for possession of a firearm by a person 
  convicted of a crime of violence, and a concurrent sixty day sentence for DUS.Â  
  On appeal, Pringle argues the trial court erred â€œby denying [Pringleâ€™s] motion 
  for a directed verdict when he was charged with being a violent felon in possession 
  of a weapon under S.C. Code Section 16-23-30, and his prior offense, third-degree 
  burglary, is not classified as a crime of violence.â€Â  We affirm

  691 (2003) (holding that in order for an issue to be preserved for appellate

  alternative ground on appeal.â€); State v. Jordan, 255 S.C. 86, 177 S.E.2d 
  464 (1970) (determining that in reviewing denial of directed verdict motion, 
  issues not raised to trial court in support of directed verdict motion are not 
  preserved for appellate review).

  JJ., concur.

title: State v. Blom
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
William Joseph Blom, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-622
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  10, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  John Gregory Hembree, of Conway; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  William Joseph Blom appeals his murder conviction, arguing 
  the trial court erred in refusing his requested jury charge on circumstantial 
  evidence.Â  We affirm.  [1] 
BACKGROUND
Lance Neal was at a bar with friends when he received a phone call.Â  When the 
  call ended, he said it was from Blom.Â  Neal said he was going out behind a nearby 
  restaurant to have a â€œman on man fightâ€ with Blom over Bronna Miller, Blomâ€™s 
  girlfriend and the mother of Nealâ€™s child.Â  One of Nealâ€™s friends tried unsuccessfully 
  to dissuade him, noting Blom owned a gun. Â Outside, Neal was seen sitting 
  in a car with Blom.Â  The two then got out of the car and were talking.Â  One 
  State witness testified the two tussled.Â  Witnesses then heard several shots 
  and saw Neal run away and Blom drive away.Â  Another bystander saw Neal running 
  after the shots were fired and saw him collapse. Â One of Nealâ€™s friends 
  ran down and found him lying in a pool of blood. Â Neal died as a result 
  of a gunshot wound to the chest. 
After the shooting, an officer looking for Blomâ€™s car encountered 
  John Poston, who said he had seen a man driving a car fitting that description.Â  
  Poston said the man stopped the car, got out, squatted down, and extended his 
  hand into some brush on the side of the road.Â  Poston showed the officer the 
  location, and police found a gun there, hidden under some pine straw.Â  
The defense asserted Blom shot Neal in self-defense.Â  The 
  defense introduced testimony that Neal was threatening Blom at the scene, that 
  Neal had been drinking and was a mean drunk, and that he liked to fight and 
  had a reputation for violence and aggression.Â  Blom, in contrast, was a â€œperfect 
  gentleman.â€Â  The defense also offered evidence that during the incident, Blomâ€™s 
  shirt was torn, his necklace was broken and ripped off, and his body was bruised 
  and scratched.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Blom argues the trial court erred in refusing to issue the State 
  v. Edwards circumstantial evidence instruction.Â  He contends because there 
  was only circumstantial evidence of the exact nature of the confrontation and 
  murder, voluntary manslaughter, and self-defense were jury options, the court 
  should have instructed the jury that it could find him guilty of murder only 
  if the evidence pointed conclusively to his guilt to the exclusion of every 
  other reasonable hypothesis.Â  We find no error.
The evidence presented at trial determines the law to be charged 
  to the jury.Â  State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 231, 589 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2003).Â  
  The trial court is only required to charge the current and correct law and a 
  charge that correctly defines the law when read as a whole is proper.Â  State 
  v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 261, 565 S.E.2d 298, 302 (2002).
Here, Blom does not dispute the charge issued is essentially the 
  one announced and recommended by our supreme court in State v. Grippon, 
  327 S.C. 79, 489 S.E.2d 462 (1997).Â  At trial Blom requested the traditional 
  circumstantial charge from State v. Edwards, 298 S.C. 272, 379 S.E.2d 
  888 (1989) and State v. Littlejohn, 228 S.C. 324, 89 S.E.2d 924 (1955).Â  
  Specifically, he wanted the language that all of the circumstances when taken 
  together must â€œpoint conclusively to the guilt of the accused to the exclusion 
  of every other reasonable hypothesis.â€Â  Edwards, 298 S.C. at 275, 379 
  S.E.2d at 889.Â  On appeal, he argues that because of the abundance of evidence 
  of a confrontation and the sketchy eyewitness accounts, the court should have 
  issued an Edwards instruction.Â  However, in Grippon, our supreme 
  court affirmed a trial courtâ€™s refusal to charge the language in question.Â  
  In Grippon, the appellant argued the trial courtâ€™s omission of the reasonable 
  hypothesis language impermissibly lowered the level of proof required for the 
  jury to find him guilty.Â  Although the trial court incorrectly believed the 
  language had been disapproved, the supreme court noted because the charge given 
  otherwise fully covered the law of circumstantial evidence and the trial court 
  correctly defined reasonable doubt, omission of the reasonable hypothesis language 
  did not affect the burden of proof.Â  Grippon, 327 S.C. at 82-83, 489 
  S.E.2d at 463-64.Â  The supreme court then announced a new recommended charge, 
  which does not contain the â€œreasonable hypothesisâ€ language.Â  Id. at 
  83-84, 489 S.E.2d at 464.Â  Both the Grippon charge and the Edwards 
  charge were proper in South Carolina at the time of Blomâ€™s trial.Â  See 
  State v. Needs, 333 S.C. 134, 155-56 & n.13, 508 S.E.2d 857, 868 
  & n.13 (1998). [2] Â  Because 
  the trial court here charged the jury with an approved circumstantial evidence 
  charge and, as in Grippon, correctly defined reasonable doubt, we find 
  no error.Â  State v. Manning, 305 S.C. 413, 417, 409 S.E.2d 372, 375 (1991) 
  (announcing recommended reasonable doubt instruction), abrogation in part 
  on other grounds recognized by Todd v. State, 355 S.C. 396, 585 S.E.2d 
  305 (2003).Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    For the current law on circumstantial evidence jury charges, see State 
    v. Cherry, Op. No. 25902 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Nov. 29, 2004) (Shearouse 
    Adv. Sheet No. 46 at 24).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Gilbert Cecil Barrs, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-623
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  10, 2004

VACATED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Gilbert Cecil Barrs appeals his Alford 
  [1]  plea to committing a lewd act on a minor, arguing the circuit court 
  lacked subject matter jurisdiction to accept his plea because he did not waive 
  presentment to the grand jury.Â  We agree and vacate his conviction and sentence. [2] 
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Barrs was indicted on three counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct 
  with a minor for allegedly molesting the daughter of a couple he was living 
  with.Â  Pursuant to a plea agreement with the State, he entered an Alford 
  plea to committing a lewd act on a minor and the State nol prossed the remaining 
  CSC indictments.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to ninety days, with credit 
  for time served while awaiting trial.Â  
DISCUSSIONÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Except for certain minor offenses, the circuit court does not have subject 
  matter jurisdiction to hear a guilty plea unless there has been an indictment, 
  a waiver of presentment to the grand jury, or unless the charge is a lesser-included 
  offense of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  Hopkins v. State, 317 
  S.C. 7, 9, 451 S.E.2d 389, 390 (1994); see also Odom v. State, 
  350 S.C. 300, 302, 566 S.E.2d 528, 529 (2002) (â€œIn the absence of an indictment, 
  there must be a valid waiver of presentment for the trial court to have subject 
  matter jurisdiction of the offense.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-10 (2003).Â  Lack 
  of subject matter jurisdiction may not be waived, and may be raised at any time, 
  including on the courtâ€™s own motion.Â  Campbell v. State, 342 S.C. 100, 
  101-02, 535 S.E.2d 928, 929 (2000).
The grand jury never indicted Barrs for the lewd act charge and Barrs did not 
  waive presentment to the grand jury.Â  Committing a lewd act on a minor is not 
  a lesser-included offense of first-degree criminal sexual conduct on a minor.Â  
  Id.; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 16-3-655(1) and 16-15-140 (2003).Â  
  Therefore, the trial court was without jurisdiction to accept Barrsâ€™ plea to 
  the unindicted charge.Â  
VACATED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970). 

 
   
    [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

title: State v. Miller
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Bruce Miller, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-620
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry 
  Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant 
  Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, 
  of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Bruce Miller (Miller) appeals his conviction for armed 
  robbery.Â  We affirm. [1]   
FACTS
Miller was convicted of robbing James Holden (Holden) at gunpoint.Â  While on 
  his way to work, Holden stopped at a convenience store in Greenville to use 
  the phone.Â  A man Holden later identified as Miller asked him for directions 
  to the interstate.Â  After Holden gave Miller directions, Miller pointed a gun 
  at Holden and demanded money.Â  Holden surrendered $106, and Miller walked behind 
  the store, out of view.Â  Miller then drove by, and Holden followed him and recorded 
  his license plate number.Â  Several days later, Holden identified Miller as the 
  perpetrator from a photographic lineup.Â  Miller was indicted and convicted for 
  armed robbery.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Miller asserts two issues on appeal.Â  First, he argues the trial 
  court lacked subject matter jurisdiction due to an insufficient indictment.Â  
  Second, he contends the trial court erred in failing to give his proposed jury 
  instruction on eyewitness testimony.Â  
I.Â  Sufficiency of the Indictment
Millerâ€™s indictment states:

That BRUCE RANDALL MILLER did in Greenville County, on or about the 9th day 
  of December, 2001, while armed with a deadly weapon, to wit: handgun, take by 
  means of force or intimidation, goods or monies described as: U.S. currency 
  from the person or presence of James Holden.Â  This is in violation of Â§16-11-330 
  of the South Carolina Code of Laws (1976) as amended. 

A circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction if: (1) there has 
  been an indictment which sufficiently states the offense; (2) there has been 
  a waiver of the indictment; or (3) the charge is a lesser included charge of 
  the crime charged in the indictment.Â  Locke v. State, 341 S.C. 54, 533 
  S.E.2d 324 (2000).Â  An indictment is sufficient to convey jurisdiction if it 
  states the offense with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the 
  court to know what judgment to pronounce and the defendant to know what he is 
  called upon to answer.Â  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 495 S.E.2d 773 
  (1998).Â  
Miller complains the indictment is insufficient because it fails 
  â€œto allege intent of permanent deprivation or that the taking was done feloniously.â€Â  
  Our supreme court has held:Â  â€œThere is no requirement that an armed robbery 
  indictment contain an allegation of an intent to permanently deprive the owner 
  of the property.â€Â  Broom v. State, 351 S.C. 219, 221, 569 S.E.2d 336, 
  337 (2002).Â  The Broom court found that â€œthe intent to permanently deprive 
  is . . . implicit in the definition of armed robbery.â€Â  Id.Â  The court 
  defined armed robbery as â€œa robbery while armed with a deadly weapon or while 
  the robber alleges, by actions or words, that he is armed with a deadly weapon 
  which a person during the commission of the robbery reasonably believes to be 
  a deadly weapon.â€Â  Id. at 220-21, 569 S.E.2d at 337 (citing S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 16-11-330(A) (Supp. 2001)).Â Â  The definition does not include the word 
  â€œfeloniouslyâ€; therefore, feloniously is not required in the indictment.Â  Cf. 
  Joseph v. State, 351 S.C. 551, 571 S.E.2d 280 (2002) (finding indictment 
  for murder sufficient where it set forth the time, place, and manner of the 
  crime, but did not include the defendant â€œâ€˜feloniouslyâ€™ and â€˜wilfullyâ€™ committed 
  the murderâ€™â€ and holding â€œthe word â€˜feloniouslyâ€™ is encompassed in the word 
  â€˜murderâ€™ because murder is a felony.â€). 
 Locke lends further support to the Stateâ€™s position that the 
  indictment does not need to include â€œfeloniouslyâ€ or â€œintent of permanent deprivation.â€Â  
  In Locke, the supreme court found that â€œthe indictment alleges the substance 
  of asportation when it reads, â€˜taking of goods and/or monies from the person 
  or presence of.â€™â€Â  341 S.C. at 56, 533 S.E.2d at 325.Â  Millerâ€™s indictment alleged 
  that he did â€œtake by means of force or intimidation, goods or monies 
  described as: U.S. currency from the person or presence of James Holden.â€Â  
  (Emphasis added).Â  Thus, the language of Millerâ€™s indictment was approved by 
  the court in Locke.Â  
II.Â  Proposed Jury Charge
Miller argues the trial court erred in failing to charge his requested instruction 
  on the accuracy of eyewitness identification.Â  The trial judge rejected Millerâ€™s 
  charge and instead gave the following charge:

The state alleges that the defendant, Mr. Miller, is the perpetrator of the 
  alleged crime charged.Â  The State has the burden of proving identity beyond 
  a reasonable doubt.Â  Identification testimony is an expression of belief or 
  impression by a witness.Â  You may consider the opportunity a witness had to 
  observe the alleged offender at the time of the alleged offense and thereafter 
  make an identification.Â  It is for you to determine the accuracy of the identification 
  as given by the witness.Â  
You may consider the credibility of the identification witness as you do any 
  other witness.Â  You may consider his or her truthfulness as well as the capacity, 
  opportunity, and circumstances of the observation of the matters about which 
  he or she testified.Â  Remember the State has the burden of proving identity 
  beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Therefore, if you find that a crime has been committed 
  as alleged, but you are not convinced, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the defendant 
  was the person who committed the crime, you must find the defendant not guilty.Â  


 The jury charge Miller proposed was a Telfaire charge (United 
  States v. Telfaire, 469 F.2d 522 (D.C. Cir 1972)).Â  Contrary to Millerâ€™s 
  assertion that South Carolina has recognized the Telfaire charge as a 
  â€œmodel instruction,â€ our courts have rejected the Telfaire charge as 
  violative of the Constitution of South Carolina.Â  See State v. Patterson, 
  337 S.C. 215, 234, 522 S.E.2d 845, 855 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding the Telfaire 
  charge â€œis essentially a charge on the facts which is contrary to our constitutional 
  prohibition [S.C. Const. Art. V, Â§ 21] against charges to the juries on the 
  factsâ€); see also State v. Robinson, 274 S.C. 198, 262 
  S.E.2d 729 (1980) (upholding trial courtâ€™s decision to decline the Telfaire 
  charge). 
A jury instruction is sufficient if, when considered as a whole, it covers 
  the law applicable to the case.Â  State v. Burton, 302 S.C. 494, 397 S.E.2d 
  90 (1990).Â  Here, the judgeâ€™s charge was sufficient.Â  As in State v. Motes, 
  264 S.C. 317, 326, 215 S.E.2d 190, 194 (1975), it â€œadequately focused the attention 
  of the jury on the necessity for a finding that the testimony identified defendant 
  as the offender beyond a reasonable doubt.â€Â  Id.Â  Moreover, at trial, 
  Holden was asked about his identification of Miller:

  
    
    
      
        Q. 
         Was there any doubts as to your selection?
      
      
        A.
         Not a doubt in the
          world.
      
    
    
  

Given Holdenâ€™s degree of certainty, there appears very little likelihood of 
  mistaken identification.Â  See State v. Jones, 344 S.C. 48, 60, 
  543 S.E.2d 541, 547 (2001).Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the conviction 
  and sentence of Miller are
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
