PER CURIAM: Bucky Mitchell appeals the lower courtâ€™s acceptance of his 
  guilty plea.Â  We dismiss. [1] Â  

FACTS
In December 2000, a Richland County grand jury indicted Bucky Mitchell on four 
  counts: two kidnapping charges and two charges of criminal sexual conduct with 
  a minor in the second degree.Â  Prior to opening statements at trial, Mitchell 
  entered a negotiated plea of guilty but mentally ill on a single count of criminal 
  sexual conduct with a minor and the State dismissed the other charges.Â  The 
  lower court accepted Mitchellâ€™s plea and sentenced him to seven years.Â  This 
  appeal follows.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mitchell argues that his guilty plea failed to comply with Boykin v. Alabama, 
  395 U.S. 238 (1969), which requires guilty pleas be voluntarily and intelligently 
  made.Â  We find that Mitchell failed to properly preserve the issue below.Â  Mitchell 
  made no objection at the plea proceeding.Â  Failure of a defendant to assert 
  that his guilty plea was not knowing and intelligent precludes consideration 
  of the issue on appeal.Â  State v. McKinney, 278 S.C. 107, 108, 292 S.E.2d 
  598, 599 (1982).Â  The proper avenue in which to challenge a guilty plea that 
  was not objected to at the time of its entry is through post-conviction relief.Â  
  In re Antonio H., 324 S.C. 120, 477 S.E.2d 713 (1996).Â  
DISMISSED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Patricia Brenda Kiser, Appellant,
v.
Charleston Lodge No. 242, Charleston South Carolina Of The Benevolent 
        and Protective Order of Elks, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-630
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chalmers Carey Johnson, 
  of Charleston, for Appellant.
Matthew H. Henrikson and Mary H. Abel, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Patricia Brenda Kiser appeals from the trial courtâ€™s grant 
  of summary judgment to the Charleston Lodge No. 242 of the Benevolent and Protective 
  Order of the Elks (the Elks) on her breach of contract claim.Â  We affirm.1Â  

FACTS
The Elks is a private club, which offers community and social events to its 
  members and guests.Â  After the Elks changed its policy and began to allow women 
  into its membership, several members of the Elks encouraged Kiser to apply for 
  membership.Â  The application process for the Elks involves a sponsor member 
  proposing the applicant and ensuring the applicant completes the application.Â  
  The sponsoring member gives the application to the lodge secretary who reads 
  it before the lodge at a regular session.Â  The investigating committee then 
  reviews the application, conducts an investigation of the applicant, and interviews 
  the applicant.Â  After completing this process, the investigating committee returns 
  the application to the secretary with a favorable or unfavorable report.Â  If 
  the report is favorable, the secretary arranges for the publication of the applicantâ€™s 
  name in the monthly newsletter with the date on which the applicant is to be 
  voted on for membership.Â  At the membership vote, the applicant must receive 
  no less than two-thirds â€œyesâ€ votes.Â  If the applicant fails to receive the 
  required votes, the applicantâ€™s initiation fee and dues are returned and the 
  applicant must wait six months before being voted on again.Â  
Kiser completed the application process and received a favorable report from 
  the investigating committee.Â  However, she failed to receive the required two-thirds 
  vote to be accepted for membership.Â  After a request from the secretary of the 
  Elks, the Grand Exalted Ruler issued an executive order waiving the six-month 
  waiting period, allowing Kiser and another applicant to be voted on again.Â  
  At the second balloting, Kiser again did not receive the required votes for 
  membership.Â  
In March of 2002, Kiser filed a breach of contract action 
  in circuit court claiming the Elks made an offer of membership to her by stating 
  the steps for application and membership.Â  Kiser claimed she accepted this offer 
  by complying with the required steps in the application process.Â  She asserted 
  the Elks breached this contract by denying her membership based on her sex.Â  
  The Elks answered, denying the existence of a contract.Â  
Kiser served discovery requests to the Elks on June 7, 2002.Â  
  On June 19, the Elks filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  On June 28, the Elksâ€™ 
  attorney requested a thirty-day extension for serving discovery responses, explaining 
  he had just received the requests, which had been mailed to his old firmâ€™s address.Â  
  Kiser granted the request.Â  The Elks served its responses to Kiserâ€™s discovery 
  requests, which contained objections to some requests, on September 10, 2002.Â  
  On September 20, the court issued an order denying the Elksâ€™ motion for summary 
  judgment based on Kiserâ€™s request for additional time to obtain discovery.Â  
  The court granted leave for the Elks to renew its motion for summary judgment. 
  Â On March 31, 2003, Kiser filed a motion to compel discovery of some of her 
  interrogatories and requests for production.Â  Subsequently, the Elks filed a 
  motion for summary judgment.Â  
Both motions were heard at the same hearing.Â  The court first 
  considered Kiserâ€™s motion to compel.Â  The court denied her requests to obtain 
  the names of other women who had applied for membership and not received the 
  requisite number of votes and the names of members who either voted on Kiser 
  or were members when Kiser came up for vote.Â  The court, however, did require 
  the Elks to produce its membership list, which the Elks had previously offered 
  to Kiser.Â  The court then considered the Elksâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  
  After hearing the partiesâ€™ arguments, the court granted the Elksâ€™ motion for 
  summary judgment based on a finding that as a matter of law no contract existed 
  between the parties.Â  The courtâ€™s written order only addressed the grant of 
  summary judgment.Â  It did not mention the motion to compel.Â  This appeal followed. 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue as to any material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Osborne 
  v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  The evidence and all 
  reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to 
  the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  â€œIt is well established that summary judgment 
  should be granted â€˜. . . in cases in which plain, palpable and indisputable 
  facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.â€™â€Â  Anders v. S.C. Farm 
  Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 371, 373, 415 S.E.2d 406, 407 (Ct. App. 1992) 
  (quoting Main v. Corley, 281 S.C. 525, 526, 316 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1984)); 
  see Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000) 
  (stating where a verdict is not reasonably possible under the facts presented, 
  summary judgment is proper).
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.                 
Prematurity of motion for summary judgment 
   
Kiser argues that she did not have a full and fair 
  opportunity to complete discovery because she was denied the opportunity to 
  obtain the membership list she requested, and that was required pursuant, to 
  her motion to compel. Â We disagree.
Summary judgment is a drastic remedy and must not be 
  granted until the opposing party has had a full and fair opportunity to complete 
  discovery.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 112, 410 
  S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991).Â  However, the nonmoving party must demonstrate the likelihood 
  that further discovery will uncover additional relevant evidence and that the 
  party is â€œnot merely engaged in a â€˜fishing expedition.â€™â€Â  Id.Â  at 112, 
  410 S.E.2d at 544.Â  See Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 71, 580 
  S.E.2d 433, 439-40 (2003) (rejecting the plaintiffsâ€™ argument that summary judgment 
  was premature because they did not have a full and fair opportunity for discovery 
  by holding further discovery was unlikely to create any genuine issue of material 
  fact); Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 128-29, 542 
  S.E.2d 736, 743 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating it was not error to grant summary judgment 
  because no further discovery would have contributed to the resolution of the 
  case).


We thus must determine whether the additional evidence 
  sought by Kiser was relevant to her breach of contract claim.Â  Kiser argues 
  on appeal that having the list of names of the current members was relevant 
  in proving her claim, but she fails to explain in her brief how the membership 
  list is relevant to proving she had a contract with the Elks or that it was 
  breached.Â  
To establish a contract, Kiser must prove three elements:Â  
  an offer, acceptance, and consideration.Â  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of S.C., 
  354 S.C. 397, 405, 581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003).Â  In order to have a valid and 
  enforceable contract, there must be a meeting of the minds between the parties 
  with regard to all essential and material terms of the agreement.Â  Player 
  v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 105, 382 S.E.2d 891, 893 (1989).Â  â€œThe â€˜meeting 
  of mindsâ€™ required to make a contract is not based on secret purpose or intention 
  on the part of one of the parties, stored away in his mind and not brought to 
  the attention of the other party, but must be based on purpose and intention 
  which has been made known or which, from all the circumstances, should be known.â€Â  
  Id.Â  at 105, 382 S.E.2d at 894.Â  Without the actual agreement of the 
  parties, there is no contract, express or implied.Â  Stanley Smith & Sons 
  v. Limestone College, 283 S.C. 430, 433, 322 S.E.2d 474, 477 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  

As the trial court noted, Kiser admitted she was only 
  invited to apply for membership and undergo the voting process.Â  She acknowledged 
  that she knew when she went through the process there was a chance she would 
  be rejected by the voting membership and that no one guaranteed that simply 
  by applying she would become a member.Â  The trial court held, â€œThe [Elks] never 
  expressly or impliedly manifested an assent to the most essential and material 
  term, i.e., [Kiserâ€™s] Lodge membership as the result of a membership vote. . 
  . . [N]either the [Elksâ€™] words nor the application circumstances indicated 
  [Kiser] and the [Elks] had the necessary â€˜meeting of the mindsâ€™ to form a contract.â€Â Â  

In our examination, the record does not indicate, and 
  Kiser has not provided evidence to suggest otherwise, that the membership list 
  is relevant to establish the existence of an offer, acceptance, or consideration 
  or that a â€œmeeting of the mindsâ€ occurred.Â  When a party fails to establish 
  the existence of an element essential to the partyâ€™s case upon which that party 
  will bear the burden of proof at trial, â€œthere can be â€˜no genuine issue as to 
  any material factâ€™ since a complete failure of proof concerning an essential 
  element of the nonmoving partyâ€™s case necessarily renders all other facts immaterial.â€Â  
  Baughman, 306 S.C. at 116, 410 S.E.2d at 546.Â  Thus, as Kiser has failed 
  to demonstrate that further discovery will likely uncover additional evidence 
  relevant to her breach of contract claim, we find the trial court did not err 
  in granting the Elksâ€™ summary judgment. 
  II.              
Grant of summary judgment following the grant of a motion to compel 
   
Kiser argues that the trial court erred in granting 
  the Elksâ€™ motion for summary judgment immediately after granting Kiserâ€™s motion 
  to compel.Â  Although at the hearing Kiser argued the motion was not ripe because 
  adequate discovery had not been completed, she did not specifically argue the 
  trial court should not grant the motion because it had just granted her the 
  right to further discovery.Â  She furthermore failed to raise this argument in 
  a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion when the order granting summary judgment did not even 
  address the motion to compel.Â  Accordingly, we find this argument not preserved 
  for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 
  S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for 
  the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the 
  trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Noisette v. Ismail, 
  304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding issue was not preserved 
  for appellate review where the trial judge did not explicitly rule on the appellantâ€™s 
  argument and the appellant made no Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment).Â  

CONCLUSION
Based on our findings, the trial court did 
  not err in granting summary judgment to the Elks on Kiserâ€™s breach of contract 
  claim. Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â 
  



 
  1We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPNION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Lawrence M. Ridgeway, Respondent,
v.
The Litchfield Company of South Carolina Limited Partnership and The 
        Litchfield Company Inc., Defendants, Of whom The Litchfield Company of 
        South Carolina Limited Partnership is the, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-631
Heard October 12, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph C. Wilson, IV, of Charleston, for Appellant.
SaulÂ  Gliserman, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:  The Litchfield Company of South Carolina Limited 
  Partnership (Litchfield) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s denial of its motion to 
  compel arbitration.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The relevant facts are not in dispute.Â  On September 18, 1999, Lawrence 
  M. Ridgeway, as grantee, entered into a purchase agreement with Heritage-Litchfield, 
  Inc., as grantor, to purchase condominium unit 20-101 in the Avian Forest development 
  in Georgetown. [1] Â  The purchase agreement contained 
  an arbitration clause, which provided as follows:

  
    
ARBITRATIONÂ  In the event that a dispute or claim shall arise with respect 
  to any of the terms or provisions of this Master Deed, or a dispute between 
  the Grantor or any contractors employed by the Grantor, and any one or 
  more Unit Owners, such claims to include but not be limited to claims for 
  negligent or improper construction, failure to meet specifications, and other 
  claims related to structural improvements, all disputes or claims shall 
  be resolved by Binding Arbitration pursuant to Title 15, Chapter 48 (Uniform 
  Arbitration Act) of the Code of Laws of South Carolina.Â  All resulting awards 
  and determinations made by the arbitrators pursuant to the provisions of this 
  section shall be conclusively binding upon all parties hereto and judgment may 
  be rendered thereon.
    
  

(Emphasis added.)Â  Litchfield was involved with the sale of the unit 
  solely as the real estate broker for Heritage-Litchfield and marketing company 
  for the Avian Forest development.Â  
Shortly after purchasing unit 20-101, Ridgeway discovered 
  that the unit was infested with toxic mold.Â  Ridgeway asserted the mold rendered 
  the unit uninhabitable.Â  Ridgeway further asserted that the development lacked 
  several promised amenities and the grounds contained several abandoned or derelict 
  buildings.Â  According to Ridgeway, the mold infestation and other deficiencies 
  have rendered the unit â€œwithout meaningful market value.â€ 
Ridgeway 
  instituted an action against Litchfield alleging that he would not have purchased 
  the Avian Forest unit but for the tortious conduct of Litchfield, which caused 
  Ridgeway to believe that Litchfield, as opposed to Heritage-Litchfield, was 
  the developer of the Avian Forest project.Â  Ridgeway asserted causes of action 
  arising from the marketing and promotion of Avian Forest, including unfair trade 
  practices, negligent misrepresentation, constructive fraud, fraud, promissory 
  estoppel, and civil conspiracy.Â  Litchfield filed an answer and motion to compel 
  arbitration based upon the arbitration clause in the purchase agreement entered 
  into by Heritage-Litchfield and Ridgeway.Â  Litchfield concedes that it was neither 
  a party nor a signatory to the purchase agreement or arbitration clause. [2] Â  The circuit court denied Litchfieldâ€™s 
  motion to compel arbitration.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 â€œWhether a claim is subject to arbitration is an issue for judicial 
  determination, unless the parties have agreed otherwise.â€Â  Vestry and Church 
  Wardens of Holy Cross v. Orkin Exterminating Co., 356 S.C. 202, 207, 588 
  S.E.2d 136, 138 (Ct. App. 2003) (citation omitted).Â  In deciding whether the 
  parties have agreed to submit a particular grievance to arbitration, the court 
  should not rule on the merits of the underlying claims.Â  Zabinski v. Bright 
  Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â  â€œA motion 
  to compel arbitration made pursuant to an arbitration clause in a written contract 
  should only be denied where the clause is not susceptible to any interpretation 
  which would cover the asserted dispute.â€Â  Id.
 â€œDeterminations of arbitrability are subject to de novo review.â€Â  
  Vestry and Church Wardens of Holy Cross, 356 S.C. at 207, 588 S.E.2d 
  at 138.Â  However, the factual findings of the trial court will be overruled 
  only if there is no evidence reasonably supporting them.Â  Deloitte & 
  Touche, LLP v. Unisys Corp., 358 S.C. 179, 182, 594 S.E.2d 523, 525 (Ct. 
  App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
In the 
  case before us, we are not asked to determine whether the arbitration clause 
  would be valid and enforceable as between Ridgeway and Heritage-Litchfield because 
  Heritage-Litchfield does not seek arbitration.Â  Instead, Litchfield, a non-signatory 
  to the arbitration clause, seeks to compel arbitration against Ridgeway.Â  
Arbitration is contractual by nature.Â  See Zabinski v. Bright 
  Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001); Tritech 
  Elec., Inc. v. Frank M. Hall & Co., 343 S.C. 396, 399, 540 S.E.2d 864, 
  865 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Therefore, a party cannot be required to submit to arbitration 
  any dispute that he has not agreed to arbitrate.Â  See United Steelworkers 
  of Am. v. Warrior & Gulf Navigation Co., 363 U.S. 574, 582 (1960); Zabinski, 
  346 S.C. at 580, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  There is strong state and federal public 
  policy favoring arbitration agreements; however, such agreements must not be 
  so broadly construed as to encompass claims and parties that were not intended 
  by the original contract.Â  See Mitsubishi Motors Corp. v. Soler Chrysler-Plymouth, 
  Inc., 473 U.S. 614, 626 (1985); Towles v. United Healthcare Corp., 
  338 S.C. 29, 37, 524 S.E.2d 839, 844 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, â€œarbitration 
  rests on the agreement of the parties, and the range of issues that can be arbitrated 
  is restricted by the terms of the agreement.â€Â  Zabinksi, 346 S.C. at 
  596-597, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  â€œIn determining whether an agreement to arbitrate 
  exists, â€˜the court should apply ordinary state-law principles that govern the 
  formation of contracts.â€™â€Â  Towles, 338 S.C. at 37, 524 S.E.2d at 844 
  (citation omitted).Â  
Litchfield argues the trial judge erred in refusing to compel arbitration 
  because, despite its lack of contractual relationship with Ridgeway, it can 
  compel arbitration: (1) as a â€œcontractorâ€ under the arbitration clause of the 
  purchase agreement, and (2) as an agent of Heritage-Litchfield.Â  We disagree.Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â 
  I.                 
Litchfield is a not â€œcontractorâ€ as intended by the arbitration clause. 
   
The arbitration clause of the purchase agreement provides for arbitration 
  of disputes between â€œany contractors employed by the Grantor, and any one or 
  more Unit Owners, such claims to include but not be limited to claims for negligent 
  or improper construction, failure to meet specifications, and other claims related 
  to structural improvements.â€Â  Litchfield asserts that the term â€œcontractor,â€ 
  according to Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary (4th ed. 1979), is â€œstrictly applicable 
  to any person who enters into a contract, but is commonly reserved to designate 
  one who, for a fixed price, undertakes to procure the performance of works or 
  services on a large scale. . . .â€ [3] Â Â  Litchfield contends that it is a contractor 
  by definition and therefore entitled to compel Ridgeway to arbitrate its dispute.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

We agree with the trial court that the definition of contractor asserted 
  by Litchfield is correct in the broadest sense of the term, but that it is not 
  the definition intended by the parties in the arbitration clause.Â Â Â  â€œThe construction 
  of a clear and unambiguous contract is a question of law for the court.â€Â  Hawkins 
  v. Greenwood Dev. Corp.  328 S.C. 585, 592, 493 S.E.2d 875, 878 (Ct. 
  App. 1997) (citation omitted).Â  â€œWhether a contract is ambiguous is to be determined 
  from the entire contract and not from isolated portions of the contract.â€ Farr 
  v. Duke Power Co.  265 S.C. 356, 362, 218 S.E.2d 431, 433 (1975) 
  (citation omitted).Â  â€œCommon sense and good faith are the leading touchstones 
  of the inquiry.â€Â  Id. at 362, 218 S.E.2d at 434.
It is 
  clear, considering the purchase agreement as a whole, that the term â€œcontractorâ€ 
  found in the arbitration clause was intended to include only those parties to 
  a contract responsible for furnishing labor and materials for the construction 
  of Ridgewayâ€™s condominium unit.Â  The entire body of the purchase agreement concerned 
  only the sale of an Avian Forest condominium unit, and the agreement stated 
  that Heritage-Litchfield â€œshall cause the Property to be constructed substantially 
  in accordance with the Plan and Specifications previously reviewed by the purchaser 
  . . . .â€Â  The arbitration clause lists the types of disputes between Ridgeway 
  and contractors to include â€œbut not be limited to claims for negligent or improper 
  construction, failure to meet specifications, and other claims related to structural 
  improvements . . . .â€Â  The purchase agreement did not contemplate any other 
  type of contractor besides those responsible for furnishing labor and materials 
  for construction.Â  Therefore, Litchfield cannot enforce the arbitration clause 
  as a contractor because it did not furnish labor or materials for construction.Â  

  II.               
  Litchfield cannot compel arbitration solely as an agent of Heritage-Litchfield.
Litchfield 
  argues that under the principles of agency, a non-signatory may invoke an arbitration 
  clause as an agent of the signatory. South Carolina courts have yet to address 
  the issue of whether a non-signatory can invoke an arbitration clause solely 
  as an agent of the signatory.Â  
Litchfield cites South Carolina Public Service Authority v. Great 
  Western Coal, Inc., 312 S.C. 559, 437 S.E.2d 22 (1993) in support of the 
  proposition that South Carolina allows non-signatories to an arbitration agreement 
  to compel arbitration against a signatory.Â  In Great Western Coal, the 
  South Carolina Public Service Authority contracted with Great Western Coal, 
  including an agreement to arbitrate.Â  The Public Service Authority initiated 
  an action against Great Western Coal and its president, Clyde E. Goings, in 
  his individual capacity.Â  The court held Goings was entitled to demand arbitration 
  of the Public Service Authorityâ€™s claims even though he did not sign the arbitration 
  clause.Â  Great Western Coal relies on the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals 
  in Arnold v. Arnold Corp., 920 F.2d 1269 (6th Cir. 1990) for this proposition, 
  stating:Â Â  â€œ[A] party should not be allowed to avoid an arbitration agreement 
  by naming nonsignatory parties in his complaint, or signatory parties in 
  their individual capacity because this would nullify the rule requiring 
  arbitration.â€ Id. at 563, 437 S.E.2d at 24-25 (emphasis in original). 
  Thus, Great Western Coal permits only non-signatories who are alter egos 
  of a signatory to compel arbitration.Â  In this case, Litchfield cannot compel 
  arbitration because it is not an alter ego of the signatory, Heritage-Litchfield, 
  Inc.Â  
Moreover, the other jurisdictions that allow a non-signatory to compel 
  arbitration under the agency theory have done so only in instances where the 
  action against the agent is within the scope of the arbitration agreement as 
  contemplated by the signing parties.Â  See, e.g., Long v. Silver, 
  248 F.3d 309, 320-21 (4th Cir. 2001) (holding non-signatory could compel arbitration 
  because the claims against the non-signatory parent corporation fell within 
  the scope of the arbitration clause signed by the employee); Sunkist Soft 
  Drinks, Inc. v. Sunkist Growers, Inc., 10 F.3d 753, 758 (11th Cir. 1993) 
  (holding that because claims against the non-signatory were â€œintimately founded 
  in and intertwined withâ€ a contract containing an arbitration clause, signatory 
  was estopped from refusing to arbitrate those claims); J.J. Ryan & Sons, 
  Inc. v. Rhone Poulenc Textile, S.A., 863 F.2d 315, 320-21 (4th Cir. 1988) 
  (holding that â€œwhen allegations against a parent company and its subsidiary 
  are based on the same facts and are inherently inseparable, a court may refer 
  claims against the parent to arbitration even though the parent is not formally 
  a party to the arbitration agreementâ€); Norcom Elecs. Corp. v. CIM USA Inc., 
  104 F.Supp.2d 198, 203 (S.D.N.Y. 2000) (quoting Smith/Enron Cogeneration 
  Ltd. Pâ€™ship. v. Smith Cogeneration Int'l, Inc., 198 F.3d 88, 97-98 (2d Cir. 
  1999)) (â€œ[T]he U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and other circuits 
  â€˜have been willing to estop a signatory from avoiding arbitration with a nonsignatory 
  when the issues the nonsignatory is seeking to resolve in arbitration are intertwined 
  with the agreement that the estopped party has signed.â€™â€); First American 
  Title Ins. Corp. v. Silvernell,  744 So.2d 883, 887-88 (Ala. 1999) 
  (holding that non-signatory real estate agent had no right to compel arbitration 
  of purchasersâ€™ claim of conspiracy by agents because the arbitration clause 
  defined arbitrable matters as controversies between the insurer and the insured 
  purchaser, and the insurer was not part of the conspiracy).
In this case, the arbitration clause applies to disputes between Ridgeway 
  and contractors responsible for furnishing labor and materials for construction.Â  
  Thus, Ridgewayâ€™s claims for unfair trade practices, negligent misrepresentation, 
  constructive fraud, fraud, promissory estoppel, and civil conspiracy against 
  Litchfield would not fall within the scope of the arbitration clause.Â  Accordingly, 
  even if we were to apply an agency theory to allow a non-signatory to enforce 
  an arbitration clause, Litchfield would not be permitted to compel arbitration 
  because Ridgewayâ€™s causes of action do not fall within the scope of the arbitration 
  clause. The order of the circuit court refusing to compel arbitration is therefore
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Heritage-Litchfield has declared bankruptcy.Â  
    There is on-going separate litigation between Ridgeway and the Heritage-Litchfield 
    insurers.

 
   [2]  Subsequent to oral argument, the court received 
    correspondence from counsel for Ridgeway stating for the first time that an 
    agent of Litchfield was a signatory to the purchase agreement and therefore 
    the arbitration clause.Â  Contrarily, both parties asserted the exact opposite 
    in front of the trial judge and in their briefs on appealâ€“that Litchfield 
    was a non-signatory to the purchase agreement.Â  Despite the revelations of 
    counsel for Ridgeway following oral argument, we are bound by the record on 
    appeal.Â  Rule 210(a), SCACR.Â  Because the record on appeal conclusively determines 
    that Litchfield was a non-signatory to the purchase agreement and arbitration 
    clause for purposes of our review, we must treat Litchfield as such.Â  

 
   [3]  We note that this definition has been amended 
    to read â€œ1. A party to a contract. 2. More specif., one who contracts to do 
    work or provide supplies for another.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary (8th 
    ed. 2004).
  Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William E. Ford,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-632
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  December 15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Robert Douglas Robbins, of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  William Ford appeals from his 
  convictions for burglary and kidnapping, arguing the trial court erred in refusing 
  to grant a directed verdict because the State failed to present substantial 
  evidence beyond a reasonable doubt that he was guilty of the offenses.Â  We affirm. [1]  Â Â 
 FACTS 
  On January 30, 2002, at approximately 9:30 p.m. in 
    Knightsville, South Carolina, Ford and a friend, John Long, were riding in 
    a sport utility vehicle with the headlights off.Â  Long was driving the vehicle.Â  
    Deputy Randy Botten was traveling in the opposite direction when the vehicle 
    ran him off the road.Â  Botten turned his car around and activated his blue 
    lights to conduct a traffic stop.Â  The vehicle did not stop and instead increased 
    its speed to about 80 to 85 miles per hour.Â  Botten followed the vehicle until 
    it turned into a driveway on Central Avenue, near Orangeburg Road, and stopped 
    behind a shed.Â  Ford and Long jumped out of the vehicle and fled.Â  Area residents 
    found Long in a yard behind the Countryside Mobile Home Park and he was arrested.Â  
    Ford ran to Elaine Mizellâ€™s house on the corner of Central Avenue and Orangeburg 
    Road and stole her brown 1982 Toyota truck.Â  At 10:47 p.m., a trooper spotted 
    Ford driving Mizellâ€™s truck with the headlights off and traveling 85 miles 
    per hour in a 25 mile an hour zone.Â  
  At approximately 9:50 p.m., at 953 Orangeburg Road, 
    the home of David and Jennifer Stover, a man entered their house and carried 
    their daughter, Trinity, outside.Â  David thought the man was his wife, so 
    he went outside to see if she needed help carrying groceries into the house.Â  
    Once outside, David did not see his wifeâ€™s car, but did notice that the interior 
    light was on inside his Mustang.Â  David then heard Trinity screaming and saw 
    her with a white male.Â  The man tried to run, but fell over a picnic table 
    and dropped Trinity.Â  The man then ran towards the woods.Â  David called 911 
    and his brother-in-law, Donald Short.Â  
  As Deputy Joli Murray was responding to Davidâ€™s 911 
    call, a small brown pickup truck drove out of the Countryside Mobile Home 
    Park and nearly hit her car head-on.Â  She testified the truck was driving 
    erratically.Â  Short also drove to the Stoversâ€™ house after receiving the phone 
    call from David.Â  After leaving the Stoversâ€™ house, Short drove around looking 
    for a white male and noticed a white male standing next to a small dark Toyota 
    truck, looking toward the Stoversâ€™ residence.Â  When he turned in to ask the 
    man what he was doing, the man jumped into the truck.Â  Short backed into the 
    truck to stop it, but the truck managed to escape.Â  Short then followed the 
    truck, which did not have its headlights on and was traveling at about 80 
    miles per hour.Â  Trooper Curtis Burns also pursued the truck until it pulled 
    into a yard.Â  The driver exited the truck and ran into the woods.Â  Burns followed 
    the man, who was identified as Ford, and caught him in the woods.Â  The truck 
    belonged to Mizell.Â  While Ford was at the detention center he took a breathalyzer 
    test, which determined he was under the influence of alcohol at the time of 
    the collision. 
  The police found footprint impressions in the Mizellâ€™s 
    and the Stoversâ€™ yards, so officers took Fordâ€™s boots from him at the detention 
    center for evidence.Â  The impressions were consistent with the general design 
    of Fordâ€™s bootâ€™s outsole.Â  SLED Agent Steven Derrick testified Fordâ€™s boots 
    or another boot with the same combined class characteristics could have left 
    the impressions.Â  However, he also testified that Fordâ€™s boot is unique and 
    is sold by Sears exclusively.Â  Tim Stephenson, an expert in tracking, followed 
    the tracks from the picnic table near the Stoverâ€™s house to Mizellâ€™s backyard 
    where her truck was parked.Â  Stephenson testified the person took the path 
    of least resistance, which is consistent with a person fleeing from the police.Â  
    Stephenson also testified the tracks indicated that the person was unfamiliar 
    with the area and was in a hurry.Â  Additionally, he stated it takes about 
    7 minutes and 19 seconds to walk the distance from the picnic table to Mizellâ€™s 
    truck when walking at a rate of 2.9 miles an hour. 
  Ford moved for a directed verdict at the conclusion 
    of the Stateâ€™s case, arguing there was no eyewitness testimony or physical 
    evidence that placed Ford in the Stoversâ€™ house.Â  The court denied the motion, 
    finding there was sufficient evidence to be submitted to the jury.Â  The same 
    motion was renewed at the close of the evidence and again denied.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
     When reviewing a denial of a motion 
      for directed verdict, we use the same standard as the trial court by viewing 
      the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to 
      the non-moving party.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 299, 536 S.E.2d 
      408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œWhen a motion for a directed verdict is made 
      in a criminal case where the State relies exclusively on circumstantial 
      evidence, the lower court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence 
      of evidence, not with its weight.â€Â  State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 
      409, 535 S.E.2d 126, 127 (2000).Â  The trial judge must submit the case to 
      the jury if there is â€œany substantial evidence which reasonably tends to 
      prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt may be fairly and 
      logically deduced.â€Â  State v. Edwards, 298 S.C 272, 275, 379 S.E.2d 
      888, 889 (1989).Â  We will reverse the trial court only when there is no 
      evidence to support the ruling below.Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife 
      & Marine Resources Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 29, 491 S.E.2d 571, 573 (1997).Â Â Â Â  
    
     LAW/ANALYSIS
      Ford argues the trial court erred 
        in refusing to grant a directed verdict because the State failed to present 
        substantial evidence beyond a reasonable doubt that he was guilty of burglary 
        and kidnapping.Â  We disagree.
        The Stateâ€™s evidence against Ford was entirely 
          circumstantial. In such cases, in order to survive a motion for directed 
          verdict, our supreme court has held the State must present substantial 
          circumstantial evidence that â€œreasonably tends to prove the guilt of 
          the accused or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.â€Â  
          Edwards, 298 S.C at 275, 379 S.E.2d at 889.Â  
        The State presented substantial circumstantial 
          evidence that reasonably tended to prove Ford entered the Stoversâ€™ home 
          and abducted their child, and from which a jury could fairly and logically 
          deduce his guilt of those crimes.Â  An expert testified that tracks lead 
          from the site where Ford stole Mizellâ€™s Toyota to the picnic table where 
          he allegedly fell and dropped Trinity.Â  Another expert testified that 
          footprint impressions found by the Stoversâ€™ Mustang and behind Mizellâ€™s 
          house were consistent with Fordâ€™s boots.Â  Additionally, Short and a 
          trooper both saw a truck consistent with Mizellâ€™s stolen Toyota within 
          minutes of the time Ford allegedly walked from the Stoversâ€™ home to 
          Mizellâ€™s home and Ford was apprehended after he exited Mizellâ€™s truck.Â  
          See State v. Cherry, Op. No. 25902 (S.C.Sup.Ct. filed 
          Nov. 29, 2004) (Shearouse Adv.Sh. No. 46 at 29); cf. Mitchell, 
          341 S.C. at 409, 535 S.E.2d at 127.Â  The evidence supports the inference 
          that, while fleeing from the police and in need of transportation, Ford 
          opened the door to the Stoversâ€™ Mustang, as indicated by the lit interior 
          light, entered the Stoversâ€™ home looking for the keys and abducted Trinity 
          Stover.Â  Thus, there was ample evidence to warrant submitting the case 
          to the jury. 
        AFFIRMED. 
        ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

       
         [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
          to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Pearl C. Bryant,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William M. Conner,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-633
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Edward C. Boggs and William Walker, Jr., both of Lexington, for Appellant.
Jonathan M. Robinson and J. Kennedy DuBose, Jr., both of Camden, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Pearl C. 
  Bryant sued William M. Conner following an automobile accident in which Bryant 
  allegedly suffered injuries.Â  The jury found in favor of Connor.Â  Bryant appeals 
  arguing the trial judge erred in permitting Connerâ€™s biomechanical expert to 
  testify on medical causation and by failing to disqualify a juror.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This accident occurred while Bryant was 
  attempting a left turn into the Lexington Post Office.Â  The cause of the accident 
  was disputed at trial.Â  Bryant testified that she had come to a complete stop 
  before turning when Conner hit her â€œfull forceâ€ from behind.Â  Conner testified 
  that he was either stopped or in the process of stopping when Bryantâ€™s car cut 
  over in front of his car.Â  Conner stated that the front of his car caught the 
  back of Bryantâ€™s car causing a very slight impact.Â  
Immediately following the accident, Bryant 
  requested an ambulance because she claimed her heart was beating rapidly and 
  she was concerned about her history of heart problems.Â  Bryant also testified 
  that she had excruciating pain in her neck, shoulder, and back following the 
  accident.Â  An ambulance transported Bryant to the hospital where her cardiologist, 
  Dr. Saunders, examined her.Â  Dr. Saunders performed x-rays on Bryantâ€™s back 
  and prescribed medication for muscle spasms.Â  Bryantâ€™s back pain persisted over 
  the next several months, and Dr. Saunders referred her to an orthopedist.Â  The 
  orthopedist treated Bryant for approximately a month and a half before obtaining 
  her MRI results indicating she suffered from a sequestered disk.Â  Upon further 
  examination, an orthopedic surgeon diagnosed Bryant with a slippage of the vertebra 
  and a herniated disk.Â  After a course of steroid treatments, the orthopedic 
  surgeon performed two surgeries on Bryantâ€™s back to correct the slippage of 
  her vertebra.Â  
During the course 
  of the trial, over Bryantâ€™s objection, Conner presented a videotaped deposition 
  of Dr. Robert Cargill, a biomechanical engineer.Â  Dr. Cargill testified that 
  based on his analysis of the forces involved in the accident, no biomechanical 
  mechanism in the collision could have caused Bryantâ€™s back injury.Â  
Also, during the trial and just after 
  Connerâ€™s testimony, a juror notified the trial judge that although she did not 
  know Conner personally, she realized that Connerâ€™s stepdaughter and her children 
  were good friends.Â  The trial judge asked the juror whether she could be fair 
  and impartial.Â  The juror responded, â€œI feel like I can be fair.â€Â  The judge 
  decided not to set aside the juror.Â  Before the jury received the case for deliberation, 
  Bryantâ€™s counsel requested the trial judge reconsider his decision not to set 
  aside the juror, stating that â€œ[the juror] was obviously very emotional, very 
  upset, I believe she was crying and very uncomfortable, at least on the appearance, 
  from an appearance standpoint, about her continuing role as a juror in this 
  case and her ability to be impartial.â€Â  The judge recalled the juror and again 
  asked if she felt she could be fair and impartial.Â  The juror responded, â€œI 
  feel like I could be fair and impartial, but if somebody feels I canâ€™t be, then 
  ---.â€Â  The trial judge declined to disqualify the juror over the objection of 
  Bryantâ€™s counsel.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.                 
Admissibility of Biomechanical Expertâ€™s Testimony 
   
On appeal, Bryant does not argue 
  that the trial judge erred in permitting Connerâ€™s expert to testify as an expert 
  in biomechanical engineering. [1] Â  Rather, Bryant argues that the judge improperly permitted 
  the expert to testify on medical causation, which is outside the scope of his 
  expertise.Â  
The qualification of a witness as 
  an expert and the admissibility of expert testimony are matters left to the 
  sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on 
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion and prejudice to the opposing party.Â  See 
  Crawford v. Henderson, 356 S.C. 389, 404, 589 S.E.2d 204, 212 (Ct. 
  App. 2003); Nelson v. Taylor, 347 S.C. 210, 214, 553 S.E.2d 488, 490 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises from an error of law or a factual 
  conclusion that is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Lee v. Suess,
318 S.C. 283, 285, 457 S.E.2d 344, 345 (1995) (citation omitted).Â  
  â€œPermitting an expert witness to testify beyond the scope of his or her expertise 
  can constitute reversible error.â€Â  Pirayesh v. Pirayesh,  359 S.C. 
  284, 298, 596 S.E.2d 505, 513 (Ct. App. 2004). 
Conner presented the deposition testimony 
  of Dr. Cargill to the jury as an expert in the field of accident reconstruction 
  and biomechanical engineering.Â  Bryant objected, arguing Dr. Cargill testified 
  about medical causation within his deposition, which was outside the scope of 
  his expertise. The judge stated that â€œ[h]e will not be qualified to give any 
  opinions medically,â€ but noted that: â€œ[h]is opinions that they can accept have 
  to be within his field of expertise.Â  Thatâ€™s all.Â  But you canâ€™t keep him from 
  saying other things.Â  All I can do is give instructions to the jury.â€Â  Bryant 
  consented to the jury instruction stating: â€œIn a perfect world you would keep 
  him from saying that, but it is not a perfect world and I understand that.â€Â  
  Bryant made no further objection and Dr. Cargillâ€™s videotaped deposition was 
  played for the jury.Â  
Dr. Cargill 
  testified to the relative changes in velocity of Bryantâ€™s vehicle and the impact 
  this would have had on Bryantâ€™s body, including the load on her back.Â  This 
  testimony is consistent with the courtâ€™s definition of biomechanics.Â  In addition, 
  Dr. Cargill testified:

Then I compared the forces, 
  again, that I calculated or established for her lower back in this accident 
  and compared those to everyday forces in the low back.Â  And my conclusion was 
  that there was no biomechanical mechanism in this - - in this collision to produce 
  the sequestered disk pathology that she was diagnosed with in September of â€™96. 


Dr. Cargill further concluded 
  that this accident was a very minor collision and that the change in velocity 
  of the vehicles at the time of the collision was very small, at most three miles 
  per hour.Â  Dr. Cargill performed a crash test using a change in velocity of 
  3.5 miles per hour and determined the weight load exerted on the test dummyâ€™s 
  spine to be eighty-five pounds.Â  He opined that the load exerted in every day 
  activities such as bending over, lifting a trash can, or running involve heavier 
  spine loads than that exerted in the crash test.Â  
In charging the jury on expert testimony, the trial judge 
  stated, â€œto the extent that an expert offers an opinion outside his or her field 
  of expertise, you are not bound to accept it.â€Â  No objection was made to this 
  jury charge.Â  Generally, a curative instruction, such as the one given in this 
  case, is deemed to have cured any alleged error.Â  See State v. Kelsey, 
  331 S.C. 50, 70, 502 S.E.2d 63, 73 (1998) (explaining that instruction to disregard 
  inadmissible evidence will usually cure any error in its admission); State 
  v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 510, 476 S.E.2d 903, 911-12 (1996) (stating 
  that when a trial judge sustains a timely objection to testimony and gives the 
  jury a curative instruction to disregard testimony, any error is deemed to be 
  cured); State v. Patterson,  337 S.C. 215, 226, 522 S.E.2d 845, 
  850-51 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Jackson v. Speed,  
  326 S.C. 289, 307, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759 (1997).Â  Bryant was required to 
  contemporaneously object to the sufficiency of the jury instruction or move 
  for a mistrial to preserve the issue for review.Â  See State v. McCord, 349 
  S.C. 477, 486, 562 S.E.2d 689, 694 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Therefore, we decline 
  to address this issue on appeal.
  II.               
   Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Juror Disqualification
Bryant argues the trial judge improperly 
  failed to excuse a juror who informed the court during the trial that her children 
  were good friends with Connerâ€™s stepdaughter.Â  We find no error.
â€œThe determination whether a juror 
  is disqualified is within the discretion of the trial judge and will not be 
  reversed on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence.â€Â  State 
  v. Tucker, 320 S.C. 206, 211, 464 S.E.2d 105, 
  108 (1995). 
Section 14-7-1020 of the South Carolina 
  Code (Supp. 2003), explains the duties of a trial judge when a party makes a 
  motion asserting a juror has an interest in the cause of action or has the appearance 
  of bias or prejudice.Â  This section instructs the trial judge to disqualify 
  the juror if it appears that the juror is not indifferent.Â  Id.Â  A juror 
  who is acquainted with a party typically will not be excused when the failure 
  to disclose the relationship is inadvertent and there is an indication that 
  the juror has the ability to be fair and impartial.Â  See State v. 
  Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 448, 567 S.E.2d 244, 247-48 (2002) (holding removal 
  of a juror acquainted with the defendantâ€™s aunt was in error when the juror 
  was only casually acquainted with the jurorâ€™s aunt and the juror indicated to 
  the trial judge her ability to be fair and impartial); Wilson v. Childs, 
  315 S.C. 431, 437, 434 S.E.2d 286, 290 (Ct. App. 1993) (declining to find an 
  abuse of discretion when the trial judge refused to excuse jurors due to relationships 
  with either a party or the partyâ€™s attorney because the jurors voluntarily disclosed 
  the relationships and stated his or her ability to be impartial).Â  
In the case at bar, the juror voluntarily 
  disclosed her relationship to Conner and stated her ability to be impartial.Â  
  The juror notified the trial judge upon her discovery that she knew of Conner 
  and later clarified that she did not know Conner personally but knew his stepdaughter.Â  
  Despite the statement from Bryantâ€™s counsel that the juror appeared to be emotional 
  and crying, we could discern no independent indication that this juror was acting 
  in any such manner.Â  Moreover, on each occasion she was questioned, the juror 
  stated that she felt she could be fair and impartial.Â  Thus, we find the trial 
  judge did not abuse his discretion in declining to excuse the juror.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find Bryantâ€™s issue concerning 
  the admission of Connerâ€™s biomechanics expert testimony not to be preserved 
  for appeal.Â  Additionally, we find the trial judge did not err in declining 
  to excuse a juror based on her relationship with Connerâ€™s stepdaughter.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.Â  

 
   
    [1]  The trial judge did not make any specific finding qualifying Connerâ€™s 
    witness as an expert in biomechanical engineering or accident reconstruction.Â Â  
    However, Bryant conceded that the witness was a biomechanical engineer expert.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Chart House, Inc., a Delaware Corporation,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Palmetto Bay Club Ownersâ€™ Association, Inc., a/k/a Palmetto Bay Club
HPR; Palmetto Bay Horizontal Property Regime; Cross Island Associates, LLC; W.G.
Shuckers, Inc.; Brighton Bay Associates, LP; and the Yacht Club 
        of Hilton Head Island,        Defendants,
of whom Palmetto Bay Club Ownersâ€™ Association, a/k/a Palmetto Bay Club 
        HPR is        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Gerald C. Smoak, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-634
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  15, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Otto W. Ferrene, of Hilton Head, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Chart House, Inc., 
  appeals an order of the circuit court granting summary judgment to Palmetto 
  Bay Club Ownersâ€™ Association, a/k/a Palmetto Bay Club HPR (â€œPalmetto Bay Clubâ€) 
  and dismissing Palmetto Bay Club from the case.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On November 1, 1978, CHE, Inc., entered 
  into a twenty-five year ground lease for the Chart House Restaurant property 
  at Palmetto Bay Marina on Hilton Head Island.Â  The Appellant, Chart House, Inc., 
  is CHEâ€™s successor in interest.Â  Palmetto Bay Marina, a partnership entity, 
  was the lessor of the property at that time.Â  The ground lease granted a leasehold 
  interest in the Chart House property, â€œtogether with all present and future 
  improvements, Lessorâ€™s easements, rights of way, servitudes and appurtenances 
  in adjoining and adjacent land . . . .â€Â  This lease was never recorded.Â  
Prior to 1982, Palmetto Bay Marina owned 
  the entire marina area.Â  Palmetto Bay Marina split into two separate partnerships 
  known as Marina Development Associates and Palmetto Bay Associates.Â  On October 
  5, 1982, Palmetto Bay Marina conveyed a portion of the real property adjacent 
  to the Chart House tract, including the parcel now owned by Palmetto Bay Club, 
  to Marina Development.Â  Palmetto Bay Marina assigned the parcel leased to Chart 
  House to Palmetto Bay Associates.Â  
On October 8, 1982, Marina Development 
  and Palmetto Bay Associates granted each other, by means of a cross easement 
  agreement, reciprocal easements for ingress, egress, and parking in the area 
  between the two properties.Â  This easement was to run with the title to the 
  Chart House property.Â  Chart House joined in the agreement â€œfor the sole purpose 
  of consenting to the easements, rights and privileges granted pursuant [to the 
  agreement] to the extent such easements, rights and privileges affect[ed] the 
  Chart House property.â€Â  This document was subsequently recorded.Â  
On the same date, Chart House entered 
  into a â€œFirst Amendment and Modificationâ€ agreement (â€œAmended Agreementâ€) with 
  Palmetto Bay Associates, its new lessor.Â  The Amended Agreement referenced both 
  the ground lease and the cross easement agreement, and purported to â€œamend and 
  modifyâ€ the ground lease.Â  The parties also executed and recorded a â€œMemorandum 
  of Lease,â€ which referenced the original ground lease.Â  The Amended Agreement 
  substituted Palmetto Bay Associates for Palmetto Bay Marina as lessor.Â  In addition, 
  the Amended Agreement contained a section entitled â€œSubstitution of Property,â€ 
  which described the leased premises,Â  substituting â€œExhibit Aâ€ of the Amended 
  Agreement for â€œExhibit Aâ€ of the ground lease.Â  This section also contained 
  a release clause providing that â€œCHE hereby acknowledges and agrees that it 
  shall from and after the date hereof have no rights whatsoever in and to any 
  real property under the Lease except for the Property described in the attached 
  Exhibit â€œA.â€Â  
At issue is the scope of the effect of 
  the release clause.Â  Chart House contends, and Palmetto Bay Club does not deny, 
  that the substitution of property was necessary to conform the ground leaseâ€™s 
  description of the premises to the redrawn property lines as a result of the 
  conveyance from Palmetto Bay Marina to Marina Development.Â  Therefore, Chart 
  House argues that the above-referenced language was intended only as a release 
  of all claims of interest to the real property under the ground lease.Â  Palmetto 
  Bay Clubâ€™s contention is that this language modified not only the ground lease, 
  but the cross easement agreement as well, so as to divest Chart House of any 
  interest in the ingress/egress and parking easement over the Marina Development 
  property.
On March 28, 2001, Chart House filed 
  suit naming several defendants, including Palmetto Bay Club.Â  The complaint 
  alleged causes of action for (1) nuisance, (2) breach of covenants, and (3) 
  trespass based on Chart Houseâ€™s rights under both the ground lease, as modified 
  by the Amended Agreement, and the cross easement agreement.Â  The causes of action 
  for nuisance and trespass dealt with parking and named all the defendants.Â  
  However, the cause of action for breach of covenant not to compete named only 
  Cross Island Associates, LLC, and its lessee, W.G. Shuckers, Inc., and alleged 
  a breach of the covenant not to compete between Chart House and Palmetto Bay 
  Marina contained in the ground lease, which prohibited Palmetto Bay Marina or 
  its successors from engaging in the restaurant business.Â  
Both Cross Island and 
  Palmetto Bay Club subsequently moved for partial summary judgment on five nearly 
  identical grounds, all of which went to the enforceability of the ground lease.Â  
  Palmetto Bay Clubâ€™s motion also contained a sixth ground, as follows: â€œThat 
  a finding that any of the above are decided in favor of the movant, result [sic] 
  in an order dismissing the movant from the first, second and third causes of 
  action.â€Â  Both motions were argued together at Palmetto Bay Clubâ€™s request.Â  
  At the hearing, counsel for Cross Island specified that its motion was directed 
  solely at the covenant not to compete contained in the ground lease and the 
  effect of the Amended Agreement on the lease.Â  The trial court granted summary 
  judgment to both Cross Island and Palmetto Bay Club on the breach of the covenant 
  not to compete claim.Â  The court also dismissed both defendants from the action, 
  holding that the release language in the Amended Agreement quoted above operated 
  to divest Chart House of any interest in any property other than its leasehold.Â  

Chart House filed a 
  timely motion to reconsider, which was denied by Judge Gregory. [1] Â  Chart House appealed from the 
  order granting summary judgment to Palmetto Bay Club.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate 
  when it is clear there is no genuine issue of material fact and the conclusions 
  and inferences to be drawn from the facts are undisputed.â€Â  McClanahan v. 
  Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 437, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002) (citation 
  omitted).Â  Additionally, in ruling on a motion for summary judgment, a reviewing 
  court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  
  Id. at 438, 567 S.E.2d at 242.Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy.Â  
  Therefore, it â€œshould be cautiously invoked so that a litigant will not be improperly 
  deprived of trial on disputed factual issues.â€Â  Cunningham ex rel. Grice 
  v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 491, 575 S.E.2d 549, 552 (2003) (citation 
  omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
 Chart House argues that the trial court 
  violated its due process rights in granting summary judgment to Palmetto Bay 
  Club based on grounds not pled in its motion.Â  We agree.
â€œIt is an error of law for a 
  court to decide a case on a ground not before it.â€Â  Griffin v. Capital Cash, 
  310 S.C. 288, 294, 423 S.E.2d 143, 147 (Ct. App. 1992) (citation omitted).Â  
  â€œDue process requires that a litigant be placed on notice of the issues which 
  the court is to consider.â€Â  Bass v. Bass, 272 S.C. 177, 180, 249 S.E.2d 
  905, 906 (1978).Â  â€œOne of the basic purposes of a notice of motion is to apprise 
  the opposing party of the relief sought and the grounds therefore.â€Â  Turbeville 
  v. Floyd, 288 S.C. 171, 174, 341 S.E.2d 651, 652 (Ct. App. 1986) (quoting 
  Skinner v. Skinner, 257 S.C. 544, 549, 186 S.E.2d 523, 526 (1972)).Â  
  Thus, a court ordinarily may not grant relief beyond the scope of the notice.Â  
  Id.Â  A limited exception to this rule exists when a ground not included 
  in the notice of the motion is nevertheless fully argued before the court without 
  objection.Â  See Salvo v. Hewitt, Coleman & Assocs., 274 S.C. 
  34, 39, 260 S.E.2d 708, 711 (1979).
In the instant case, Palmetto 
  Bay Club moved for summary judgment on grounds substantially similar to those 
  in Cross Islandâ€™s motion, and requested that the motions be argued together.Â  
  At the beginning of the hearing, Cross Island made it very clear that its argument 
  was limited to the breach of covenant issue in Chart Houseâ€™s second cause of 
  action.Â  Neither in the notice of motion nor during the hearing did Palmetto 
  Bay Club apprise Chart House that it was arguing the parking easement issue.Â  
  All of the grounds listed in the notice of motion went to the enforceability 
  of the ground lease.Â  Palmetto Bay Club did include an averment in its notice 
  requesting that a finding in its favor result in its release on all three causes 
  of action.Â  However, this vague request did not in any way place Chart House 
  on notice of its theory that one provision in the amended lease agreement effectively 
  nullified a separate agreement Chart House executed that same day with different 
  parties.Â  In other words, although Palmetto Bay Clubâ€™s notice of motion was 
  sufficient to apprise Chart House of the â€œrelief sought,â€ it failed to sufficiently 
  allege the â€œgrounds therefore.â€Â  See Turbeville, 288 S.C. at 174, 
  341 S.E.2d at 652.Â  
Because summary judgment was granted 
  on grounds that were not included in the motion and were not fully argued at 
  the hearing, we hold that the trial court erred in granting summary judgment 
  and dismissing Palmetto Bay Club from the case.Â  Accordingly, the order of the 
  trial court is 
 REVERSED and REMANDED.  [2] 
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  The trial judge, Judge Gerald C. Smoak, Sr., retired 
    subsequent to the trial and was replaced by Judge Jackson V. Gregory.Â  

 
   
    [2]  We decline to address Chart Houseâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.Â  
    See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 
    598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (finding that an appellate court need 
    not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Murphy L. Rivers,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Daniel  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-636
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 16, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan 
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  In this appeal, we must decide 
  whether the circuit court erred in denying the defendantâ€™s motion for a mistrial 
  due to alleged juror misconduct.Â  We find no abuse of discretion and therefore 
  affirm.
FACTS
Murphy Rivers was indicted for assault with intent 
  to kill and tried before a jury.Â  The trial continued over the course of two 
  days.Â  On the morning of the second day, defense counsel raised a concern about 
  possible juror misconduct that allegedly occurred during the previous dayâ€™s 
  proceedings.Â  The following colloquy took place outside the presence of the 
  jury:

DEFENSE COUNSEL: Your Honor, 
  it came to my attention on [sic] yesterday after the close of the testimony 
  that a member of the jury had been sleeping throughout a substantial part of 
  the trial, and for that reason we would move for a mistrial.
THE COURT: I would deny that. 
  It is a little late to bring it to the Courtâ€™s attention.
DEFENSE COUNSEL: It wasnâ€™t until 
  after the jury had left the Court yesterday that people who were in the Courtroom 
  advised us of that.
THE COURT: Bring in the jury.Â  


Rivers moved for a mistrial, which was denied.Â  
  The issue of the allegedly sleeping juror was not raised to or addressed by 
  the circuit judge any further.Â  At the conclusion of the trial, the jury found 
  Rivers guilty of the crime charged.Â  Rivers now appeals the circuit courtâ€™s 
  denial of his motion for a mistrial.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant or deny a motion for a mistrial 
  is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court. Creighton v. 
  Coligny Plaza Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 334 S.C. 96, 118, 512 S.E.2d 510, 521 (Ct. App. 
  1998).Â  Absent an abuse of discretion, the decision of the trial court will 
  not be overturned on appeal. Id.Â  The burden is upon the moving party 
  to show not only error, but resulting prejudice. State v. Wasson, 299 
  S.C. 508, 510, 386 S.E.2d 255, 256 (1989). In any event, the grant of a mistrial 
  is an extreme measure that should not be granted unless absolutely necessary, 
  and the trial judge should exhaust all other methods to cure possible prejudice 
  before aborting a trial. Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rivers argues the circuit court abused 
  its discretion by denying his motion for a mistrial without investigating the 
  allegations of juror misconduct.Â  We disagree.
Rivers argues that an abuse of discretion 
  must be found based on our opinion in State v. Hurd, 325 S.C. 384, 480 
  S.E.2d 94 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In Hurd, the trial court refused the defendantâ€™s 
  request to question a juror who appeared to be asleep during portions of closing 
  arguments and jury instructions.Â  We reversed the defendantâ€™s conviction, stating 
  that a trial court â€œshould at least attempt to make this determination whenever 
  a juror appears to be asleep.â€ Id. at 390, 480 S.E.2d at 97.Â  The trial 
  court in Hurd made no such inquiry.Â Â  Thus, we held the trial judge â€œshould 
  have either determined whether the juror was in fact asleep, recharged the entire 
  jury, or replaced the juror.â€ Id.  
 The present case is readily distinguishable 
  from Hurd.Â  First, and most importantly, Rivers did not request that 
  the trial judge conduct any investigation into the matter of alleged juror misconduct.Â  
  Rivers simply accepted the trial judgeâ€™s denial of his motion for a mistrial 
  without asking the court to voir dire the juror or undertake further inquiry.Â  
  Because Rivers bore the burden of showing the juror was asleep or otherwise 
  engaged in misconduct, his failure to request direct examination of the jurorâ€”unlike 
  the defendant in Hurdâ€”waives any complaint on appeal.Â  See State 
  v. Smith, 338 S.C. 66, 75, 525 S.E.2d 263, 268 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding 
  that defendantâ€™s failure to request that the trial judge investigate allegations 
  that a juror was asleep during trial â€œwaives any complaint on appealâ€); see 
  also State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 550-51, 514 S.E.2d 584, 589-90 
  (1999) (noting that counsel must request that the trial court investigate juror 
  misconduct).
Further distinguishing the instant case 
  is the fact that, in Hurd, the defense counsel reported that he actually 
  saw the juror sleeping, and the trial judge agreed there was cause for concernâ€”declaring 
  specifically that he â€œnoticed [the juror] nodding off a couple of timesâ€ but 
  that the juror â€œwas alert during most of the charge.â€ 325 S.C. at 388-89, 480 
  S.E.2d at 97.Â  Here, on the other hand, defense counsel based his motion solely 
  on the statement of an unnamed third party that a juror was asleep.Â  No assertion 
  was made that defense counsel or anyone else directly involved in the trial 
  witnessed any juror misconduct.Â  It would be difficult indeed to fault the trial 
  judge for giving little credence to these unsupported, unverifiable allegations.Â  
  These bare assertions clearly fall well short of the necessary showing to warrant 
  the grant of a motion for mistrial.
CONCLUSION
We find Rivers waived any complaint on 
  appeal regarding the alleged juror misconduct by failing to request that the 
  trial judge investigate the matter.Â  Moreover, we otherwise find no abuse of 
  discretion by the trial judge given the scant grounds raised in support of the 
  motion for a mistrial. The ruling of the circuit court is therefore
AFFIRMED.Â  
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Maurice Wally,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-638
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  16, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  A Beaufort County grand jury 
  indicted Maurice Wally on one count of burglary in the first degree.Â  Following 
  trial, Wally was convicted and sentenced to a term of fifteen years.Â  On appeal, 
  Wally argues the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict of not guilty 
  on the burglary charge because the State failed to present evidence that Wally 
  entered the dwelling with the intent to commit a crime therein.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
Facts
Around 4:00 
  a.m. on December 6, 2001, William and Starletta Hairston were asleep in the 
  upstairs portion their home when they were awakened by the chirping of their 
  alarm system. [2] Â  William got 
  out of bed and went to check on his three boys who were sleeping in an adjacent 
  bedroom.Â  After ensuring the children were in bed, he went back to his bedroom 
  and retrieved a shotgun from a locked compartment behind his bed.Â  Starletta 
  turned on the bedroom lights and called the police.Â  
With the 
  shotgun in hand, Mr. Hairston rushed to the top of the stairs where he noticed 
  Wally moving from the interior of the house towards the front door.Â  William 
  testified he cocked the shotgun to let Wally know he â€œwas ready,â€ and then ordered 
  him to stop in his tracks. Â Wally complied and did not move.Â  William then asked 
  Wally what he was doing in the house and Wally replied, â€œthe gate told [me] 
  to come in.â€Â  William then ordered Wally to get down on the floor where he was 
  held at gunpoint until the police arrived and placed him under arrest.Â  
William testified 
  Wally did not have anything in his hands when this confrontation took place 
  and an inspection of the house the next morning revealed nothing was missing.Â  
  William estimated Wally was in the home for a little over two minutes before 
  he was confronted.Â  
At the close of 
  evidence, defense counsel moved for a directed verdict asserting that Wally 
  did not attempt to take anything out of the home and the State failed to prove 
  he intended to commit a crime in the house.Â  The trial court denied the motion, 
  found Wally guilty but mentally ill, and sentenced him to fifteen years imprisonment. 
  [3] Â Â  
Law/Analysis
Wallyâ€™s sole argument 
  on appeal is â€œ[t]he trial court erred in failing to grant a directed verdict 
  to the charge of burglary because the state failed to present any substantial 
  evidence . . . that appellant entered the dwelling with the intent to commit 
  a crime.â€Â  We disagree.
â€œIn considering 
  a motion for directed verdict in a criminal case, all evidence is viewed in 
  the light most favorable to the State.â€Â  State v. Smith, 352 S.C. 133, 
  136, 572 S.E.2d 473, 474 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  To this end, â€œ[t]he Court of Appeals 
  is concerned with the existence or non-existence of evidence, not its weight.â€Â  
  State v. Nesbitt, 346 S.C. 226, 230, 550 S.E.2d 864, 866 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  As such, we can only reverse the trial court if the record contains no evidence 
  justifying its ruling.Â  State v. Douglas, 359 S.C. 187, 203, 597 S.E.2d 
  1, 9 (Ct. App.Â  2004).Â  Thus, an accused is entitled to a directed verdict when 
  the State fails to present evidence of the crime charged.Â  Id.  
A person is guilty of first-degree burglary when 
  â€œthe person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime 
  in the dwelling, and . . . (3) the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (2003).Â  Essentially Wally argues that because nothing 
  was missing from the house and none of the homeownersâ€™ belongings were in his 
  possession when he was caught, there is no evidence he intended to commit a 
  crime in the house.
This assertion, however, is completely without 
  merit.Â  As our supreme court noted in State v. Haney, 257 S.C. 89, 91, 
  184 S.E.2d 344, 345 (1971), â€œ[a]bsent an admission by the defendant, proof of 
  intent necessarily rests on inference from conduct.â€Â  The court went on to explain 
  that â€œ[w]hen the building entered is a dwelling house, the weight of authority 
  holds that the unexplained breaking and entry in the night is itself evidence 
  of intent to commit larceny . . . . The fundamental theory, in the absence of 
  evidence of other intent or explanation for breaking and entering, is that the 
  usual object or purpose of burglarizing a dwelling house at night is theft.â€Â  
  Id. at 91-92, 184 S.E.2d at 345. 
Conclusion
Accordingly, because intent to commit a 
  crimeâ€”i.e., larcenyâ€”can be inferred from the breaking and entering itself, we 
  find there is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  Accordingly, we 
  find the trial court did not err in failing to grant Wallyâ€™s directed verdict 
  motion and as such, the ruling is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 
  

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Mr. Hairston explained that the alarm would chirp when one of the 
    homeâ€™s doors or windows were opened.Â  

 
   
    [3]  At trial, defense counsel brought to the courtâ€™s attention the fact 
    that Wallyâ€™s mental evaluation indicated he had a family history of psychotic 
    illness and mental retardation.Â  He also noted Wally received treatment in 
    the past for hearing voices and a personality disorder.Â Â  Although the court 
    took this history into consideration and sentenced Wally accordingly, Wallyâ€™s 
    mental condition is not at issue in this appeal.
