Christopher Carlton Cosgrove,       
Appellant.
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-640
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  20, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Maggi Fields Bailey, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Jefferson G. Wood and E. Kimberly Berry, both of Greenville,
for Respondent. 

      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  In this action for child support, a father appeals an 
  award of both retroactive and prospective child support and attorneyâ€™s fees 
  to the mother.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. [1] 
FACTS
Vickie F. Myers (â€œMotherâ€) and Christopher 
  C. Cosgrove (â€œFatherâ€) dated and cohabitated intermittently from July 1997 until 
  July 1999.Â  In November 1998, the couple had a child. Â Mother brought 
  this action on May 2, 2001, pursuant to section 20-7-420 of the South Carolina 
  Code (Supp. 2003), seeking custody of the minor child, child support, retroactive 
  child support, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â Â  
In a temporary order, the family court ordered 
  a paternity test.Â  If the paternity test was positive, Father was ordered to 
  pay the costs of the test and child support retroactively from the date the 
  action was filed.Â  The test results, which were positive, were mailed to both 
  parties on August 16, 2001; however, Father denies having any knowledge of the 
  results until January 2002.Â  Also in January 2002, the case was administratively 
  stricken from the active trial docket pursuant to the â€œ270 day rule.â€
In an order dated September 27, 2002, the court 
  denied Motherâ€™s first motion to restore the action, in part because discovery 
  was not complete.Â  This was due largely to Fatherâ€™s failure to cooperate with 
  Motherâ€™s discovery requests.Â  The court gave Mother leave to file another motion 
  to restore when discovery was complete.Â  The court granted motherâ€™s second motion 
  to restore the action as well as a contemporaneous motion to amend the pleadings.Â  
  The motion to amend sought to include a request for Father to carry life insurance 
  for the benefit of their child.Â  The court also found Father waived the mediation 
  requirement by his refusal to participate.Â Â Â  
At the final hearing, Mother testified she is currently 
  employed as a legal assistant with a reported gross monthly income of $2,150. 
  Health insurance expenses each month for the minor child are $120.Â  Daycare 
  initially cost $303 per month but at the time of the final hearing cost approximately 
  $275 per month.Â  Mother also has custody of a seven-year-old son from a previous 
  relationship for which she receives no child support.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Father testified he is a part-time tattoo artist 
  apprentice with a monthly income of $600. He has completed three and a half 
  years of a five-year apprenticeship.Â  He is thirty-two years of age and 
  in good health.Â  He reported living expenses of $810.87, including $237 per 
  month child support for another child.Â  Father, however, receives periodic gifts 
  of cash from his mother, who also pays for the mortgage on his residence, which 
  they jointly own.Â  He has not filed a tax return for the last five years.Â  When 
  asked why he did not file tax returns, he responded, â€œIâ€™m making six hundred 
  dollars ($600) a month. And I do not owe the IRS any monies. You do not have 
  to file your income tax if you do not owe any money.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Â The family court found Father to be the childâ€™s 
  biological father, gave custody to Mother, awarded her child support of $589 
  per month, and required Father to pay retroactive child support from the date 
  of the initial filing.Â  The court ordered that back child support be paid in 
  two lump sum payments and orderedÂ Â  Father to pay $7,500 of Motherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has 
  authority to find the facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence. Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 
  154, 157 (1996).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to 
  disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the family 
  court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers 
  v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ ANALYSIS
I. Child Support
Father claims the family court erred 
  in awarding Mother child support of $589 per month based upon an imputed income 
  of $2,929 per month.Â  We disagree.
The amount of a child support award is 
  within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on 
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 
  624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975). Â In determining the amount of child support, 
  crucial factors include: the needs of the children; the incomes, earning capacities 
  and assets of the parents; and the health, ages, general physical condition, 
  and living expenses of the parents.Â  Bradley v. Bradley, 285 S.C. 
  170, 172-73, 328 S.E.2d 647, 648 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  
At trial, the family court heard an abundance of 
  testimony concerning the earning capacities of the parties, much of it conflicting.Â  
  On his financial declaration, Father claimed a gross monthly income of $600 
  per month because he only worked three days a week as a tattoo apprentice.Â  
  He testified the benefit of the apprenticeship is a resulting recommendation 
  into a tattoo guild, though he admitted â€œyou donâ€™t have to be a member of the 
  [guild to] set up shop and make money tattooing.â€Â  Mother testified Father worked 
  both part-time and full-time as a tattoo artist when she was living with him 
  and he averaged $150 per day, after expenses.Â  She stated he had a reputation 
  in the community as a â€œvery good artist.â€Â  Father, on the other hand, stated 
  he usually averaged only $50 per day.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Ten years ago, Father 
  was employed as a construction worker making approximately $14 per hour.Â  He 
  quit this job to follow the Grateful Dead around the country.Â  Even though he 
  did not graduate, he received a certificate of completion in 1991 from the Harley 
  Davidson mechanicâ€™s program.Â  Furthermore, he was proficient enough in motorcycle 
  maintenance to build his own bike out of spare parts.Â  Mother provided current 
  occupational employment wage statistics for motorcycle mechanics and highway 
  maintenance workers in Florida, where Father currently resides.Â  Construction 
  workers with experience can earn $13 per hour, while entry-level mechanics can 
  earn as much as $10 per hour.Â  Father, however, testified he was injured in 
  â€œseveralâ€ car wrecks, preventing him from doing any work that requires sitting 
  or standing.Â  He did not, however, submit any evidence to corroborate these 
  statements.Â  He also admitted he was not â€œreally fightingâ€ the denial of his 
  disability claim because he did not â€œneed to be living off the state.â€Â  He testified 
  he could â€œmake enough to pay for [his] food on the tableâ€ with his salary of 
  $150 per week.Â Â  
Although this court has authority to find the facts 
  in accordance with our own view of the evidence, we are mindful that the family 
  court judge was better situated to evaluate witness credibility and assign comparative 
  weight to their testimony.Â  Bowers, 349 S.C. at 91, 561 S.E.2d at 613.Â  
  It is abundantly clear from the family courtâ€™s order that the trial judge found 
  Fatherâ€™s testimony grossly lacking in the areas of consistency and credibility, 
  and from what we can glean from the record on appeal, we agree.Â  Husband contradicted 
  himself throughout his testimony about his business, finances and the facts 
  of this case. For instance, on direct examination he testified his tattoo business 
  failed because he â€œdidnâ€™t have enough business smarts to keep it going.â€Â  On 
  cross-examination, however, he claimed the business failed because â€œthe guy 
  [he] was going in partnership with [was] tripped out on drugs.Â  And he made 
  [them] get kicked out of [their] studio.â€Â  In a deposition, Father stated that 
  he was involved in litigation to recoup these business losses.Â  When questioned 
  on the matter at trial Father explained he â€œnever pursuedâ€ the lawsuit.Â  In 
  fact, he could not even recall the name of the attorney representing him in 
  the alleged action.Â  Similarly, at trial, Father denied having knowledge of 
  the paternity test results until shortly before trial began, while in his deposition 
  he admitted learning of the results in January 2002.Â  
The South Carolina Code defines income 
  of a parent as â€œthe actual gross income of the parent, if employed to full capacity, 
  or potential income if unemployed or underemployed.â€Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 
  114-4720(A)(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  To determine potential income, â€œthe court should 
  determine the employment potential and probable earnings level of the parent 
  based on that parentâ€™s recent work history, occupational qualifications, and 
  prevailing job opportunities and earning levels in the community.â€Â  27 S.C. 
  Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)(5)(b) (Supp. 2003).Â  For the reasons discussed above, 
  we find no error in the family courtâ€™s acceptance of Motherâ€™s testimony regarding 
  Fatherâ€™s earning potential for the purposes of calculating child support.
We likewise find the family courtâ€™s consideration 
  of money Father receives from his mother a proper factor in the computation 
  of child support.Â  In regard to computing income for the purpose of determining 
  child support, the regulations provide:

(2)(b) In addition to determining potential earnings, the 
  court should impute income to any non-income producing assets of either parent, 
  if significant, other than a primary residence or personal property . . . .
Gross income does not include: . . . 
(3)(c) In-kind income; however, the court should count 
  as income expense reimbursements or in-kind payments received by a parent from 
  self-employment or operation of a business if they are significant and reduce 
  personal living expenses, such as a company car, free housing, 
  or reimbursed meals.

27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)(2)(b) & (A)(3)(c) 
  (emphasis added).
Father admitted his mother gave him large 
  amounts of cash in 1998, 1999, and 2002 for maintenance of the house they jointly 
  own; however, he submitted no evidence that the money was actually spent on 
  anything relating to the upkeep of the house.Â  His mother also pays his portion 
  of the mortgage, amounting to approximately $5,149.92 per year.Â Â Â  In this case, 
  Father admits that by maintaining the house, he is managing an investment for 
  his mother.Â  Because Fatherâ€™s personal expenses are substantially reduced by 
  the payments he receives for this service, we conclude the money given to Father 
  falls under the exception to the general rule that in-kind income is not gross 
  income for the purposes of computing child support. 
Father argues that because he is not 
  obligated to pay taxes on this income, and there is no guarantee he will continue 
  receiving these monetary gifts in the future, it should not be considered as 
  â€œgross incomeâ€ for the purposes of calculating child support.Â  We are not convinced.Â  
  In Mobley v. Mobley, 309 S.C. 134, 139, 420 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 
  1992), this court held a husbandâ€™s income from employee benefits, including 
  housing and utilities, could be treated as income for purposes of determining 
  child support payments even though the husband had â€œno tax liability for the 
  value of the housingâ€ or any guarantee that he would continue to receive the 
  bonuses.
Having reviewed the record, we find by 
  a preponderance of the evidence that Father has a potential to earn significantly 
  more income. We therefore affirm the family courtâ€™s determination that Fatherâ€™s 
  imputed income is $2,929 per month.Â  Consequently, we uphold the family courtâ€™s 
  award of $589 per month in child support.Â Â  
II. Attorneyâ€™sÂ  Fees
Father claims the family court 
  erred in awarding Mother $7,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the discretion 
  of the court.â€Â  Hardwick v. Hardwick, 303 S.C. 256, 261, 399 S.E.2d 
  791, 794 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, 
  the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees, the 
  beneficial results obtained by the attorney, the partiesâ€™ respective financial 
  conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. 
  v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 815 (1992). 
We find no abuse of discretion 
  in requiring Father to pay a portion of Motherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family 
  court found Mother owed her attorney at least $9,380.50. Â In addition, Mother 
  incurred costs of $1,075.70 during the discovery process due to Fatherâ€™s refusal 
  to cooperate.Â  Father also failed to comply with court ordered mediation, prolonging 
  this litigation.
Â Fatherâ€™s potential income, 
  combined with his earnings for managing the property on which he lives, brings 
  his total gross monthly income to an amount greater than Motherâ€™s.Â  Furthermore, 
  Father has equity in the Florida residence of approximately $29,000. [2] Â Â Â  
On the other hand, Mother 
  has no assets or savings, and is burdened by considerable debt.Â  She cannot 
  afford to pay her attorneyâ€™s fees without substantially impacting the standard 
  of living of her and her children.Â  See Pendergast v. Pendergast, 
  354 S.C. 32, 40, 579 S.E.2d 530, 534 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Because of Fatherâ€™s conduct, 
  including his failure to comply with the mediation order or cooperate with discovery, 
  Mother incurred a greater amount of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Mother testified, â€œ[h]e 
  just kept saying, â€˜Take me to courtâ€™â€ when she would beg him for money.Â  In 
  fact, Father admitted he â€œdidnâ€™t give her any other option other than coming 
  to court.â€Â  This court finds his conduct unnecessarily prolonged this litigation.
Motherâ€™s counsel achieved 
  beneficial results, as she received a substantial award of child support, which 
  we now affirm.Â  As the family courtâ€™s appropriate consideration of the E.D.M. 
  factors in determining the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees is apparent from the record, 
  we conclude the family court did not err in requiring Father to contribute $7,500 
  toward Motherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.
III. Lump Sum Payments
Father claims the family court 
  erred in requiring him to pay attorneyâ€™s fees and retroactive child support 
  in large lump sum payments.Â  We disagree.
The family court ordered 
  Father to pay $2,500 of the attorneyâ€™s fees in a lump sum.Â  It further ordered 
  three equal installments of $3,951.67 for retroactive child support.Â  Father 
  has a potential income of $2,929 per month and substantial equity in his home.Â  
  He has the ability to pay the past due child support and attorneyâ€™s fees in 
  the time allotted and this will not create any undue hardship or burden on him.Â  
  Accordingly, we affirm the award of lump sum payments for the attorneyâ€™s fees 
  and child support.
IV. Life Insurance Award Reservation
Father claims the family court 
  erred in reserving an award of life insurance. We agree.Â  
South Carolina recognizes 
  the availability of life insurance as security for the support obligation.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-160 (Supp.2003).Â  â€œThe family court is within 
  its legal authority to require a supporting spouse to maintain a life insurance 
  policy naming the child as beneficiary to insure the continued support of the 
  minor child.â€Â  Ivey v. Ivey, 286 S.C. 315, 318, 334 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. 
  App. 1985).Â  This imposition, however, must be based on compelling reasons, 
  such as failure to pay, which make the security a necessity.Â  Id.Â  
Although the family court denied 
  Motherâ€™s request for Father to maintain life insurance with the child as irrevocable 
  beneficiary, the court reserved the right to grant the request in six months. 
  A reservation of an award is not standard in child support cases because â€œif 
  it subsequently appears security is necessary, the continuing jurisdiction of 
  the family court affords ample opportunity to require security by life insurance.â€Â  
  Id.Â Â  The family court may reserve an award if there are present or foreseeable 
  circumstances warranting the reservation.Â  Hardy v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 
  435-36, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  When there are no compelling reasons 
  for an award of life insurance as security for the child support obligation 
  at the time of trial, and â€œno indication of physical or mental illness, foreseeable 
  change in need in the future, or such other extenuating circumstance,â€ reservation 
  is not appropriate.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 363, 384 S.E.2d 
  741, 747 (1989).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 Because the record 
  does not reflect any specific factual findings to support reservation of the 
  grant of life insurance as security for support, we reverse the family courtâ€™s 
  ruling on this issue.Â  However, we remand this issue back to the family court 
  for additional findings to determine what extenuating circumstances exist, if 
  any, to justify a reservation of the award.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the family courtâ€™s 
  rulings are hereby 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J. , GOOLSBY andÂ  WILLIAMS, JJ. , concur.

 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR. 

 
   
    [2]  Current equity in the home is approximately $58,000, split between 
    the co-owners.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Marcum Mace,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Chevy Chase Bank,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-643
Heard November 16, 2004 â€“ Filed December 20, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Rivers S. Stilwell and Peter G. Siachos, both of Greenville, 
  for Appellant.
Joseph A. Mooneyham, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Chevy Chase Bank appeals a 
  circuit court order enforcing a settlement agreement entered into between it 
  and Marcum Mace.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In September 1996, Marcum 
  Mace obtained a second mortgage to finance construction of a residential swimming 
  pool.Â  Payments were not to be made on the mortgage until construction of the 
  swimming pool was completed and the last payment given to the pool contractor.Â  
  Before construction was complete, Chevy Chase Bank acquired the mortgage and 
  began to prematurely assess interest and penalties on the loan.Â  Mace filed 
  suit against the Bank, seeking return of the mistaken penalties and interest 
  and correction of his credit history.Â  
The parties held mediation after considerable written 
  discovery was taken, including Maceâ€™s credit report, and on September 11, 2001, 
  they entered into a written settlement agreement.Â  The Bank agreed to pay Mace 
  $20,000 and to refinance the principal loan on his home.Â  The agreement provided 
  the refinancing was â€œcontingent upon the submission and approval of an application 
  by Mace.â€Â  Mace and a representative of the Bank, as well as both attorneys, 
  signed the agreement, but it was neither filed with the court nor entered into 
  the record.Â  
In November 2001, the Bank paid the agreed upon 
  $20,000 and sent Mace a credit application.Â  Mace completed the application 
  and returned it to the Bank, but it was rejected because Mace used a pencil.Â  
  A second application, completed with a pen, was sent to the Bank on December 
  18, 2001.Â  No action was taken on this application until it was rejected in 
  February 2002 based on a negative credit history.Â  In August 2002, Mace commenced 
  the current litigation by filing a motion to compel settlement.Â  
At the hearing, Mace argued the Bank improperly 
  refused to refinance his home loan.Â  Specifically, Mace asserted the credit 
  report given to the Bank at the time the settlement took place showed no substantial 
  negative credit history.Â  Although he acknowledged his credit report did contain 
  negative history by the time the Bank took action on the application, Mace asserted 
  the negative history occurred as Mace â€œallowed some things to go a little bit 
  late because he anticipated the refinance and having additional funds with which 
  to resolve some credit card bills.â€Â  Mace argued the settlement contemplated 
  approval for the refinancing at the time of settlement, not five months later.Â  

The Bank presented two reasons why the settlement 
  should not be enforced.Â  First, the Bank argued Rule 43(k), SCRCP, specifically 
  applied to the settlement, and because the settlement was not filed with the 
  court nor entered into the record, it was not enforceable.Â  Alternatively, the 
  Bank asserted the condition precedent to the refinancingâ€”submission and approval 
  of an applicationâ€”was not met.Â  The Bank averred it considered Maceâ€™s application, 
  but was just unable to approve it because of the negative credit history.Â  
On May 6, 2003, the circuit court issued an order 
  granting the motion to compel settlement.Â  The court ruled that Rule 43(k) did 
  not apply to the settlement agreement, and the Bank could not, by its own delay, 
  prejudice Maceâ€™s application.Â  Accordingly, the court ordered the Bank to grant 
  the refinancing.Â  The Bank argues on appeal these rulings were in error.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to determine liability under a settlement 
  agreement is an action at law.Â  Pruitt v. South Carolina Medical Malpractice 
  Liability Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001).Â  
  â€œ[I]n an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings 
  of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without 
  evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs., 
  Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
The Bank first asserts the circuit court erred 
  in finding Rule 43(k), SCRCP, did not prevent enforcement of the settlement 
  agreement.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 43(k), SCRCP provides:Â  â€œ[n]o agreement between 
  counsel affecting the proceedings in an action shall be binding unless reduced 
  to the form of a consent order or written stipulation signed by counsel and 
  entered in the record, or unless made in open court and noted upon the record.â€Â  
  The Bank argues this rule applies and therefore, the settlement agreement is 
  unenforceable because it was neither entered into the record nor filed with 
  the court.Â  
While it is true the actual agreement was not entered 
  into the record, the Bank admitted there was an agreement.Â  Following a comment 
  by the trial judge that there was no question the parties entered into an agreement, 
  the Bank responded, â€œ[s]ure, Your Honor, and we donâ€™t contend that this isnâ€™t 
  a binding settlement by any means.â€Â  A short time later, the Bank again admitted 
  the agreementâ€™s existence when it explained, â€œ[w]eâ€™re not trying to get out 
  of, of the settlement agreement here, Your Honor.â€Â  Because, Rule 43(k) does 
  not apply when an agreement is admitted or has been carried into effect, it 
  does not render this settlement unenforceable.Â  See Ashfort Corp. 
  v. Palmetto Constr. Group, Inc., 318 S.C. 492, 494 n.1, 458 S.E.2d 533, 
  534 n.1 (1995).Â  
The Bank also contends the circuit court erred 
  in failing to rule that a condition precedent to the refinancing had not been 
  fulfilled and in ruling that the Bank unreasonably delayed examining Maceâ€™s 
  application.Â  Again, we disagree.
South Carolina case law defines a condition precedent 
  as â€œany fact other than the lapse of time, which, unless excused, must exist 
  or occur before a duty of immediate performance arises.â€Â  Worley v. Yarborough 
  Ford, Inc., 317 S.C. 206, 210, 452 S.E.2d 622, 624 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
  Even assuming a condition precedent exists, the change in Maceâ€™s credit history 
  occurred during the delay between the settlement and loan approval.Â  The circuit 
  court found the Bank caused the delay, and it would be improper to allow the 
  Bank to gain from its wrongdoing.
Furthermore, included in every contract, including 
  settlement agreements, is an implied covenant of fair dealing.Â  See Boddie-Noell 
  Properties, Inc. v. 42 Magnolia Pâ€™ship, 344 S.C. 474, 484, 544 S.E.2d 279, 
  284 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Allen v. Allen, 301 
  S.E.2d 514, 515-16 (N.C. Ct. App. 1983).Â  In this case, the court found 
  the Bankâ€™s unreasonable delay prejudiced Maceâ€™s application.Â  
It took over two months from the settlement date 
  for the Bank to provide Mace with an application.Â  Although Mace improperly 
  completed the first application in pencil, he sent the Bank a proper application 
  on December 18, 2001.Â  The Bank took no action on this application for nearly 
  two months until it was denied based on Maceâ€™s credit history sometime after 
  February 11, 2002.Â  Counsel for the Bank conceded that what amounted to a five-month 
  delay between settlement and denial of the loan application was unusual, but 
  instead insisted there was no evidence the Bank deliberately delayed reviewing 
  the application.Â  While it is difficult to reconstruct the exact reasons for 
  the delay, we find there is ample evidence to support the courtâ€™s determination 
  that the Bank unreasonably delayed processing Maceâ€™s application.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Coleman Ellerbe,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-644
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Coleman Ellerbe appeals 
  the dismissal of his petition for a writ of habeas corpus, arguing that, since 
  his petition failed to expressly allege he exhausted all state administrative 
  remedies, the circuit court was required to treat the petition as an application 
  for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
In September 1988, Appellant pled 
  guilty to murder and was sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  In 1995, Appellant 
  filed an application for PCR.Â  Following a hearing in March 1996, the application 
  was dismissed.Â  In 1999, Appellant filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus 
  in the circuit court, claiming his trial attorney induced him into pleading 
  guilty by promising him a reduction in his sentence due to the absence of a 
  prior criminal record.Â  
The circuit court dismissed Appellantâ€™s 
  petition on two grounds. First, the court concluded that, because Appellant 
  failed to allege he had exhausted all available PCR remedies, the petition was 
  improper.Â  Second, the court found Appellantâ€™s claims were cognizable 
  under the Uniform Post Conviction Procedure Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 
  to â€“120 (2003), and thus may not be raised in a petition for habeas corpus.Â  
  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
Upon enactment in 1966, the Uniform Post 
  Conviction Procedure Act largely superseded and encompassed the habeas corpus 
  procedure provided by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to â€“120 
  (2003); Gibson v. State, 329 S.C. 37, 41, 495 S.E.2d 426, 428 (1998).Â  
  Although habeas corpus continues to be available as a constitutional remedy, 
  it is available only when other remedies, such as PCR, are inadequate or unavailable.Â  
  See S.C. Const. art. 1, Â§ 18; Gibson, 329 S.C. at 41, 495 S.E.2d 
  at 428.Â  As such, â€œa matter which is cognizable under the Act may not be raised 
  by a petition for a writ of habeas corpus before the circuit or other lower 
  courts.â€Â  Simpson v. State, 329 S.C. 43, 46, 495 S.E.2d 429, 431 (1998).Â  
  Furthermore, the Act is â€œbroadly inclusive and will rarely be inadequate or 
  unavailable to test the legality of [a] detention.â€Â  Gibson, 329 S.C. 
  at 41, 495 S.E.2d at 428; see also Simpson, 329 S.C. at 
  45-47, 495 S.E.2d at 430-31.
Because Appellantâ€™s petition alleges that 
  he was convicted in violation of the constitution, his claim is obviously cognizable 
  under the Act; thus, Appellant is procedurally barred from petitioning the circuit 
  court for a writ of habeas corpus.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-20(a)(1) 
  (2003); Keeler v. Mauney, 330 S.C. 568, 571, 500 S.E.2d 123, 124 (Ct. 
  App. 1998).Â  â€œIf a person is procedurally barred, his only means of obtaining 
  state habeas corpus relief is to file a petition in the original jurisdiction 
  of the Supreme Court.â€Â  Keeler, 330 S.C. at 571, 500 S.E.2d at 124.Â  
  The trial court properly dismissed Appellantâ€™s petition on this ground.
Appellant correctly asserts that if a 
  petition for a writ of habeas corpus fails to allege that PCR remedies are unavailable, 
  inadequate, or have previously been exhausted, the petition should be treated 
  as a PCR application.Â  Gibson, 329 S.C. at 42, 495 S.E.2d at 428.Â Â  In 
  his petition, Appellant mentioned, albeit vaguely, the dismissal of his previous 
  PCR application.Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s determination that Appellant had not 
  alleged exhaustion of available PCR remedies could be construed as an erroneous 
  finding.Â  However, as stated above, the trial court dismissed the petition on 
  proper grounds in its additional ruling.Â  Moreover, had the action been treated 
  as a PCR application, as Appellant now requests, it would have been similarly 
  dismissed as time barred pursuant to the PCR statute of limitations.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003).
For the foregoing reasons, the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling is
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, CJ., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD 
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Vernon C. Ballard,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Alvin K. Benson, Reyâ€™s Jewlers, Henry Taylor d/b/a Taylor Electric, Bobby 
        Mosley, United States of America and Joyce Equipment Company,       
Defendants,
Of Whom Alvin K. Benson is       
Appellant,
      
    
  

and

  
    
      
Reyâ€™s Jewelers, Henry Taylor d/b/a Taylor Electric, Bobby Mosley, United 
        States of America and Joyce Equipment Company are       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-646
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  21, 2004Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard E. Thompson, Jr., of Anderson, for Appellant.
Harold P. Threlkeld, of Anderson, James D. McCoy, III, of 
  the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office andÂ  Michael Stephen Chambers, of Greenville, for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Alvin K. Benson appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s withdrawal of an earlier order and the subsequent issuance 
  of a decree of partition.Â  We affirm. [1]   
FACTS
In August 1989, Best Amusement, Inc., conveyed 2.075 
  acres of property to Samuel L. McMullin and William M. Mattison.Â  In 1992, McMullen 
  and Mattison failed to pay taxes on the property. To settle the default, Anderson 
  County sold the easternmost acre to Vernon C. Ballard at a tax sale in October 
  1993.Â  Exactly one year later, following the statutory redemption period, Ballard 
  received his title.
On April 20, 1994, the federal government filed 
  a forfeiture action in the United States District Court for the District of 
  South Carolina against McMullen and Mattison for illegal drug activities.Â  The 
  complaint alleged McMullen and Mattison began purchasing cocaine from various 
  sources in 1984 and used money from cocaine sales to make the down payment on 
  the property. The complaint further alleged that the property should be forfeited 
  to the United States pursuant to 21 U.S.C.A. Â§ 881(a)(6) (1999).Â  Anderson County 
  was notified of the action on April 21, 1994.
On September 25, 1995, a forfeiture order was entered 
  whereby McMullen and Mattison forfeited their interest in the property to the 
  United States. On November 19, 1998, the United States Marshal for the District 
  of South Carolina sold the property.Â  Alvin K. Benson successfully bid on the 
  property and received a deed, releasing the United Statesâ€™ interest in the tract.Â  
  A few months later, on February 26, 1999, the marshal executed a corrected deed 
  which specifically excluded the one-acre tract already sold by the County to 
  Ballard.Â  In late 2000, Ballard petitioned the circuit court for partition of 
  the property.Â  Benson responded, arguing the Marshalâ€™s sale conveyed title to 
  the entire property and was superior to Ballardâ€™s deed received from the county 
  tax sale.
The circuit court initially found for Benson.Â  
  Ballard, however, filed a motion to alter or amend the order pursuant to Rule 
  52(b), SCRCP.Â  In support of his motion, Ballard submitted an affidavit from 
  Nancy Prince Mackey, Aiken County Treasurer, dated January 28, 2003. 
  [2] Â  Mackey asserted she conferred with the U.S. Attorney handling the 
  forfeiture and both agreed the United Statesâ€™ interest in the property was subject 
  to Ballardâ€™s deed.Â  After reviewing the affidavit, the circuit court withdrew 
  its earlier order. 
In its final order, the circuit court recognized 
  Ballardâ€™s one-acre interest in the property.Â  After determining the property 
  could not be practically divided or partitioned, the court ordered it be appraised 
  and sold, with proceeds distributed between Benson and Ballard according to 
  their respective interests. This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of title to real property is 
  at law.Â  Wigfall v. Fobbs, 295 S.C. 59, 60, 367 S.E.2d 156, 157 (1988).Â  
  In an action at law tried without a jury, the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings 
  will not be disturbed on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or 
  controlled by an error of law; however, this court may correct errors of law 
  without deference to the lower court.Â  Simmons v. Bellamy, 349 S.C. 473, 
  476, 562 S.E.2d 687, 688 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Benson argues he gained title to the entire property, 
  including the one-acre tract the County sold to Ballard, by virtue of the 1998 
  Marshalâ€™s sale.Â  We disagree.
The federal government secured its interest 
  in the property pursuant to 21 U.S.C.A. Â§ 881(a)(6) (1999), which provides that 
  any property furnished by any person in exchange of controlled substances is 
  subject to forfeiture by the United States.Â  When property is subject to forfeiture 
  for the violation of law, title vests absolutely in the sovereign at the date 
  of the illegal act. 21 U.S.C.A. Â§ 881(h) (1999).
Benson argues that this relation back theory applies 
  here; thus, the forfeiture relates back to 1989, when McMullen and Mattison 
  used proceeds from controlled substances to purchase the property.Â  The corrected 
  deed issued to Benson by the U.S. Marshal, however, added an exclusion for the 
  acre that had already been sold by the County to Ballard. This supports the 
  circuit courtâ€™s finding that the United States never acquired any interest in 
  the acre claimed by Ballard.
As noted previously, Ballard submitted an affidavit 
  from Mackey, the Anderson County treasurer, with his motion to reconsider. She 
  asserted the propertyâ€™s easternmost acre was sold at a tax sale to Ballard in 
  1993 and a deed was conveyed to him in 1994.Â  Since the sale, Ballard has paid 
  taxes on the parcel.Â  The remaining 1.075 acres was not sold to Benson until 
  1998.Â  Although there was some confusion on the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s part about the 
  description of the forfeited property, the matter was clarified in a conference 
  between Mackey and the U.S. Attorney handling the forfeiture action. The U.S. 
  Attorney agreed with the Mackey that the sale of the one-acre tract predated 
  the forfeiture and was not subject to forfeiture. The affidavit also confirms 
  that Benson had no interest in the one-acre tract. Â 
Assuming for the sake of argument the 
  federal government did gain an interest in the entire tract by forfeiture, Ballard 
  is protected by the innocent owner defense.Â  Ballard was never given any notice 
  of the forfeiture action.Â  At the time the action took place, the federal forfeiture 
  statute contained an exception which provided that â€œno property shall be forfeited 
  under this paragraph, to the extent of the interest of an owner, by reason of 
  any act or omission established by that owner to have been committed or omitted 
  without the knowledge or consent of that owner.â€ 21 U.S.C.A. Â§ 881(a)(6) (1999). 
  [3] Â  The South Carolina forfeiture statute contains similar language, providing 
  that the court may return any seized property to the owner if the owner shows 
  that he â€œwas not a consenting party to, or privy to, or did not have the knowledge 
  of, the use of the property which made it subject to seizure and forfeiture.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§44-53-586 (2002).Â  
We note the overriding purposes of civil 
  drug forfeitures are deterrence and retribution.Â  Forfeitures are viewed by 
  the government as a necessary tool to deter drug trafficking, and are not intended 
  to punish innocent owners.Â  Michael D. Dautrich, The â€œInnocent Ownerâ€ 
  Defense in Civil Drug Forfeitures after United States v. 92 Buena 
  Vista Avenue: Still an Uphill Battle for Third-party Claimants, 3 Widener 
  J. Pub. L. 995 (1994).Â  With this in mind, we conclude Ballard qualifies as 
  an innocent owner as he had neither knowledge of, nor consented to, the illegal 
  activity leading to the forfeiture.Â  Though there is no case directly on this 
  point in South Carolina, other jurisdictions have held that a bonafide purchaser 
  is entitled to protection as an innocent owner.Â Â  See United States 
  v. One Single Family Residence Located at 6960 Miraflores Ave, 731 F. Supp. 
  1563, 1568 (S.D. Fla. 1990).
Because Benson failed to prove that the entire 
  tract had been forfeited to the United States and conveyed to him, the circuit 
  courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  The affidavit was made part of the record without 
    objection. 

 
   
    [3]  Congress struck the innocent owner defense from Â§ 881(a)(6), which 
    became effective for any forfeiture commenced on or after 120 days from April 
    25, 2000.Â  See Civil Asset Forfeiture Reform Act of 2000, Pub.L. No. 
    106-185, Â§ 21, 114 Stat. 202, 225 (2000).Â  However, the governmentâ€™s forfeiture 
    in this case predated the effective date for elimination of the innocent owner 
    defense.

Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-648
Heard October 13, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Patrick W. Carr, of Charleston. for Appellant.
William P. Hatfield, Robert D. McKissick, of Florence,
for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Marion Elizabeth 
  Morris appeals the trial courtâ€™s order granting Timothy M. Carterâ€™s motion for 
  a new trial, arguing the trial court judge abused his discretion in considering 
  offers of settlement and in failing to view the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Carter and Morris were involved in an 
  automobile accident on March 30, 2001.Â  At the time of the accident, Carter 
  was stopped at an intersection and was immediately preceded by the vehicle driven 
  by his wife.Â  After the traffic light turned green, Carter and his wife proceeded 
  forward, but both slowed for another vehicle turning in front of them.Â  After 
  the other driver made his turn, Carterâ€™s wife moved forward.Â  According to Carter, 
  he had taken his foot off the brakes but had not yet pressed the gas when he 
  was rear-ended by Morris.Â  
The impact from the collision caused 
  the rear axle of Carterâ€™s vehicle to bend and the back end to fly into the air.Â  
  The front end of Morrisâ€™s car slid underneath Carterâ€™s SUV and sheared the cable 
  securing the spare tire underneath.Â  The tire was thrown between seventy-five 
  and one hundred feet before it landed in a nearby field.Â  The impact also pushed 
  Carterâ€™s vehicle between twenty-five and forty feet forward.Â  Following the 
  accident, Carter complained of injuries to his neck, back, and hands. 
At trial, Morris admitted negligence 
  but contested the issues of proximate cause and damages.Â  The jury returned 
  a verdict in favor of Morris.Â  Carter immediately moved for a new trial under 
  the thirteenth juror doctrine and for a new trial absolute based on the gross 
  inadequacy of the verdict.Â  Morris opposed the motion, arguing there was contradictory 
  evidence regarding to causation and asserting that a new trial based on the 
  inadequacy of the verdict was inappropriate because Carter never moved for a 
  directed verdict.Â  In deciding the motion, the judge orally set forth the legal 
  principles for both the thirteenth juror and the new trial absolute doctrines.Â  
  He further stated:

 The Court has to set aside, not being relevant, 
  any negotiation that takes place prior to trial or during the trial, but I canâ€™t 
  ignore the fact that I know there were negotiations and the Plaintiff didnâ€™t 
  think it was sufficient or adequate.Â  There are substantial offers that have 
  been made in this case by the Defendant and of course that doesnâ€™t become an 
  issue or question of law for a hearing.Â  But I know in the Defendantâ€™s attempt 
  to resolve it, evaluate it, and to make an offer of a substantial sum of money 
  and during the discovery period and the exchange of interrogatories and depositions 
  that the Defense, in their approach to the case, they had an exposure to liability 
  and they donâ€™t make substantial offers if they donâ€™t feel that the Plaintiffâ€™s 
  got [sic] a case, legitimate injury of proof as to carpal syndrome. That is 
  the crux of the case in the defense.Â  

No objection was made to the trial judgeâ€™s discussion 
  of settlement negotiations.
The trial judge granted the motion for 
  a new trial without stating under which doctrine.Â  From this order, Morris appeals.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
Morris first argues the 
  trial judge abused his discretion and committed an error of law by considering 
  settlement negotiations when he granted Carterâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  We 
  find this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
Generally, an issue must be raised to and 
  ruled upon by the trial judge in order to be preserved for appellate review. 
  Â Talley v. South Carolina Higher Educ. Tuition Grants Comm., 289 S.C. 
  483, 487, 347 S.E.2d 99, 101 (1986).Â  A matter that was not raised to or ruled 
  upon by the trial court cannot be considered by this court.Â  Id. at 487, 
  347 S.E.2d at 101.Â  â€œWhere a question has not been decided by the lower court, 
  this court will not consider it on appeal.â€Â  Mason v. Gossett, 303 S.C. 
  466, 468, 401 S.E.2d 425, 426 (Ct. App. 1991) (citations omitted).Â  
In Mason, the appellant 
  argued that the trial judge erred in granting a new trial solely on damages, 
  as opposed to granting a new trial on damages and liability, because such a 
  ruling was in violation of a statute and because the issues were so inextricably 
  intertwined that they should be tried together.Â  This court found the issues 
  not preserved for appeal because the appellant made no objection to the judgeâ€™s 
  grant of a new trial on damages alone and because the arguments raised on appeal 
  were not raised to the trial court by Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Id. at 467-68, 
  401 S.E.2d at 426.Â Â  The court noted that because the issue concerning the statutory 
  violation was not raised, that point of law was not ruled upon.Â  Id. 
  at 468, 401 S.E.2d at 426.
Similarly, in this case, the 
  issue concerning improper consideration of settlement negotiations was not raised 
  to the trial judge by objection at the time of the statement.Â  After Carter 
  moved for a new trial, the judge set forth his reasons for granting the new 
  trial on the record.Â Â  The judge reasoned initially that he could not consider 
  settlement negotiations because they were irrelevant, but then stated that â€œI 
  canâ€™t ignore the fact that I know there were negotiations and the Plaintiff 
  didnâ€™t think it was sufficient or adequate.â€Â  Morris did not contemporaneously 
  object to the judgeâ€™s consideration of the settlement negotiations.Â  Because 
  this particular objection was not ruled upon by the trial court, it is not preserved 
  for appeal.Â  See id.; see also Portman v. Garbade, 
  337 S.C. 186, 189, 90, 522 S.E.2d 830, 832 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding argument 
  that judge improperly considered evidence outside the scope of Rule 12(B)(6) 
  when granting the motion to dismiss not preserved for appeal when the issue 
  was not raised to or ruled on by the trial judge either by objection or by Rule 
  59(e) motion).Â  
Morris also contends the trial judge erred 
  by failing to consider the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party when he granted Carterâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
Under the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine, â€œa trial judge may grant a new trial upon the facts if the judge determines 
  the verdict â€˜is contrary to the fair preponderance of the evidence.â€™â€Â  McEntire 
  v. Mooregard Exterminating Servs., Inc.,Â  353 S.C. 629, 631, 578 S.E.2d 
  746, 74 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting Dent v. Redd, 270 S.C. 585, 586, 243 
  S.E.2d 460, 460 (1978)).Â  The trial judge weighs the evidence and does not view 
  it in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  
However, the trial court may also grant 
  a new trial if the verdict is excessive or inadequate.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 
  310 S.C. 375, 379, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993).Â  â€œThe trial court should grant 
  a new trial based on the excessiveness of the verdict only if the amount is 
  not merely different from that which he would have awarded, but is so grossly 
  excessive so as to shock the conscience of the court and clearly indicates that 
  the figure reached was the result of caprice, passion, prejudice, partiality, 
  corruption, or other improper motives.â€ Id. at 379-80, 426 S.E.2d at 
  805. The trial judge must consider the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the non-moving party.Â  McEntire, 353 S.C. at 631, 578 S.E.2d at 748.Â Â Â  

As a threshold matter, we must determine 
  whether the trial judge granted the motion for a new trial under the thirteenth 
  juror doctrine or as a new trial absolute.Â  Neither the judgeâ€™s oral order nor 
  his written order specifies under which doctrine he granted the new trial.Â Â  
  However, it is axiomatic that a party must first be found entitled to damages 
  before the amount of damages can be determined or challenged as inadequate.Â  
  Therefore, we find the judge could only have granted a new trial based on the 
  thirteenth juror doctrine because a new trial absolute based on the gross inadequacy 
  of the verdict is improper when the verdict is in favor of the non-moving party.Â Â  
  See Harrison v. Bevilacqua,  354 S.C. 129, 140, 580 S.E.2d 
  109, 115 (2003) (â€œIf the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate 
  or excessive so as to be the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, or some 
  other influence outside the evidence, the trial judge must grant a new trial 
  absolute.â€ (emphasis added)); Trivelas v. South Carolina Dept. of Transp., 
  357 S.C. 545, 551, 593 S.E.2d 504, 507 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œSouth Carolina's 
  thirteenth juror doctrine allows the circuit court judge to grant a new trial 
  absolute when the judge finds the evidence does not justify the verdict.â€) 
  (emphasis added)).Â  Thus, the trial judge was not required to view the evidence 
  in the light most favorable to the Morris.Â  See McEntire,Â  353 
  S.C. at 631, 578 S.E.2d at 747 (stating that under the thirteenth juror doctrine, 
  the trial judge does not view it in the light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party).
Moreover, Morris did not file a Rule 59(e) 
  motion seeking clarification on whether the judge granted a new trial based 
  on the thirteenth juror or on the ground that the verdict was grossly inadequate.Â  
  Thus, this issue is not preserved for appeal because the trial judge was never 
  afforded the opportunity to clarify his order.Â  See Talley, 289 
  S.C. at 487, 347 S.E.2d at 101 (stating that an issue must be raised to and 
  ruled upon by the trial judge in order to be preserved for review); Nelums 
  v. Cousins  304 S.C. 306, 307-08, 403 S.E.2d 681, 681-82 (Ct. 
  App. 1991) (finding appellantâ€™s argument that the judge failed to be specific 
  in his order not preserved for review because no Rule 59(e) motion was made 
  asking the judge to clarify the order). 
Accordingly, the order granting Carter a 
  new trial is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Janice Elaine Garrett,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Estate of Jerry Neil Marsh,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-650
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 
  21, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
H.W. Pat Paschal, Jr. and James H. Price, III, both of Greenville, 
  for Appellant.
Kenneth C. Porter, of Greenville ,for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this contempt action, Janice 
  Elaine Garrett (â€œWifeâ€) claimed Jerry Neill Marsh [1]  (â€œHusbandâ€) violated their separation agreement by improperly 
  deducting from her share of rental income monies expended by Husband on improvements 
  made without her prior approval. The family court found Husband in contempt 
  and ordered him to reimburse Wife for the deductions made in 2001.Â  By motion 
  to reconsider, Wife sought to introduce evidence of deductions from rental income 
  made during the years 1997, 1998, 1999, and 2000.Â  The family court granted 
  her request for the years 1999 and 2000, but barred her claims to monies for 
  the years 1997 and 1998.Â  The family court found Wifeâ€™s claims were barred by 
  res judicata.Â  Wife appeals.Â  Because Husband never pled the defense of res 
  judicata, we reverse. [2] Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were 
  divorced on November 14, 1996.Â  The final order of divorce incorporated Â Â Â Â Â  
  the partiesâ€™ separation agreement by reference.Â  Among other provisions, 
  the separation agreement provided for certain assets to be sold and the net 
  sale proceeds to be divided between the parties.Â  The agreement also contemplated 
  that some of the assets would generate rental income and provided for the rental 
  income to be used to pay certain expenses, including necessary maintenance or 
  repairs, and for any surplus to be divided between the parties.Â  The agreement 
  stipulated that such repairs must first be approved by both parties in writing.Â Â Â  

In January of 1999, Wife filed 
  a complaint seeking to hold Husband in contempt for his failure to comply with 
  certain terms of the separation agreement.Â  Wife alleged, among other things, 
  that Husband â€œfailed to account for all the income and expenses on all the properties 
  and further performed maintenance and/or repairs which were not approved, by 
  both parties in writing.â€Â  At the contempt hearing, the judge permitted Wife 
  to present five of the allegations asserted in her complaint, but did not permit 
  Wife to present the issue concerning expenses from maintenance and repairs.Â  
  The court stated at the hearing:Â  â€œIf I get an amended ruling, Iâ€™ll hear the 
  rest of it.Â  Iâ€™m going to set yâ€™all [sic] to come in at two oâ€™clock on December 
  11th, thatâ€™s a Monday.â€Â  In his written order, the court â€œfinds this 
  matter should be rescheduled and is rescheduled for December 11, 2000 at 2:00 
  p.m. for the matter to be completely tried with these remaining issues and any 
  other issues to be brought up by the parties.â€Â  Following this written order, 
  Wife moved to dismiss her rule to show cause and â€œthe remaining issues raised 
  therein with prejudice.â€Â  The court granted the motion to dismiss with prejudice.Â  

On May 8, 2001, Wife filed another 
  complaint seeking to hold Husband in contempt for, among other allegations, 
  continuing to make repairs to an office building without prior approval by Wife.Â  
  The complaint and amended complaint stated that this issue was â€œpreviously before 
  the Court on a Rule to Show Cause.â€Â  At the hearing on contempt, the judge found 
  Husband in contempt for deducting from rents due to Wife, monies Husband expended 
  on renovations to the office building without the prior approval of Wife.Â  The 
  judge did not permit the introduction of any documentation concerning the amounts 
  deducted by Husband.Â  After Wifeâ€™s counsel clarified his argument to the judge, 
  and Husbandâ€™s counsel conceded that it was improper for Husband to deduct the 
  expenses from Wifeâ€™s rental income, Wifeâ€™s counsel stated:Â  â€œI wonâ€™t submit 
  those papers then, Your Honor.â€Â  
The judge found Husband in contempt for 
  deducting expenses for repairs from Wifeâ€™s rental income without prior approval 
  of Wife.Â  Both Wife and Husband submitted proposed orders.Â  Wifeâ€™s order contained 
  figures demonstrating the amounts Husband deducted from Wifeâ€™s rental income 
  for the years 1997 through 2001.Â  Husbandâ€™s order contained figures for the 
  year 2001 only.Â  The judge accepted the figures as presented by Husband for 
  the year 2001 only, and ordered Husband to reimburse Wife $20,120.67.Â  
Wife filed a Rule 59(e) motion requesting 
  an opportunity to introduce evidence regarding the amount of expenses deducted 
  from Wifeâ€™s rental income.Â  At the hearing on the motion, Husband did not dispute 
  the figures as presented by Wife for the years 1997, 1998, 1999, and 2000.Â  
  Rather, Husband argued that Wifeâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion should be denied because 
  of the dismissal with prejudice of Wifeâ€™s 1999 rule to show cause and â€œthe remaining 
  issues raised therein.â€Â  The court granted Wifeâ€™s motion for reconsideration 
  and found that Wife was entitled to the expenses deducted for the years 1999 
  and 2000, in addition to those from the year 2001 previously ordered.Â  However, 
  the court denied the motion with respect to the years 1997 and 1998, finding 
  Wifeâ€™s claims to monies owed from those years were barred by the order granting 
  Wife a dismissal of her 1999 rule to show cause with prejudice.Â  From this order, 
  Wife appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, 
  we have authority to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 
  616, 617 (1981).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to 
  disregard the findings of the lower court.Â  Id.Â  Neither are we required 
  to ignore the fact that the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses, was 
  in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their 
  testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 
  (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife argues the family court erred in 
  denying her motion for reconsideration with respect to monies owed during the 
  years 1997 and 1998 on the basis of res judicata because the issue concerning 
  expenses for repairs was not raised in any previous proceeding or prior pleading.Â  
  Wife also argues in her reply brief that Husband was precluded from asserting 
  res judicata at the Rule 59(e) hearing because he raised this defense for the 
  first time at the hearing.Â  We agree.
A case that is dismissed â€œwith prejudiceâ€ 
  indicates adjudication on the merits and prohibits subsequent litigation by 
  res judicata as if the action had been tried to final adjudication.Â  See 
  Nelson v. QHG of South Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 311, 580 S.E.2d 
  171, 182 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).Â  â€œRes judicata requires three 
  elements: (1) the judgment must be final, valid and on the merits; (2) the parties 
  in the subsequent action must be identical in the first; (3) the second action 
  must involve matters properly included in the first action.â€Â  Latimer v. 
  Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 385, 602 S.E.2d 32, 37 (2004).Â  â€œRes judicata is an 
  affirmative defense that must be pled at trial in order to be pursued on appeal. 
  An affirmative defense is waived if not pled.â€ RIM Assocs. v. Blackwell, 
  359 S.C. 170, 182, 597 S.E.2d 152, 159 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations omitted).Â  
  Moreover, defenses not presented in the pleadings will not be considered on 
  appeal.Â  Id. at 182-83, 597 S.E.2d at 159.
In this case, Wife asserted in her 1999 
  complaint for contempt that Husband â€œfailed to account for all the income and 
  expenses on all the properties and further performed maintenance and/or repairs 
  which were not approved, by both parties in writing.â€Â  Wife voluntarily dismissed 
  this complaint with prejudice.Â  Wife sought to hold Husband in contempt again 
  in her 2001 complaint for continuing to make repairs to an office building without 
  prior approval by Wife.Â  Wifeâ€™s complaint and amended complaint stated that 
  this issue was â€œpreviously before the Court on a Rule to Show Cause.â€Â  Husband 
  answered the 2001 complaint admitting he made repairs to the building but denying 
  he was seeking reimbursement for the costs of the repairs.Â  Husband never asserted 
  res judicata as a defense to Wifeâ€™s claims in his answer or at the hearing on 
  the merits; rather, Husband raised it for the first time on reconsideration.Â  
  As a result, we find Husband waived his right to assert the defense of res judicata.Â  
  See RIM Assocs., 359 S.C. at 182-83, 597 S.E.2d at 159.Â  Â Accordingly, 
  we find the judge erred in denying Wifeâ€™s claims for monies owed during the 
  years 1997 and 1998.Â  
Because the parties stipulated the facts 
  at the Rule 59(e) hearing and Husband conceded to deducting from Wifeâ€™s rental 
  income $14,500 for renovations made without Wifeâ€™s prior approval in 1997 and 
  $10,350 in 1998, we find Wife entitled to reimbursement from Husband for those 
  funds in addition to the funds from the years 1999, 2000, and 2001 as previously 
  ordered.Â  
REVERSED.
 GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Jerry Neill Marsh died while this litigation was pending.Â  The â€œEstate 
    of Jerry Neil Marshâ€ has been substituted as a party.Â  

 
   [2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

v.

Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court

Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office

Attorney General Henry Dargan

PER CURIAM:Â  Larry Dorsey pled guilty to 
  assault and battery with intent to kill and possession of a weapon during a 
  violent crime.Â  Dorsey argues his guilty pleas failed to comply with the mandates 
  set forth in Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969).Â  His counsel attached 
  to the final brief a petition to be relieved as counsel, stating he reviewed 
  the record and concluded Dorseyâ€™s appeal was without merit.Â  Dorsey filed a 
  pro se response.Â  
After a thorough review of the record 
  pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. 
  Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and 
  grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved.

  [1]

  JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ronald Blanding,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-653
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed December 22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Walter M. Bailey, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dorchester County grand jurors 
  indicted Ronald Blanding for murder.Â  At trial, Blanding petitioned the trial 
  judge to charge the jury with the lesser-included offense of voluntary manslaughter.Â  
  The trial judge rejected this request, and the jury found Blanding guilty as 
  charged.Â  Blanding appeals on the ground that the trial judge erred in failing 
  to instruct the jury on voluntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 
  220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Harris v. State, 354 
  S.C. 382, 387, 581 S.E.2d 154, 156 (2003) (providing voluntary manslaughter 
  is the unlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion upon 
  sufficient legal provocation); State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 
  S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001) (holding the law to be charged must be determined from 
  the evidence presented at trial); State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 319, 474 
  S.E.2d 430, 430 (1996) (providing that in determining whether the evidence requires 
  a charge of voluntary manslaughter, appellate courts view the facts in a light 
  most favorable to the defendant); State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101, 525 
  S.E.2d 511, 513 (2000) (â€œTo warrant a courtâ€™s eliminating the offense of manslaughter, 
  it should very clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to 
  reduce the crime from murder to manslaughter.â€); Cole, 338 S.C. at 101-02, 
  525 S.E.2d at 513 (â€œBoth heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation must 
  be present at the time of the killingâ€ to reduce murder to manslaughter.)Â  State 
  v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 452, 529 S.E.2d 721, 728 (2000) (â€œEven when a personâ€™s 
  passions were sufficiently aroused by a legally adequate provocation, if at 
  the time of the killing those passions had cooled or a sufficiently reasonable 
  time had elapsed so that the passions of the ordinary reasonable person would 
  have cooled, the killing would be murder and not manslaughter.â€)
AFFIRMED. [1] 
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    and 220(b)(2) SCACR.
